      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528-green1.jpg?itok=qmPfwTF1" width="528" height="471" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle">Fields of Study<br />
	 </h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">MIT's SHASS fields of study at the School represent the most diverse range of scholarship at the Institute. One quality they share is the capacity to illuminate the important questions of our time.<br /><br />
	Tour the SHASS fields by clicking the arrows on this page, or select fields from the Nav Bar on the left. 

 

 </p>

            <article id="node-2133" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Graduate Studies <strong>|</strong> Postdoctoral<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/graduate/590x320_Rebecca-Millsap-Graduate-Students.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 320px;" /></p>

<div class="text">
	<p class="credits">“You have to consider that art is a very real part of our lives and societies, we have art institutions, we have funding for the arts, everyone has an idea of what it is,” says Rebecca Millsop, a PhD student in philosophy. <a href="http://news.mit.edu/2016/student-profile-rebecca-millsop-0720" target="_blank">Story</a>. (Photo: Ian MacLellan)<br />
		 </p>
</div>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><strong>Preparing for Leadership </strong><br /><br />
	PhD and MA degree students play a central role in all of the Institute's wide-ranging research activities, making a vital contribution to the educational experience of students, faculty, and to the success of the research itself.<br /><br />
	The graduate culture of MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences is very robust. Working closely with acclaimed faculty, our graduate students prepare for leadership roles in the following fields. </span></p>

<p><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>Explore the </strong><strong>Graduate Programs</strong></span><br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/comparative-media-studies/masters/">Comparative Media Studies</a><br /><br /><a href="http://economics.mit.edu/graduate">Economics</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/hasts/">HASTS: History, Anthropology, and STS </a><br /><br /><a href="http://linguistics.mit.edu/graduate/" target="_blank">Linguistics</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philos/www/admission.html">Philosophy</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/grad/index.html">Political Science</a><br /><br /><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/writing/science-writing/">Science Writing</a></span></p>

<p> </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><strong>Online Charts </strong><br /><br />
	Review the SHASS Masters and PhD programs by discipline<br /><a href="/about/organization" target="_blank">View Charts</a></span><br /><br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><span class="largerx1"><strong>Fellowships</strong><br /><br /><span class="smallerx1"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/mellon-postdoctoral-fellowship" target="_blank">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowships</a></span><br /><br /><span class="smallerx1"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/diversity-predoc" target="_blank">Diversity Predoctoral Fellowships</a></span></span></span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>Admissions Information + Applications</strong><br /><br />
	Visit the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/admissions/graduate/">MIT Graduate Admissions site</a>, where you will find all the information needed to apply to MIT's graduate programs. We wish you the best of luck in your pursuit of a graduate degree at MIT.</span></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-1699" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1><span>2018-2019 Diversity Predoctoral Fellowships</span><br /><strong>Application deadline date: To Come</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/graduate/590x320_Diversity-Predoctoral-Fellowships-Grid.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 319px;" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>The School of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences, Massachusetts Institute of Technology invites applications for the 2018-2019 Diversity Predoctoral Fellowships.  </strong></p>

<p><br />
	The purpose of the Diversity Predoctoral Fellowships program is to enhance diversity in the School and to provide the Fellow with additional professional support and mentoring as they enter the field.</p>

<p>The fellowships are intended to support scholars from a wide range of backgrounds, who can contribute to the diversity of SHASS and the higher education community. Applicants from members of racial and ethnic groups that have historically been underrepresented in the humanities and social sciences and from disadvantaged backgrounds are encouraged to apply.</p>

<p>These Fellowships support graduate scholars for a 9-month appointment at MIT that generally runs from September through May. They offer an opportunity for scholars who plan a career in higher education and have completed all other PhD requirements to finish their dissertations with access to libraries and faculty of the School. Fellows may be pursuing the PhD degree in any discipline or area taught in the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences.  Current fields of study can be viewed on <a href="/fields" target="_blank">the MIT SHASS <u>website</u></a>. Each Fellow will be affiliated with a department or program in the School. Fellows will not be required to teach while at MIT.</p>

<p>This year up to seven Fellowships will be awarded.  Each Fellowship provides a stipend of $37,500, office area, and library privileges.</p>

<p>In order to qualify for this Fellowship candidates must be:</p>

<ul><li>Authorized to work in the United States.</li>
	<li>Enrolled in a PhD program in the humanities or social sciences at an accredited institution other than MIT, have passed their PhD qualifying examinations, and have an approved dissertation proposal.</li>
	<li>Be a student of exceptional academic merit who belongs to a group underrepresented in higher education or who comes from a disadvantaged background.</li>
</ul><p>Applications consist of:</p>

<ul><li>A 2-3 page personal statement describing the student's work, dissertation, and providing any information that the student would like to present to the selection committee.  The statement should address the dissertation’s aim, methodologies (how the student will conduct the research), originality, and contribution to its field.</li>
	<li>Current curriculum vita</li>
	<li>Letter from Advisor</li>
</ul><p><b>Check back for application deadline information.</b></p>

<p>These materials should be sent to the SHASS Dean’s office at <a href="mailto:predoc-shass@mit.edu">predoc-shass@mit.edu</a>. They can be transmitted in more than one email.</p>

<p>Questions can be addressed to the SHASS Dean’s office at <u>predoc-shass@mit.edu</u>.</p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship in the Humanities <br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p class="imageonly"><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/graduate/590x320_color-shapes-on-wall.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 320px;" /><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>How to apply</strong><br />
	Read this page first for an overview of requirements. <a href="/graduate/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship_apply" target="_blank"><span>Then access the online application</span></a>.<br /><br /><strong>Next Application Cycle</strong><br />
	The current applciation cycle is completed.</p>

<hr /><h3><span class="largerx1"><strong> </strong></span></h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3><span class="largerx1">Application Process</span></h3>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>The Mellon Fellowship is for scholarship across boundaries</strong><br /><br />
	Thanks to the generous support of the Mellon Foundation, MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences awards two fellowships each year to promising young scholars working at the intersection of humanities disciplines, or between the humanities and other disciplines. This Fellowship is especially intended for scholars who work in more than one specialty within the humanities, or bridging from the humanities with other disciplines.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Terms of Appointment </strong><br /><br />
	The School of Humanities, Arts, and, Social Sciences has four departments participating in this search: Comparative Media Studies/Writing, Literature, Global Studies and Languages, Music and Theater Arts. Applicants must designate one of the four academic units in which they would like to be located. Appointments will be for two years, effective July 1, 2018. Fellows will teach one course in Spring 2019 and one per semester the following academic year, and will be in residence at MIT during this time. The salary will be $66,000 per year with standard benefits, and each Fellow will receive a research fund of $1,000 to cover travel and other costs associated with research and professional development.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Eligibility and Selection </strong><br /><br />
	To be eligible for the positions, applicants must have received their Ph.D. no earlier than July 1, 2015 and no later than July 1, 2018. If you have not earned your degree at the time you apply for the fellowship, we require an attached Letter of Certification from your institution's Registrar’s Office, Department of Graduate Studies, or your Department Head, to confirm that you are expected to be formally awarded your degree by July 1, 2018. Please make sure that your letter writer specifies the date of your expected conferral date. Applicants who have not been formally awarded their degree by July 1, 2018 will not be considered.<br /><br />
	Fellows may not hold other appointments throughout the duration of the Fellowship. Applicants must have received their degrees from institutions other than MIT. International scholars will be considered for the position, but fellowships are contingent upon eligibility to legally work within the United States. MIT will offer a J1 visa sponsorship if needed. The Mellon Selection Committee will announce the Fellows in April 2018.<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Application Materials </strong></p>

<ul><li>Letter describing the applicant's teaching and research experience, and presenting a brief proposal for a new research project to be completed during the term of the fellowship</li>
	<li>Curriculum Vitae</li>
	<li>One-page description of an undergraduate class to be offered in Spring</li>
	<li>Three letters of recommendation</li>
	<li>Letter of Certification from the Registrar’s Office, Department of Graduate Studies, or Department Head, certifying that the applicant will be formally awarded a PhD diploma by July 1, 2018. This requirement is only relevant for applicants who have not yet formally received a PhD at the time the application is due.<br />
		 </li>
</ul><hr /><p><strong>MIT-SHASS is no longer accepting applications.</strong><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Questions?</strong><br />
	Please check out the <a href="/resources/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship/faqs">FAQ page</a>. Email <a href="mailto:shass-mellon@mit.edu?subject=Mellon%20Question">shass-mellon@mit.edu</a>, or call the SHASS Dean's Office at 617-253-0888.</p>

<p><strong>Begin the Online Application</strong><br />
	The current applciation cycle is completed.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Links </strong><br /><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/mellon/postdoctoral-fellows" target="_blank">Gallery of Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows </a></p>

<p><a href="/graduate/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship_apply" target="_blank"><span>Online application</span></a></p>

<p><a href="/resources/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship/faqs">FAQ page</a></p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>FAQs<strong> | </strong>Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship <br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h3> </h3>

<p><br /><strong><img alt="" height="160" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/inside/400-faq.jpg" width="400" /></strong></p>

<p> <br /><br /><br /><strong>Are there any exceptions made regarding eligibility of applicants who received their Ph.D. outside of the date range specified?</strong><br />
	We only accept applications from candidates who have formally been awarded their degrees between [the current application cycle is completed.] We are unable to grant any exceptions to this requirement due to the nature of the fellowship.</p>

<p><br /><strong>In what form do we accept materials?</strong><br />
	We only accept online materials in the form of PDF. We ask that applicants not include any special characters, spaces, or underscores in the file names. Example: -. %. &amp;, *, #.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Can I submit an application if I applied last year?</strong><br />
	Yes. As long as you still meet all of the eligibility requirements, you can re-apply for the fellowship.</p>

<p><br /><strong>How can I send letters of recommendation?</strong><br />
	The online application system has a recommendation portal, through which applicants request letters of recommendation from their letter writers via email. The email sent to letter writers includes a link that allows writers to attach documents in PDF form. Applicants can check on the status of their letters and resend requests through our online portal. Applicants also receive a confirmation email when each letter of recommendation has been received.</p>

<p><br /><strong>How many letters of recommendation can I send?</strong><br />
	Our office requires three letters of recommendation. Additional letters will not be accepted.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Can I use a dossier service to submit my letters?</strong><br />
	Yes. Our online form will allow the dossier service to deliver the letters through the online system. If you plan on submitting your references through Interfolio, please follow the directions in our application. Instead of writing in the referee’s email, please type in the Interfolio email address attached to the letter of recommendation you would like to submit. The request for a letter will be forwarded to your Interfolio account, and you can attach it from there. Please be aware that Interfolio’s turn around time for attaching documents is two days.</p>

<p><br /><strong>If my letters do not arrive before the deadline, will my application still be accepted?</strong><br />
	You are responsible for making sure that your reference letters are submitted before the deadline. Applications missing required material cannot be considered.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Can I send additional documents not requested in the application?</strong><br />
	No. In an effort of fairness, we maintain the same requirements for each application. We will not accept any additional documents from applicants.</p>

<p><br /><strong>How can I attach a letter of certification?</strong><br />
	Our office does not view letters of certification as confidential in nature, as they are solely confirming the expected conferral date. Applicants are responsible to upload the documents themselves in the appropriate upload box on the application.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Can I send additional updates to my CV, after my application has been submitted?</strong><br />
	No. Once an application is submitted, no additions or supplements can be made.</p>

<p><br /><strong>In what languages do you accept application materials?</strong><br />
	All application materials must be submitted in English.</p>

<p><br /><strong>When will I hear if I’ve been awarded the fellowship?</strong><br />
	We expect to be able to announce the fellows in April 2018.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>How long should my teaching experience description and new research project proposal be?</strong><br />
	We do not have any restrictions on how long your letter should be. It is good to keep in mind, however, that the committee will be reviewing a high volume of applications, so it will be helpful to be descriptive yet concise. Most applicants submit letters between 1-2 pages.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>To whom should I address my letter?</strong><br />
	Your letter can be addressed to the “Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship Search Committee.”</p>

<p><br /><strong>Can my Mellon research project be a continuation of my dissertation or work on my first book? </strong><br />
	Candidates are welcome to propose a project that would involve turning their dissertations into books. Please note that a successful Mellon Proposal will be one that focuses on interdisciplinary work. We suggest making that a primary focus in your application.</p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-912" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Meet the Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="250" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/585_overlapping-color-shapes-wall.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p> </p>

<div class="text">
	<p><strong>Research across disciplines and boundaries </strong><br /><br />
		With the generous support of the Mellon Foundation, the School awards up to three fellowships each year to promising young scholars working at the intersection of humanities disciplines, or between humanities and other disciplines. This Fellowship is intended especially for scholars who work in more than one specialty within the humanities, or whose work bridges from the humanities to science, technology, or architecture.</p>

	<p> </p>

	<h4><span class="largerx1">       </span></h4>

	<table cellspacing="10" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2017-2019</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p><br /><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2017/Headshot-Abramson.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Anna Jones Abramson </strong>| Literature</h2>

					<p>Anna Jones Abramson specializes in interdisciplinary approaches to global modernist literature, with particular interests in environment and climate sciences, affect theory, war, and violence. Abramson received her Ph.D. in English from the University of California, Berkeley, in 2016 and comes to MIT following a fellowship year at Harvard University’s Mahindra Humanities Center.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, Abramson will complete her current book manuscript, <em>The Age of Atmosphere: Air, Affect, and Technology in Modernist Literature</em>. The study explores twentieth-century atmosphere in multiple senses of the word: literal air and weather; public moods; aesthetic and literary ambience. In the first few decades of the twentieth century, technological innovations such as poison gas, the airplane, the radio, and modern weather forecasting made air lethal, palpable, and legible in unprecedented ways. At the same time, modernist writers experimented with new formal strategies for generating literary atmospheres. Abramson’s project traces the historically and technologically inflected convergence of these meteorological, affective, and literary atmospheres, and considers a range of implications for contemporary crises in climate change and climate control.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td>
					<p><br /><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2017/headshot1.jpg" style="height: 200px; width: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Liz Koslov </strong>| Comparative Media Studies / Writing</h2>

					<p>Liz Koslov works at the intersection of media and cultural studies, urban studies, and the sociology of climate change. She received a Ph.D. in Media, Culture, and Communication from New York University, where she was also affiliated with the Institute for Public Knowledge.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, Liz will develop her first book project. <em>Retreat: Moving to Higher Ground in a Climate-Changed City</em>, under advance contract with the University of Chicago Press, is an ethnographic account of “managed retreat,” the relocation of people and clearing of land vulnerable to extreme weather, sea level rise, and other effects of climate change. Retreat is based on fieldwork over four years in the New York City borough of Staten Island, where coastal residents organized in favor of government buyouts of their homes after Hurricane Sandy.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><h4> </h4>

	<h4>       </h4>

	<h4> </h4>

	<h4> </h4>

	<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows <strong>|</strong> 2016-2018</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/news/2016/Flood-Photo-Crop.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Lauren Flood </strong>| Music and Theater Arts</h2>

					<p>Lauren Flood works at the intersections of music, anthropology, sound studies, and science and technology studies. She received her Ph.D. in ethnomusicology from Columbia University in 2016, with research and writing support from the Whiting Foundation, the Berlin Program for Advanced German and European Studies, and the National Science Foundation.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, she will focus on a book manuscript based on her ethnographic fieldwork in New York and Berlin, provisionally titled Permanent Prototype: DIY Futures and Sonic Instruments. The project explores how experimental instrument builders navigate ethical labor and cultural citizenship in the contexts of the do-it-yourself (DIY) ethos, maker culture, and popular, avant-garde, and underground music scenes. She is especially interested in the cultural significance of instruments and the interrelations between machines, design and craftsmanship, and “hands-on” DIY practices in an increasingly digital world.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/news/2016/hong_mit_profile_photo_1.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Sun-ha Hong </strong>| Comparative Media Studies / Writing</h2>

					<p>Sun-ha's research examines the ideals and fantasies surrounding new media technologies. He received his Ph.D. from the Annenberg School for Communication, University of Pennsylvania. His work has been published through journals like <em>First Monday</em> and <em>European Journal of Cultural Studies</em>.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, he will be working on completing one book project and beginning another. The first, <em>Data Epistemologies / Surveillance and Uncertainty</em>, analyses the changing boundaries of the known, the probable and the unknowable vis-à-vis early twenty-first century technologies of state “dragnet” surveillance and self-tracking. The second, <em>A Speculative Literature for a Data-Driven Society</em>, examines the genealogy of our imaginations about data, innovation and surveillance — from science fiction of the early twentieth century to experimental prototypes of “big” data in the present day.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

	<p> </p>

	<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2015-2017</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/MIT-Profile-Picture.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Feng-Mei Heberer </strong>| Global Studies and Languages</h2>

					<p>Feng-Mei Heberer studied film and comparative literature in Germany, France, and China before receiving her Ph.D. in Critical Studies from the University of Southern California. Her research explores Asian and Asian diasporic media cultures, in particular how they partake in and represent contemporary conditions of globalization. </p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, Feng-Mei will be working on her book manuscript on Asian diasporic video from parts of North America, Western Europe, and East Asia, and how these visual works stage new forms of minoritarian belonging. She will further delve into a new project on the representation of Asian labor in new media industries, analyzing what “Asia” means in a transnational circuit of labor that unequally exploits people and resources for the making of digital devices and online services today. </p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/marykuhn-200.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Mary Kuhn </strong>| Literature</h2>

					<p>Mary Kuhn received her Ph.D. in English from Boston University in 2014. Her book manuscript examines the relationship between literature and botanical culture in nineteenth-century America, focusing on how literary domesticity drew upon transatlantic scientific and commercial plant networks.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>While at MIT, she will consider how literary and scientific studies of sentiment work in relation to one another. Researchers in CSAIL and the Media Lab are approaching emotion through computerized “sentiment analysis” of writing, and collaborations between literary and scientific communities can demonstrate to each the techniques and expertise of the other. </p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

	<p> </p>

	<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2014-2016</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="/files/shass/cimg/news/2014/200_Mellon.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Heather Lee </strong>| Global Studies and Languages</h2>

					<p>Heather Lee received her Ph.D. from Brown University in American Studies. She studies the historical transformation of Chinese restaurants in the United States from an enclave business into one of the largest mass consumer industries.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>Blending archival research with quantitative and spatial analyses, this project tells the story of how the Chinese developed a system for shuttling capital and labor across the Pacific that accounts for the Chinese restaurant industry’s rapid growth in the early twentieth century. Alongside this research, Heather is developing a historical database of Chinese restaurants, which she will make publically available through an interactive digital platform on Chinese migration.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody><tbody><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="/files/shass/cimg/news/2014/200_2014-Mellon_mcmurray.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Peter McMurray </strong>| Music and Theater Arts</h2>

					<p>Peter McMurray is a musician, filmmaker and anthropologist of sound. He received a Ph.D. in ethnomusicology from Harvard University with a secondary field in critical media practice. His research engages questions of urban sound and Islam, particularly within the context of transnational Turkish communities in Berlin.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>While at MIT, he will be working on a book on the Islamic acoustics of Berlin as well as a series of related audiovisual media pieces. These projects build on recent media work on sensory-rich engagements with Islam, including a 16-channel audio piece, <em>God Listens to Those Who Praise Him</em> (2014), documenting some of the multifaceted sounds of Turkish Berlin, and a collaborative film with Kythe Heller, <em>Dear Bawa Muhaiyaddeen</em>, (2013), on the life and legacy of the Sri Lankan Sufi teacher and the limits of visuality. He is also an assistant curator of the Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature and a co-editor-in-chief of <em>Sensate Journal</em>. </p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

	<p> </p>

	<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2013-2015</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="/files/shass/cimg/community/Meredith-27.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Meredith Schweig </strong>| Music and Theater Arts</h2>

					<p>Meredith Schweig received her Ph.D. in ethnomusicology from Harvard University. Her research explores twentieth- and twenty-first-century music of East Asia, with a particular emphasis on popular song, narrativity, and cultural politics in Taiwan and China.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>At MIT, Schweig will be working on a book about Taiwan's hip-hop scene. The project focuses on how performers have invoked rap as a storytelling practice to make sound and sense of the dramatic social and political transformations that accompanied Taiwan's democratization at the end of the twenty-first century. A second project in development refracts questions about music, memory, and mediation through a study of pop icon Teresa Teng. </p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="/files/shass/cimg/magazine/2013/07/200_vodart.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Maria L. Vidart-Delgado </strong>| Anthropology</h2>

					<p>Maria received her Ph.D. in Anthropology from Rice University. Her research explores the design practices and ordering logics that shape political participation in late-liberal democracies. Her dissertation project looks at the introduction of an American-inspired political marketing industry into Colombian politics, and how it easily intersected with existing clientelistic political practices.</p>

					<p> </p>

					<p>While at MIT, she intends to further explore the features of liberalism that allow clientelism and media-based politics to coexist, and even thrive, under a single system. She is also currently developing a second research project that studies emergent participatory approaches in American urban design. By looking at the participatory methodologies and implementation of public interest design projects, Maria explores how these projects envision a pluralized and socially just version of a market-centered liberalism in the United States. </p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

	<p> </p>

					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Rebecca Dirksen </strong>| Music and Theater Arts</h2>

					<p>Rebecca received her Ph.D. from the University of California-Los Angeles in Ethnomusicology. She studies contemporary and classical music in Haiti, focusing upon a wide range of musical groups who have used cultural action for community development. Her dissertation is titled "Power and Potential in Contemporary Haitian Music: Mizik Angaje, Cultural Action, and Community- Led Development in Port-au-Prince." </p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>

					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Julia Lehua Panko </strong>| Literature</h2>

					<p>Julia received her Ph.D. from the University of California-Santa Barbara in Literature. She is a literature scholar who studies how changes in the technology of media storage generated innovations in literary imagination, forcing a reconceptualization of what books mean. Her dissertation is titled "Dead-tree  Data: Print Novels, Information Storage, and Media Transition, 1910/2010." </p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>

				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Marcella Szablewicz </strong>| Comparative Media Studies</h2>

					<p>Marcella received her Ph.D. from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Communication and Rhetoric. Marcella studies internet gaming in China from an ethnographic perspective, looking at the politics of video games, concerns about "addiction," and the aim of many games to "produce ideal citizens." She situates this study in the internet cafes, dorm rooms, and small apartments where gaming takes place. Her dissertation is titled "The Politics of Internet Gaming in China." </p>
				</td>

	<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-180"><tbody><tr><td> </td>
				<td>
					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2011-2013</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2011/200-chung-mellon.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Hye Jean Chung </strong>| Comparative Media Studies</h2>

					<p>Hye Jean Chung received her PhD in Film and Media Studies from the University of California, Santa Barbara, where she concentrated on transnational cinema, cross-border mobility, production studies, digital visual effects and animation, documentary film, East Asian cinema, and Asian-American cinema.   <br /><br />
						As a fellow at MIT, Chung is working on a book project that analyzes the globally dispersed and digitally networked workforce of film production pipelines, and its relation to the fictional spaces, computer-generated imagery and digital aesthetics of contemporary cinema. She is also pursuing another project that explores how media texts, cultural practices, and digital technologies manifest and actualize aspirations for global mobility.<br /><br />
						Her work has been published in journals such as <em>Spectator and Contemporaneity</em>, and in the anthology <em>Documentary Testimonies: Global Archives of Suffering</em>, edited by Bhaskar Sarkar and Janet Walker. Other essays, “Media Heterotopia and Transnational Filmmaking: Mapping Real and Virtual Worlds” and “<em>Kung Fu Panda</em>: Animated Animal Bodies as Layered Sites of (Trans)National Identities,” will appear in forthcoming issues of<em>Cinema Journal</em> and <em>The Velvet Light Trap</em>, respectively. She has recently co-edited and contributed to a themed issue of <em>Media Fields Journal</em> on the intersection of media, labor, and mobility. In addition to her scholarly endeavors, Chung has worked as a journalist, and published translations of literary works from Korean into English and vice versa.</p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2011/200-henderson-mellon.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Gretchen E. Henderson </strong>| Writing and Humanistic Studies</h2>

					<p>Gretchen E. Henderson writes across genres and the arts to invigorate her critical and creative practices. Working at the intersection of literature, art history, museum studies, disability studies, and music, her research explores aesthetics of deformity, museology as narrative strategy, poetics of (dis)embodiment / (in)accessibility / author(ity), and literary appropriations of music. She holds degrees from Princeton University, Columbia University, and the University of Missouri, as well as a Preparatory Certificate in Voice from the San Francisco Conservatory of Music. <br />
						 </p>

					<p>Gretchen’s forthcoming novels include <em>Galerie de Difformité</em>(&amp;NOW Books, winner of the Madeleine P. Plonsker Emerging Writer’s Prize) and <em>The House Enters the Street</em> (Starcherone Books), as well as a critical volume about literary appropriations of music and silence, <em>On Marvellous Things Heard</em> (Green Lantern Press), and a poetry chapbook engaging cartographic history,<em>Wreckage: By Land &amp; By Sea</em> (Dancing Girl Press). Her fiction, poetry, scholarship, and hybrid writings have been published in a number of journals and anthologies, including <em>The Kenyon Review</em>, <em>The Iowa Review</em>, <em>The Southern Review</em>, <em>Denver Quarterly</em>, <em>Black Warrior Review</em>, <em>Notre Dame Review</em>, <em>Witness, disClosure: a Journal of Social Theory</em>, <em>The &amp;NOW Awards: The Best Innovative Writing</em>, and elsewhere. Her work has been heavily influenced by residencies at artist colonies, by collaborative practice, by cross-disciplinary inquiries, and by teaching at a number of colleges.<br />
						 </p>

					<p>Among other projects while at MIT, Gretchen will be working on a book tentative titled <em>Ugliness: A Cultural History</em>, while continuing the material, collaborative deformation of her <em>Galerie de Difformité</em>, which invites participation at:<a href="http://difformite.wordpress.com/" target="_blank">difformite.wordpress.com</a>.</p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

					<h3> </h3>

					<h2 class="dotted"><strong><strong>Chuong-Dai Vo </strong>| </strong>Global Studies and Languages</h2>

					<p><strong><strong> </strong></strong></p>

					<p>Chuong-Dai Vo is working on two book projects pertaining to Asian diasporas and transnationalism. The first book project, <i>An Assemblage of Fragments: Ethics and Aesthetics in Vietnamese Transnationalism</i>, analyzes the relationship among aesthetics, post-war returns, and neoliberalism in literature, films and visual art produced about marginalized subjects in Vietnam and in the diaspora. Her second book project will be a co-edited anthology about contemporary Southeast Asian visual culture—alternative art practices and spaces.  <br /><br />
						She is co-editing with Mariam Lam and contributing to a special issue of <i>Amerasia</i> on diasporic Vietnamese cultural studies. Her publications can be found in <i>Journal of Vietnamese Studies</i>, the anthology <i>Political Regimes and the Media in Asia, </i>edited by Krishna Sen and Terence Lee,<i> </i>and the forthcoming anthology <i>Film in Contemporary Southeast Asia: Cultural Interpretation and Social Intervention</i> edited by David Lim and Hiroyuki Yamamoto.</p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p><br /><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2010/200_Borsuk.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Amaranth Borsuk </strong>| Comparative Media Studies / Writing  </h2>

					<p>Amaranth Borsuk is a poet and scholar. Her PhD. is in Literature and Creative Writing from the University of Southern California, where her work focused on the use of writing technologies by modern and contemporary poets to change their relationship to the page and their constructions of authorship. <br /><br />
						As a fellow, she will undertake a book of essays on the state of digital poetics and work on her second manuscript of poems. Her essays have appeared in <em>Writing Technologies</em> and the H.D. issue of the <em>Journal for Cultural and Religious Theory</em>. Poems have recently appeared in <em>Colorado Review</em>, <em>Columbia Poetry Review</em>, AND <em>FIELD</em>, among other journals. Her long poem, <em>Tonal Saw</em>, was published as a chapbook by The Song Cave. Collaboration is central to her practice; she has translated and transverted the work of Oulipo poet Paul Braffort, working with Gabriela Jauregui; undertaken a mutationally conjoined poem project with Kate Durbin; and crafted an augmented-reality chapbook with Brad Bouse. <br /><br />
						In addition to writing and studying poetry, Amaranth is a letterpress printer and book artist whose fascination with printed matter informs her work on digital media.  </p>
				</td>
			</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

					<h4><span class="largerx1">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows | 2009-11</span></h4>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p> </p>

					<p><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2010/200_burges.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Joel Burges</strong> | Literature and Comparative Media Studies</h2>

					<p> </p>

					<p>Joel Burges received his B.A. from Yale in American Studies, and his PhD from Stanford in English and American Literature. His current research and teaching interests include twentieth and twenty-first century literature, television, and film, the relationship between technology and time in contemporary culture, critical theory, and media studies.</p>

					<p>While at MIT, Burges is working on a book provisionally entitled <i>Turning back the Clock: Technological Obsolescence and Historical Time in Contemporary Culture</i>. An essay on filmmaker Douglas Sirk related to this book has been published in the collection <i>Trash Culture: Objects and Obsolescence in Cultural Perspective, </i>edited by Gillian Pye; another essay, "Adorno's Mimeograph: The Uses of Obsolescence in <i>Minima Moralia,</i>" is forthcoming in <i>New German Critique.</i></p>

					<p>A blogger at Stanford's <a href="http://arcade.stanford.edu/" target="_blank">Arcade</a>, Burges is also working on other projects related to the status of history in contemporary culture, including: a forthcoming essay on 9/11, Hannah Arendt, and the contemporary novel; research and writing about how televisual fiction alters the shape of literary fiction after 1945, and about how TV shows such as <i>Deadwood</i> build "worlds"; and collaborating on an essay that proposes a sonic vocabulary for the study of film.</p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td>
					<p><br /><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2010/200_djwayne.jpg" width="200" /></p>
				</td>
				<td>
					<h2 class="dotted"><strong>Wayne Marshall</strong> | Global Studies and Languages and Music</h2>

					<p>Wayne Marshall is an ethnomusicologist focusing on the musical and cultural production of the Caribbean and the Americas, and their circulation in the wider world, with particular attention to digital technologies.</p>

					<p>While a Mellon Fellow at MIT, he's writing a book on music, networked media, and transnational youth culture. He recently co-edited and contributed to <i>Reggaeton</i> (Duke University Press 2009), and has published in journals such as <i>Popular Music</i> and <i>Callaloo, </i>while writing for popular outlets like <i>The Fader</i>, <i>The Wire</i>, and the <i>Boston Phoenix</i>.</p>

					<p>He holds a PhD. in ethnomusicology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, where he completed his dissertation on migration, media, and nation, "Routes, Rap, Reggae:Hearing the Histories of Hip-Hop and Reggae Together." Dr. Marshall has taught courses and lectured on music, media, and culture at Brandeis University, University of Chicago, Harvard College, and Brown University. He is also an active DJ and maintains and runs the blog and website called <a href="http://www.wayneandwax.com/" target="_blank">Wayne and Wax</a>.</p>
				</td>
			</tr><tr><td><br /><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/graduate/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship" target="_blank"><img alt="" height="200" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/news/2010/200_apple_lightbulb.jpg" width="200" /></a></td>
				<td>
					<p> </p>

            <article id="node-2163" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Undergraduate Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/590_MISTI-Students.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 318px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>100% of MIT undergraduates study the humanities, arts, and social sciences.</strong>   </span></p>

<h4> </h4>

<p><span class="largerx2">The MIT SHASS disciplines — the humanities, arts, and social sciences — are central to the Institute's mission to provide all graduates with the knowledge, skills, and perspectives to make lasting contributions to the nation and the world.<br /><br />
	All MIT undergraduates spend substantial time on subjects like literature, languages, economics, music, political science, and history. In fact, every MIT undergraduate takes a minimum of eight such classes — about 25% of the total class time.<br /><br />
	For an online overview of the HASS options and fields of study at MIT: </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/tour" target="_blank"><strong>Take the TOUR de SHASS</strong></a></span><br /><br /><br /><span class="largerx2">Explore the following pages for more information and ideas:  </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/news/news-2014-power-of-humanities-arts-social-sciences-at-mit" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Power of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/hass" target="_blank">The HASS Requirement</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/comm-requirement" style="font-size: 0.92em;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Communication Requirement</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/majors" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Majors</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/minors" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Minors</span></a><br /><br /><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Concentrations</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/joint" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Joint Degrees</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Interdisciplinary Programs</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/harvard" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Harvard/MIT Cross-Registration Program</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/classes" target="_blank">Introductory Classes</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/news" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">HASS Exploration Subjects</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/courses-on-diversity-related-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS Diversity Subjects</span></a></span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/programs/courses-current-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS classes related to current U.S. social, political, and economic issues</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">FAQs</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships" target="_blank">Student Awards and Opportunities</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Contacts for Information + Assistance</span></a></span></p>

<p> </p>

<p><br /><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528-green1.jpg?itok=qmPfwTF1" width="528" height="471" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle">Fields of Study<br />
	 </h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">MIT's SHASS fields of study at the School represent the most diverse range of scholarship at the Institute. One quality they share is the capacity to illuminate the important questions of our time.<br /><br />
	Tour the SHASS fields by clicking the arrows on this page, or select fields from the Nav Bar on the left. 

 

 </p>

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528-green1.jpg?itok=qmPfwTF1" width="528" height="471" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle">Fields of Study<br />
	 </h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">MIT's SHASS fields of study at the School represent the most diverse range of scholarship at the Institute. One quality they share is the capacity to illuminate the important questions of our time.<br /><br />
	Tour the SHASS fields by clicking the arrows on this page, or select fields from the Nav Bar on the left. 

 

 </p>

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528_anthropology-mongolia.jpg?itok=Xphjzg33" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:10.09317%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/">Anthropology</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">"Culture is not quaint or exotic tradition, nor produced only by artists. Culture is a system of signs and practices through which humans interact and communicate."<br />
	 </p>
                                <p class="author">Susan Silbey, Goldberg Professor of Humanities; Professor of Sociology and Anthropology</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/">Visit Anthro @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/cis/">Center for International Studies</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“CIS has a great reputation, not only for deep thinking, but also for turning those thoughts into action. I have an opportunity here to engage with people who are thinking seriously about the challenges we face in the world today.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
Admiral William Fallon<br />
Robert E. Wilhelm Fellow<br />
2008-09 </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/cis/">Visit CIS @ MIT</a></p>

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528_CMSW-FoS-website-page.jpg?itok=026e9gdA" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/">Comparative Media Studies / Writing </a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“Media at MIT? The answer goes beyond ‘yes’ to a fundamental repositioning of the term ‘media’ from the familiar domain of media texts to a larger order that includes systems, technologies, and implications.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
William Uricchio<br />
Professor of Literature<br />
CMS/W</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/">Visit CMS/W @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/economics/www">Economics</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“Even the very best ideas in science or engineering do not automatically translate into broader economic prosperity. In large measure, the material benefits of innovation spring from complementarities between technology and economics.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
Ben Bernanke, PhD ’79<br />
Chairman, US Federal Reserve Board</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/economics/www">Visit Economics @ MIT</a></p>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu">Global Studies and Languages </a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“Giving MIT students deep knowledge of other languages and cultures, and the capacity to be global citizens and wise leaders, is vital to a 21st century education—and critical to the Institute's leadership position.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Deborah Fitzgerald<br />
	Professor of the History of Technology<br />
	 </p>

        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/gcws">Graduate Consortium in Women's Studies</a></h1>

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528x468_GSL_emblem-Subbiah.jpg?itok=6wX-e-Iy" width="528" height="468" alt="Global Studies and Languages image " /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu">Global Studies and Languages </a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“Giving MIT students deep knowledge of other languages and cultures, and the capacity to be global citizens and wise leaders, is vital to a 21st century education—and critical to the Institute's leadership position.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Deborah Fitzgerald<br />
	Professor of the History of Technology<br />
	 </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu">Visit GSL @ MIT</a></p>

            <article id="node-21" class="node node-dspcpage">

  <div id="divnodecontent">

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528_history-leo.jpg?itok=EDAuyVkd" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://history.mit.edu/">History</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“The lives of ordinary people matter not only because they are the greater part of human experience, but also because by knowing what they say and experience we gain a richer, more accurate understanding of the great as well as the small currents of history.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
	John W. Dower<br />
	Professor of History </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://history.mit.edu/">Visit History @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528-jpal.jpg?itok=tU7YX82Q" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://www.povertyactionlab.org">Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab </a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“Ms. Duflo, Mr. Banerjee and their colleagues have a simple, if radical, goal. They want to overhaul development aid so that more of it is spent on programs that actually make a difference.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
David Leonhardt<br />
The New York Times</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://www.povertyactionlab.org">Visit J-PAL @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

  <div id="divnodecontent">

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528_Fields-MISTI-yellow-vest.jpg?itok=NiuYYQdP" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.19876%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/misti/">MIT International Science and Technology Initiatives</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“When you ask students about their MISTI experience, the word that comes up over and over is ‘transformational.' The professional challenges and cultural immersion made them smarter and wiser—about the world and about themselves.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Susan Hockfield<br />
Former MIT President<br />
 </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/misti/">Visit MISTI @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->

      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philos/www/">Philosophy</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“All the members of the program, whatever their areas of special focus, believe that developments in the philosophy of language had a major impact on philosophy generally, throughout the 20th century.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Judith Jarvis Thomson, Professor Emeritus of Philosophy</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philos/www/">Visit Philosophy @ MIT</a></p>

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528-sciwrite.jpg?itok=HmerCt05" width="528" height="468" alt="" /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://sciwrite.mit.edu/">Graduate Program in Science Writing</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“For MIT to have a graduate program in writing about science for a public audience sends the message that we feel the public should be engaged with the scientific enterprise. That's a critical message for citizens, and for the country as a whole.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Alan Lightman<br />
Program Co-founder </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://sciwrite.mit.edu/">Visit GPSW @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/">Science, Technology and Society</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“The STS program is a unique interdisciplinary enterprise where faculty and students explore how politics, culture, and ethics shape science and technology—and vice versa.”</p>
                                <p class="author">Charles M. Vest<br />
MIT President Emeritus </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/">Visit STS @ MIT</a></p>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://theaterarts.mit.edu/">Theater Arts</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">“My study of physics has enabled me to better step back and analyze the mechanics of an issue or a problem. Theater has enabled me to better examine an issue or a problem in terms of its human relevance.”</p>
                                <p class="author"><br />
Kenneth L. Roraback<br />
SB ’06, Physics + Theater</p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://theaterarts.mit.edu/">Visit Theater @ MIT</a></p>

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <!-- photo -->
      <div class="mainimage"><img src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/styles/dspcimg/public/img/dspc/528x468_Holmes-Ties%20that%20bind.jpg?itok=Fn0f9UMb" width="528" height="468" alt="Detail of Collage, by Ekua Holmes " /></div>

      <!-- text box -->
      <div class="maintext gray" style="margin-top:13.97516%;">
        <h1 class="boxtitle"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/wgs/">Women's and Gender Studies</a></h1>
        <div class="boxtext">
                      <p class="quote">"Re-vision, the act of looking back, of seeing wtih fresh eyes, of entering an old text from a new critical direction is - for women — more than a chapter in cultural history; it is an act of survival."<br /><br /><span class="smallerx1">Adrienne Rich</span></p>
                                <p class="author"> 

<br /><span class="smallerx1">(Image, © Ekua Holmes)</span>

 

 

 

 </p>
                                <p class="link"><a href="http://web.mit.edu/wgs/">Visit WGS @ MIT</a></p>
                  </div><!-- boxtext -->
      </div><!-- text -->

            <article id="node-2133" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Graduate Studies <strong>|</strong> Postdoctoral<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/graduate/590x320_Rebecca-Millsap-Graduate-Students.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 320px;" /></p>

<div class="text">
	<p class="credits">“You have to consider that art is a very real part of our lives and societies, we have art institutions, we have funding for the arts, everyone has an idea of what it is,” says Rebecca Millsop, a PhD student in philosophy. <a href="http://news.mit.edu/2016/student-profile-rebecca-millsop-0720" target="_blank">Story</a>. (Photo: Ian MacLellan)<br />
		 </p>
</div>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><strong>Preparing for Leadership </strong><br /><br />
	PhD and MA degree students play a central role in all of the Institute's wide-ranging research activities, making a vital contribution to the educational experience of students, faculty, and to the success of the research itself.<br /><br />
	The graduate culture of MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences is very robust. Working closely with acclaimed faculty, our graduate students prepare for leadership roles in the following fields. </span></p>

<p><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>Explore the </strong><strong>Graduate Programs</strong></span><br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/comparative-media-studies/masters/">Comparative Media Studies</a><br /><br /><a href="http://economics.mit.edu/graduate">Economics</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/hasts/">HASTS: History, Anthropology, and STS </a><br /><br /><a href="http://linguistics.mit.edu/graduate/" target="_blank">Linguistics</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philos/www/admission.html">Philosophy</a><br /><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/grad/index.html">Political Science</a><br /><br /><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/writing/science-writing/">Science Writing</a></span></p>

<p> </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><strong>Online Charts </strong><br /><br />
	Review the SHASS Masters and PhD programs by discipline<br /><a href="/about/organization" target="_blank">View Charts</a></span><br /><br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><span class="largerx1"><strong>Fellowships</strong><br /><br /><span class="smallerx1"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/mellon-postdoctoral-fellowship" target="_blank">Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowships</a></span><br /><br /><span class="smallerx1"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/diversity-predoc" target="_blank">Diversity Predoctoral Fellowships</a></span></span></span><br /><br /><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>Admissions Information + Applications</strong><br /><br />
	Visit the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/admissions/graduate/">MIT Graduate Admissions site</a>, where you will find all the information needed to apply to MIT's graduate programs. We wish you the best of luck in your pursuit of a graduate degree at MIT.</span></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-427" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Mellon Postdoctoral Fellowship in the Humanities <br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p class="imageonly"><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/graduate/590x320_color-shapes-on-wall.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 320px;" /><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>How to apply</strong><br />
	Read this page first for an overview of requirements. <a href="/graduate/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship_apply" target="_blank"><span>Then access the online application</span></a>.<br /><br /><strong>Next Application Cycle</strong><br />
	The current applciation cycle is completed.</p>

<hr /><h3><span class="largerx1"><strong> </strong></span></h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3><span class="largerx1">Application Process</span></h3>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>The Mellon Fellowship is for scholarship across boundaries</strong><br /><br />
	Thanks to the generous support of the Mellon Foundation, MIT's School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences awards two fellowships each year to promising young scholars working at the intersection of humanities disciplines, or between the humanities and other disciplines. This Fellowship is especially intended for scholars who work in more than one specialty within the humanities, or bridging from the humanities with other disciplines.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Terms of Appointment </strong><br /><br />
	The School of Humanities, Arts, and, Social Sciences has four departments participating in this search: Comparative Media Studies/Writing, Literature, Global Studies and Languages, Music and Theater Arts. Applicants must designate one of the four academic units in which they would like to be located. Appointments will be for two years, effective July 1, 2018. Fellows will teach one course in Spring 2019 and one per semester the following academic year, and will be in residence at MIT during this time. The salary will be $66,000 per year with standard benefits, and each Fellow will receive a research fund of $1,000 to cover travel and other costs associated with research and professional development.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Eligibility and Selection </strong><br /><br />
	To be eligible for the positions, applicants must have received their Ph.D. no earlier than July 1, 2015 and no later than July 1, 2018. If you have not earned your degree at the time you apply for the fellowship, we require an attached Letter of Certification from your institution's Registrar’s Office, Department of Graduate Studies, or your Department Head, to confirm that you are expected to be formally awarded your degree by July 1, 2018. Please make sure that your letter writer specifies the date of your expected conferral date. Applicants who have not been formally awarded their degree by July 1, 2018 will not be considered.<br /><br />
	Fellows may not hold other appointments throughout the duration of the Fellowship. Applicants must have received their degrees from institutions other than MIT. International scholars will be considered for the position, but fellowships are contingent upon eligibility to legally work within the United States. MIT will offer a J1 visa sponsorship if needed. The Mellon Selection Committee will announce the Fellows in April 2018.<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Application Materials </strong></p>

<ul><li>Letter describing the applicant's teaching and research experience, and presenting a brief proposal for a new research project to be completed during the term of the fellowship</li>
	<li>Curriculum Vitae</li>
	<li>One-page description of an undergraduate class to be offered in Spring</li>
	<li>Three letters of recommendation</li>
	<li>Letter of Certification from the Registrar’s Office, Department of Graduate Studies, or Department Head, certifying that the applicant will be formally awarded a PhD diploma by July 1, 2018. This requirement is only relevant for applicants who have not yet formally received a PhD at the time the application is due.<br />
		 </li>
</ul><hr /><p><strong>MIT-SHASS is no longer accepting applications.</strong><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Questions?</strong><br />
	Please check out the <a href="/resources/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship/faqs">FAQ page</a>. Email <a href="mailto:shass-mellon@mit.edu?subject=Mellon%20Question">shass-mellon@mit.edu</a>, or call the SHASS Dean's Office at 617-253-0888.</p>

<p><strong>Begin the Online Application</strong><br />
	The current applciation cycle is completed.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Links </strong><br /><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/academics/graduate/mellon/postdoctoral-fellows" target="_blank">Gallery of Mellon Postdoctoral Fellows </a></p>

<p><a href="/graduate/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship_apply" target="_blank"><span>Online application</span></a></p>

<p><a href="/resources/mellon_postdoctoral_fellowship/faqs">FAQ page</a></p>

            <article id="node-1134" class="node node-video">

  <div id="divnodecontent">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Robert Lepage conducts creative workshop with MIT students<br />
 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
                  <p><iframe src="http://techtv.mit.edu/embeds/18089?html5=true&amp;size=custom&amp;custom_width=590&amp;player=simple&amp;external_stylesheet=" height="364" frameborder="0" width="590"></iframe> </p>
                        <p>A master shares his creative methods with MIT students.  <br /><br />
Acclaimed multidisciplinary and performance artist Robert Lepage, winner of the 2012 McDermott Award, conducts a theater workshop with MIT students. Renowned as a director, filmmaker, playwright, and actor, Lepage is currently directing <em>Der Ring des Nibelungen </em>at the Metropolitan Opera in New York.<br /><br />
Versatile in every form of theatre craft, Robert Lepage is equally talented as a director, playwright, actor and film director. His creative and original approach to theatre, which incorporates new technologies, has won him international acclaim. Lepage is currently directing <em>Der Ring des Nibelungen </em>at the Metropolitan Opera in New York. He has created two <em>Cirque du Soleil</em> productions and <em>The Image Mill™  </em>— a spectacular architectural illumination and  urban projection.</p>
<p>The McDermott Award celebrates innovative talents in all arts  disciplines and is one of the most generous cultural honors in the U.S.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Suggested Links </strong></p>
<p><a href="http://arts.mit.edu/mcdermott/lepage-at-mit/" target="_blank"><br />
Lepage at MIT</a></p>
<p><a href="http://arts.mit.edu/mcdermott/2012-recipient/" target="_blank">Arts at MIT | Robert Lepage</a></p>
<p><a href="http://lacaserne.net/index2.php/robertlepage/" target="_blank">Ex Machina | about Lepage</a><br /><a href="http://lacaserne.net/index2.php/exmachina/gallery_video/" target="_blank"><br />
Video Gallery | Lepage and Ex Machina</a> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><img width="180" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/multimedia/2012/180_lepage-projection.jpg" alt="" /></p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>              </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Research by Field<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <div class="maintext">
	<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/research/590x320_Man-in-Field-HumanFactor-emblem.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 320px;" /><br /><em><span class="smallerx1">Image from the Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab, a program of the Department of Economics </span></em><br />
		 </p>

	<hr /><p> </p>

	<p><span class="largerx2">MIT SHASS generates research that helps alleviate poverty; safeguard elections; steer economies; understand the past and present; assess the impact of new technologies; understand language and human cultures; create new forms at the juncture of art and science; and inform policy and cultural mores on critical issues, including justice, healthcare, energy, climate, education, jobs, manufacturing, elections, national security, immigration, human rights, and economic equity.<br /><br />
		Learn about leading MIT humanities, arts, and social science research in these fields:</span></p>

	<p> </p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://www.povertyactionlab.org/evaluations" target="_blank">Abdul Latif Jameel Poverty Action Lab</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://anthropology.mit.edu/research" target="_blank">Anthropology</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://cis.mit.edu/publications/research-activities" target="_blank">Center for International Studies</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/research-groups/" target="_blank">Comparative Media Studies/Writing</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://economics.mit.edu/about/research" target="_blank">Economics</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="https://mitgsl.mit.edu/research-projects" target="_blank">Global Studies and Languages</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="https://history.mit.edu/research-urop" target="_blank">History</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://linguistics.mit.edu/research/" target="_blank">Linguistics</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://lit.mit.edu/curriculum/" target="_blank">Literature</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://mta.mit.edu/research" target="_blank">Music and Theater Arts</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/philosophy/dissertations.html" target="_blank">Philosophy</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/research/index.html" target="_blank">Political Science</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/research/index.html" target="_blank">Science, Technology, and Society</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/ssp/research/index.html" target="_blank">Security Studies Program</a></span></p>

	<p><span class="largerx1"><a class="external" href="https://wgs.mit.edu/research" target="_blank">Women's and Gender Studies</a></span></p>
</div>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->
