            <article id="node-1982" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Selected SHASS Courses on MIT OpenCourseWare<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/resources/education-innovation-gallery-of-innovations" target="_blank">From the Gallery of Innovations</a></p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Political Science</b></p>

<p><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/political-science/17-445-international-relations-theory-in-the-cyber-age-fall-2015/this-course-at-mit/" target="_blank"><i>17.445/17.446 International Relations Theory in the Cyber Age (Fall 2015), Nazli Choucri</i></a><br />
	Nazli Choucri comments on the importance of active participation during seminars and shares how she uses questions to promote engagement.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Anthropology</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/anthropology/21a-445j-slavery-and-human-trafficking-in-the-21st-century-spring-2015/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21A.445 Slavery and Human Trafficking in the 21st Century (Spring 2015), Mitali Thakor</i></a><br />
	Mitali Thakor describes how she uses non-traditional examples to broaden students’ understanding of human trafficking, how she thinks about students’ emotional responses to triggering topics, how she navigates teaching as a new instructor, and her thoughts on using writing assignments to encourage students to complete reading assignments.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Comparative Media Studies/Writing</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/comparative-media-studies-writing/21w-758-genre-fiction-workshop-spring-2013/this-course-at-mit"><i>21W.758 Genre Fiction Workshop (Spring 2013), Shariann Lewitt</i></a><br />
	Shariann Lewitt shares unique aspects of teaching fiction writing at MIT and discusses how she teaches students to challenge texts.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/comparative-media-studies-writing/21w-747-rhetoric-spring-2015/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21W.747 Rhetoric (Spring 2015), Steven Strang</i></a><br />
	Steven Strang describes how he facilitates writing workshops and how he changes the course from year to year.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/urban-studies-and-planning/11-127j-computer-games-and-simulations-for-education-and-exploration-spring-2015/this-course-at-mit/"><i>CMS.590J Computer Games and Simulations for Education and Exploration (Spring 2015), Eric Klopfer</i></a><br />
	Eric Klopfer describes the form and function of teamwork in this course. He also shares tips for facilitating project-based learning.</p>

<p><em><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/comparative-media-studies-writing/cms-301-introduction-to-game-design-methods-spring-2016/this-course-at-mit/" target="_blank">CMS.301 Introduction to Game Design Methods (Spring 2016), Mikael Jakobsson and Sara Verrilli</a></em><br />
	The instructors discuss course design and “cultivating an atmosphere in which peer feedback is an important part of the learning experience.”</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/comparative-media-studies-writing/cms-611j-creating-video-games-fall-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>CMS.611J Creating Video Games (Fall 2014), Philip Tan, Sara Verrilli, Richard Eberhardt, and Andrew Haydn Grant</i></a><br />
	The instructors share their pedagogical approaches in 8 videos. Topics include: teaching students how to solve creative problems as teams; sequencing learning experiences; encouraging iteration, fostering diversity of voice in the course; assessing students’ projects; refining the course; advice for other educators; and their reflections on the collaboration between MIT and the Red Cross/Red Crescent Society during the course. <i> </i></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/comparative-media-studies-writing/cms-608-game-design-spring-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>CMS.608/CMS.864 Game Design (Spring 2014), Philip Tan and Richard Eberhardt</i></a><br />
	Philip Tan and Richard Eberhardt discuss how they prepare for the semester and class sessions, how they help students build game-playing experience, their assessment design, and factors, such as student background and feedback from students, that impact how they teach the course. </p>

<p><b> </b></p>

<p><b>Global Studies and Languages</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/global-studies-and-languages/21g-101-chinese-i-regular-fall-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21G.101 Chinese I (Regular) (Fall 2014), Haohsiang Liao</i></a><br />
	In video interviews, recorded in both English and Chinese, Haohsiang Liao shares how the curriculum in this course helps students develop cultural competence. He also describes the daily grading system in the course, the importance of listening to audio files, reasons to prioritize speaking and listening before reading and writing, how he supports struggling students, how he creates an immersive classroom environment, and how he motivates students to engage in language study.<i> </i></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/global-studies-and-languages/21g-107-chinese-i-streamlined-fall-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21G.107 Chinese I (Streamlined) (Fall 2014), Min-Min Liang</i></a><br />
	In video interviews, recorded in both English and Chinese, Min-Min Liang shares her philosophical approach to language teaching, her insights about teaching heritage learners, her use of technology in this streamlined language course, her approach to assessment, and her hopes for incorporating more authentic texts into the curriculum in future iterations of the course.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/global-studies-and-languages/21g-735-advanced-topics-in-hispanic-literature-and-film-the-films-of-luis-bunuel-fall-2013/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21G.735 Advanced Topics in Hispanic Literature and Film: The Films of Luis Bunuel (1999-2013), Elizabeth Garrels</i></a><br />
	This course was taught at MIT seven times between 1999 and 2013. Elizabeth Garrels shares a history of the course, her film selections, and how she facilitated discussions in Spanish with students at different language proficiency levels. </p>

<p><em><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/resources/res-21g-001-the-user-friendly-classroom-spring-2016/this-resource-at-mit/" target="_blank">RES.21G-001 The User-Friendly Classroom, A.C. Kemp</a></em><br />
	A.C. Kemp discusses the importance of focusing on International Teaching Assistants (ITAs), shares how user experience can be applied to ITA training, and ways to use the materials in this video training series. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Science, Technology, and Society</b></p>

<p><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/science-technology-and-society/sts-080-youth-political-participation-spring-2016/this-course-at-mit/" target="_blank"><i>STS.080/11.151 Youth Political Participation (Spring 2016), Jennifer Light </i></a><br />
	tudents take an active role in this course. They help the instructor, Jennifer Light, write the exam questions, lead presentations, and examine primary sources at the MIT Museum. In addition to instructor insights, visitors to the OCW course will find student perspectives about the pedagogical strategies shaping the learning experiences in this class. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>History</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/history/21h-134j-medieval-economic-history-in-comparative-perspective-spring-2012/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21H.134J Medieval Economic History in Comparative Perspective (Spring 2012), Anne McCants</i></a><br />
	Anne McCants shares insights about using a survey at the beginning of a course to understand students’ needs and backgrounds, to help students see that different students have different needs, and to encourage students to get into the habit of writing. She also discusses how she frames the humanities as problem solving endeavors and how she infuses the course with current events. Other topics include: teaching communication, the intersection of research and teaching, and adapting the course from year to year.</p>

<p><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/history/21h-343j-making-books-the-renaissance-and-today-spring-2016/this-course-at-mit/" target="_blank"><i>21H.343J Making Books: The Renaissance and Today (Spring 2016), Anne McCants, Jeffrey Ravel and Ken Stone</i></a><br />
	The instructors of this course, in which students built a printing press, discuss using archival experiences to ground readings and allay educators' skepticism about facilitating a hands-on course in the humanities.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/history/21h-991-theories-and-methods-in-the-study-of-history-fall-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21H.991 Theories and Methods in the Study of History (Fall 2014), Anne McCants</i></a><br />
	Anne McCants shares how she engages students in archive-based research, how she infuses the course with multiple voices, and how she helps students develop professional competencies. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Literature</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/literature/21l-011-the-film-experience-fall-2013/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21L.011 The Film Experience (Fall 2013), David Thorburn</i></a><br />
	David Thorburn shares his pedagogical approach to teaching film in seven videos. Topics include his approach to lecturing, how he views the course as literary in nature, how the course has changed over the 30 years that he has taught it, the role of video lectures, and the themes structuring course.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/literature/21l-315-prizewinners-nobelistas-spring-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21L.315 Prizewinners: Nobelistas (Spring 2015), Wyn Kelley</i></a><br />
	Wyn Kelley shares how she selects Nobelistas to spotlight in the course, how she facilitates discussions, and her approach to teaching novices. </p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/literature/21l-460-medieval-literature-legends-of-arthur-fall-2013/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21L.460 Medieval Literature: Legends of Arthur (Fall 2013), Arthur Bahr</i></a><br />
	Arthur Bahr describes how he sets the stage for the study of Arthurian literature with a key question, how he encourages participation during classroom discussions, and his ideas for alternative assessment strategies in the course. </p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/literature/21l-501-the-american-novel-stranger-and-stranger-spring-2013/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21L.501 The American Novel: Stranger and Stranger (Spring 2013), Wyn Kelley</i></a><br />
	Wyn Kelley describes her motivation for developing the course and how she organizes it. She also describes her text selection, the digital tools she uses in the course, workshops, and unique aspects of teaching literature at MIT.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/literature/21l-705-major-authors-old-english-and-beowulf-spring-2014/this-course-at-mit/"><i>21L.705 Major Authors: Old English (Spring 2014), Arthur Bahr</i></a><br />
	Arthur Bahr describes the curricular scope and sequence of the course, his textbook choice, how he assesses student learning, and how he develops rapport with students. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Music and Theater Arts</b></p>

<p><a href="https://ocw.mit.edu/courses/music-and-theater-arts/21m-380-music-and-technology-sound-design-spring-2016/this-course-at-mit/" target="_blank"><i>21M.380 Music and Technology: Sound Design (Spring 2016), Florian Hollerweger </i></a><br />
	Florian Hollerweger discusses course design, teaching with technology (and without), learning actively in groups, using surveys to get to know students, assessing student learning in creative contexts, and engaging students deeply in the design process.</p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/music-and-theater-arts/21m-065-introduction-to-musical-composition-spring-2014/this-course-at-mit"><i>21M.065 Introduction to Musical Composition (Spring 2014), Keeril Makan </i></a><br />
	Keeril Makan describes his pedagogical goals in the course, which include helping students develop different ways of listening to music and to their environments and providing students with a hands-on introduction to music. He also shares pedagogical strategies, such as emphasizing student performance, using paper and pencil before employing software to complete projects, and engaging students in composer forums and concerts.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Linguistics and Philosophy</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/linguistics-and-philosophy/24-191-ethics-in-your-life-being-thinking-doing-or-not-spring-2015/this-course-at-mit/"><i>24.191 Ethics in Your Life: Being, Thinking, Doing (or Not?) (Spring 2015), Sally Haslanger, Patricia-Maria Weinmann, Brendan de Kennessy</i></a><br />
	Patricia-Maria Weinmann and Brendan de Kenessey share the history and design of this course, how they cultivated a classroom culture conducive to honest discussions, and how they experimented with a new discussion format. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><b>Women and Gender Studies</b></p>

<p><a href="http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/womens-and-gender-studies/wgs-151-gender-health-and-society-spring-2016/this-course-at-mit/"><i>WGS.151 Gender, Health, and Society (Spring 2016), Brittany Charlton</i></a><br />
	Brittany Charlton shares teaching techniques she uses to engage students, her insights on teaching content rooted in real-world contexts, and her thoughts on teaching students with a broad range of background experiences. She also discusses students’ final projects. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/resources/education-innovation-gallery-of-innovations" target="_blank">Back to the Gallery of Innovations</a></p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-2163" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Undergraduate Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/590_MISTI-Students.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 318px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>100% of MIT undergraduates study the humanities, arts, and social sciences.</strong>   </span></p>

<h4> </h4>

<p><span class="largerx2">The MIT SHASS disciplines — the humanities, arts, and social sciences — are central to the Institute's mission to provide all graduates with the knowledge, skills, and perspectives to make lasting contributions to the nation and the world.<br /><br />
	All MIT undergraduates spend substantial time on subjects like literature, languages, economics, music, political science, and history. In fact, every MIT undergraduate takes a minimum of eight such classes — about 25% of the total class time.<br /><br />
	For an online overview of the HASS options and fields of study at MIT: </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/tour" target="_blank"><strong>Take the TOUR de SHASS</strong></a></span><br /><br /><br /><span class="largerx2">Explore the following pages for more information and ideas:  </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/news/news-2014-power-of-humanities-arts-social-sciences-at-mit" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Power of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/hass" target="_blank">The HASS Requirement</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/comm-requirement" style="font-size: 0.92em;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Communication Requirement</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/majors" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Majors</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/minors" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Minors</span></a><br /><br /><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Concentrations</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/joint" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Joint Degrees</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Interdisciplinary Programs</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/harvard" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Harvard/MIT Cross-Registration Program</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/classes" target="_blank">Introductory Classes</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/news" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">HASS Exploration Subjects</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/courses-on-diversity-related-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS Diversity Subjects</span></a></span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/programs/courses-current-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS classes related to current U.S. social, political, and economic issues</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">FAQs</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships" target="_blank">Student Awards and Opportunities</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Contacts for Information + Assistance</span></a></span></p>

<p> </p>

<p><br /><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-1439" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>MIT SHASS Introductory-Level Subjects <strong>| Fall 2017</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="390" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_Undergraduate_Introductory-Classes-emblem-2.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Suggested Introductory Subjects </strong></p>

<p><br />
	The following is a list of subjects that have been suggested by the departments, programs, and sections as among those recommended for students who may not already have experience in these fields. This list is not all-inclusive, and is intended only as one possible starting point for students looking to explore the MIT SHASS fields. <a href="http://mit.edu/hassreq/exploration.html">HASS-Exploration (HEX) subjects</a>, for instance, provide another appropriate route, and many students will find additional subjects that match their own distinctive interests.</p>

<p>The full list of course offerings is available through the <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/index.cgi" target="_blank">online subject listing</a> and more information is always available through the <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/tour" target="_blank">departments, programs, and sections</a>. Students should always refer to the official subject listing for updated schedules and locations. This list may not be updated after the start of classes.<br /><br /><strong>Enjoy the exploration!  </strong><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Fields of Study </strong><br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Aa.html">Anthropology</a></h4>

<p>21A.00 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21a.00&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Anthropology: Comparing Human Cultures</a>; HASS-S  | G. Jones<br />
	21A.500J/STS.075J <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21a.500&amp;style=verbatim">Technology and Culture</a>; HASS-S  | S. Helmreich<br />
	21A.520 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21a.520&amp;style=verbatim">Magic, Science, and Religion</a>; HASS-S  | G. Jones<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/mCMSa.html">Comparative Media Studies (CMS)</a></h4>

<p>CMS.100 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=CMS.100&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Media Studies</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | J. Picker and S. Hong<br />
	CMS.300 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=CMS.300&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Videogame Theory</a>; HASS-H  | M. Jakobsson<br />
	CMS.309J/21W.763J <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=CMS.309&amp;style=verbatim">Transmedia Storytelling: Modern Science Fiction</a>; HASS-A  | H. Hendershot<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m14a.html">Economics</a></h4>

<p>14.01 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=14.01&amp;style=verbatim">Principles of Microeconomics</a>; HASS-S  | J. Gruber<br />
	14.02 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=14.02&amp;style=verbatim">Principles of Macroeconomics</a>; HASS-S  | R. Caballero<br />
	14.73 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=14.73&amp;style=verbatim">The Challenge of World Poverty</a>; HASS-S, CI-H  | F. Schilbach<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Ga.html">Global Studies and Languages (GSL)</a></h4>

<p>21G.030J/WGS.236J  <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21G.030&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to East Asian Cultures: From Zen to K-Pop</a>; HASS-H  | E. Teng<br />
	21G.064  <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21G.064&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Japanese Culture</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | P. Roquet<br />
	21G.070  <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21G.070&amp;style=verbatim">Latin America and the Global Sixties: Counterculture and Revolution</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | S. Greene<br /><br />
	GSL offers language instruction courses at a variety of levels to suit your skills. All but ELS provide subjects for complete beginners:  <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gb.html">Chinese</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gc.html">English Language Studies</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gd.html">French</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Ge.html">German</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gf.html">Japanese</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gr.html">Korean</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gh.html">Portuguese</a>, <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gq.html">Russian</a>, and <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Gs.html">Spanish</a>.</p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Ha.html">History</a></h4>

<p>21H.001 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21H.001&amp;style=verbatim">How to Stage a Revolution</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | P. Alimagham, M. Ghachem, C. Horan<br />
	21H.130 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21H.130&amp;style=verbatim">The Ancient World: Greece</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | S. Ostrow<br />
	21H.157 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21H.157&amp;style=verbatim">The Making of Modern South Asia</a>; HASS-S | S. Aiyar</p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m24b.html">Linguistics</a></h4>

<p>24.900 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=24.900&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Linguistics</a>; HASS-S, CI-H | A. Albright<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21La.html">Literature</a></h4>

<p>21L.015 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21L.015&amp;style=verbatim">Children's Literature</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | A. Bahr, M. Gubar<br />
	21L.021 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21L.021&amp;style=verbatim">Comedy</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | P. Donaldson<br />
	21L.024 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21L.024&amp;style=verbatim">Literature and Existentialism (Proposed)</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | E. Brinkema<br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Ma.html">Music</a></h3>

<p>21M.011 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.011&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Western Music</a>; HASS-A, CI-H | E. Pollock, T. Neff, A. Boyles<br />
	21M.030 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.030&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to World Music </a>; HASS-A, CI-H | P. Tang, L. Flood<br />
	21M.051 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.051&amp;style=verbatim">Fundamentals of Music</a>; HASS-A |  E. Kwon, K. Salfelder<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m24a.html">Philosophy</a></h4>

<p>24.01 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=24.01&amp;style=verbatim">Classics of Western Philosophy</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | S. Haslanger<br />
	24.02 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=24.02&amp;style=verbatim">Moral Problems and the Good Life</a>; HASS-H, CI-H | K. Setiya<br />
	24.08J/9.48J <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=24.08&amp;style=verbatim">Philosophical Issues in Brain Science</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | E. J. Green<br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m17a.html">Political Science</a></h3>

<p>17.20 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=17.20&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to the American Political Process</a>; HASS-S, CI-H  | D. Caughey<br />
	17.40 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=17.40&amp;style=verbatim">American Foreign Policy: Past, Present, and Future</a>; HASS-S, CI-H | S. Van Evera<br />
	17.50 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=17.50&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Comparative Politics</a>; HASS-S, CI-H | C. Lawson<br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/mSTSa.html">Science, Technology, and Society (STS)</a></h3>

<p>STS.004 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=STS.004&amp;style=verbatim">Intersections: Science, Technology, and the World</a>; HASS-H  | D. Fitzgerald<br />
	STS.026 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=STS.026&amp;style=verbatim">History of Manufacturing in America</a>; HASS-H  | M. Roe Smith<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Mb.html">Theater Arts</a></h4>

<p>21M.603 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.603&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Design for the Theater</a>; HASS-A  | S. Brown<br />
	21M.604J/21W.754J <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.604&amp;style=verbatim">Playwriting I</a>; HASS-A  | L. Harrington, K. Urban<br />
	21M.605 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21m.605&amp;style=verbatim">Voice and Speech for the Actor</a>; HASS-A  | K. Eastley, O. D'Ambrosio<br />
	 </p>

<h4><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/mWGSa.html">Women's and Gender Studies (WGS)</a></h4>

<p>WGS.101 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=WGS.101&amp;style=verbatim">Introduction to Women’s and Gender Studies</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | A. Walsh<br />
	WGS.110J/21H.108J  <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=WGS.275&amp;style=verbatim">Sexual and Gender Identities</a>; HASS-H  | C. Horan<br />
	WGS.S10 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=WGS.S10&amp;style=verbatim">Special Subject: History of Women in Science and Engineering (New)</a> | M. Weinstock<br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/m21Wa.html">Writing</a></h3>

<p>21W.747 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21w.747&amp;style=verbatim">Rhetoric</a>; HASS-H, CI-H  | S. Strang<br />
	21W.755 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21w.755&amp;style=verbatim">Writing and Reading Short Stories</a>; HASS-A  | S. Lewitt<br />
	21W.762 <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/search.cgi?search=21w.775&amp;style=verbatim">Poetry Workshop</a>; HASS-A  | E. Barrett</p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-1980" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>MIT SHASS courses on diversity-related issues<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/590_diversity-dna.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 285px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>At MIT, diversity and inclusion are core values</strong>. In MIT’s School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences these values strengthen our teaching and research, and are embodied in the backgrounds and perspectives of our faculty and students. The MIT SHASS faculty teach a large number of classes on diversity-related issues, including classes with a focus on:</p>

<p><br />
	    • <a href="#Race">Race or ethnicity in the United States</a><br />
	    • <a href="#Cultures">Cultures outside the United States</a><br />
	    • <a href="#Gender">Gender and/or sexuality</a><br />
	    • <a href="#Globalization">Globalization or transnationalism</a><br />
	 </p>

<p>See below for a list of diversity-related classes, organized around these four themes<em>. </em>And please refer to the <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/" target="_blank">official subject listings</a> for updated schedules and locations.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>For more information about MIT’s diversity, equity, and inclusion programs, visit: <a href="http://diversity.mit.edu/" target="_blank">http://diversity.mit.edu/</a></p>

<p> </p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>The Top HASS FAQs<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br />
	 <img alt="" height="160" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/400-faq.jpg" width="400" /></p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>Is your question here? </strong> <br />
	Over the years, the SHASS Dean's Office team has fielded many questions. Yours might already be here, so please take a look at the links below.  </p>

<p><br /><strong>FAQs about...</strong></p>

<p><strong><a href="/undergraduate/faqs/minors" target="_blank">Minors</a></strong> |  <strong><a href="/undergraduate/faqs/majors" target="_blank">Majors</a></strong><br />
	 </p>

<p>If you don't find an answer to your question in the FAQs above, please contact one of the following people: <br />
	 </p>

<p>For questions about:</p>

<ul><li>The HASS Requirement</li>
	<li>Concentrations</li>
	<li>Petitions for substitutions within the HASS Requirement</li>
	<li>Overlap between the HASS and Communication Requirements</li>
</ul><p>Contact: <a href="mailto:hassreq@mit.edu">hassreq@mit.edu</a><br />
	Patty Fernandes<br />
	Office of the HASS Requirement<br />
	5-133<br />
	x3-2313 <br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank">http://web.mit.edu/hassreq</a></p>

<p> </p>

<p>For questions about:</p>

<ul><li>HASS Minors</li>
	<li>Interdisciplinary Majors</li>
	<li>Course 21E / 21S Majors</li>
	<li>General SHASS information</li>
	<li>Advising for special concentrations</li>
</ul><p>Contact: <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">awirth@mit.edu</a><br />
	Andrea Wirth<br />
	SHASS Academic Administrator<br />
	4-240<br />
	x3-4441<br /><a href="https://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank">http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate</a></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-276" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Questions about Majors<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="130" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/inside/130-question-key.jpg" style="border: 0px;" width="130" /><br /><br /><br /><strong>Who do I talk to about majors in HASS?</strong><br />
	You should speak to someone in the individual <a href="/undergraduate/majors">department, section or program</a> you’re interested in. This might be a faculty member and/or the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/acadinfo/deptcontacts/undergrad_administrators.html">Undergraduate Academic Administrator</a> in the Headquarters Office. They are happy to help.</p>

<p><strong>What are interdisciplinary majors (formerly major departures) within SHASS?</strong><br />
	An interdisciplinary major is a major by special arrangement in one of six specific fields in Humanities requiring approval by the SHASS Dean. Information is available <a href="/undergraduate/majors">online</a> or by appointment with the <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">SHASS Academic Administrator</a>. Students write an interdisciplinary major proposal, list the courses they intend to include in their major program, and obtain the approval of the Faculty Advisor for that field. Students receive an S.B. in "Humanities."</p>

<p><strong>Can I major and concentrate in the same field?</strong><br />
	Each department, program and section in HASS has its own policy in regard to majoring and concentrating in the same field. You should contact the <a href="/undergraduate/majors">field office</a> for information on a specific field.</p>

<p><strong>If I major in a HASS department how many of my classes can count toward my major and toward the HASS requirement?</strong><br />
	MIT leaves this up to each <a href="/undergraduate/majors">department, program, or section</a>.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

            <article id="node-275" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Questions about Minors<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="130" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/130-question-key.jpg" width="130" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>When is my Minor Application due?</strong><br />
	We recommend that you submit your minor application by the end of your junior year. </p>

<p><strong>When is my Minor Completion form due?</strong><br />
	The final deadline for Minor Completion Forms is the end of the third week of classes in your final term. Even if you are taking a class for your minor in your final semester, you should still submit the form by the deadline. Forms turned in after the third week of classes in your final term will be subject to a $50 late fee. If you finish your minor before your final semester, you should turn in your completion form as soon as you finish all six of the approved classes.</p>

<p><strong>How do I get a Minor Advisor</strong><br />
	Minor Advisors are assigned by field; you can look up the current list <a href="/undergraduate/minors/advisors">here</a>. Please note that Minor Advisors can change as often as every semester; thus it is possible that different advisors will sign your proposal and completion forms.</p>

<p><strong>How can I drop a Minor?</strong><br />
	E-mail the <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu?subject=HASS%20Minor%20Drop&amp;body=Full%20Name%3A%20%0AMIT%20ID%3A%20%0AClass%20Year%3A%20%0AMinor%20to%20be%20Dropped%3A%20">SHASS Academic Administrator</a> with your full name, ID, class year and the name of the minor that you would like to drop.</p>

<p><strong>Can I minor and concentrate in the same field? </strong><br />
	Yes. You can build on a <a href="http://mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank">concentration</a> to form a <a href="/undergraduate/minors">minor</a>. Minor requirements are usually more structured than the concentrations, though, so you should consult with the requirements for the concentration and minor you're interested in to be sure that the specific classes you are interested in taking will be acceptable for both the minor and the concentration.</p>

<p><strong>If I do a HASS minor, how many of my classes can count toward both my minor and the HASS Requirement?</strong><br />
	Out of the 6 classes required for a minor, 5 may count toward the HASS Requirement. A course must be <a href="http://student.mit.edu/catalog/symbols.html" target="_blank">designated</a> “HASS,” however, in order to count toward the HASS requirement.</p>

<p><strong>What do I do if I’ve already filled out a Minor Application but I have to take different classes?</strong><br />
	You should have any changes approved by the <a href="/undergraduate/minors/advisors">Minor Advisor</a> before you make them. In order to do this, you should go to your Minor Field Office, pick up the white copy of your application, make the changes on that copy and bring the revised application to the Minor Advisor for approval. If s/he approves, s/he will initial the changes. You should take your revised and approved application back to the field office, make a copy, and bring the copy to the HASS Academic Administrator.</p>

<p><strong>Where can I find my Minor Application so that I can bring it with me to have my completion form signed?</strong><br />
	The white copy of your Minor Application is available in the <a href="/undergraduate/minors/advisors">Field Office</a> for your minor.</p>

<p><strong>If I do a HASS Minor, do I still have to do a HASS Concentration? </strong><br />
	Yes. Every undergraduate student at MIT must file the <a href="http://mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank">HASS Concentration</a> Proposal and Completion forms in order to graduate. You may, however, use the same classes toward your concentration that you use toward your <a href="/undergraduate/minors">minor</a>.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-176" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>The Harvard<strong>/</strong>MIT Cross-Registration Program<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_Harvard_square_harvard_yard.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><br /><br />
	The procedures for MIT undergraduate students cross-registering at Harvard have been revised, as of the Spring 2014 term. Administration of the MIT-Harvard Cross-Registration Program has been moved from the Dean's Office of SHASS, to the MIT Registrar's Office. </p>

<p><strong>To cross-register, visit the </strong><a href="http://web.mit.edu/registrar/reg/xreg/ugradMITtoHarvard.html" target="_blank"><strong>MIT Registrar's Office</strong></a><strong>.</strong><br />
	 </p>

<p> </p>

<p><em><span class="smallerx1">Photocredit: Harvard square, by Chensiyuan</span></em><br /><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Harvard_square_harvard_yard.JPG" target="_blank"><em><span class="smallerx1">Licensed under Creative Commons</span></em></a><em><span class="smallerx1"> </span></em></p>

<p><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-176 -->

            <article id="node-160" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>The HASS Requirement<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_SHASS-globe.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>HASS Requirement</strong> | <strong>Menu</strong></p>

<p><a href="/undergraduate/hass/petition">Credit by Petition or Transfer</a><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>The HASS Education Office is divided between two offices </strong>— the SHASS Academic Administrator and the Office of the HASS Requirement. The two offices handle HASS-related questions and matters according to the following chart: <br />
	  </p>

<table class="linetable"><thead><tr><th scope="col">
				<h3><br /><span class="largerx1">Office of the HASS Requirement  </span>         <br />
					 </h3>
			</th>
			<th scope="col">
				<h3><br /><span class="largerx1">SHASS Academic Administrator</span></h3>
			</th>
		</tr></thead><tbody><tr><td><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq" target="_blank">http://web.mit.edu/hassreq</a></td>
			<td><br /><a href="/undergraduate" target="_blank">http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate</a>   </td>
		</tr><tr><td width="225"><br />
				Patty Fernandes<br /><a href="mailto:hassreq@mit.edu">hassreq@mit.edu</a><br />
				5-133<br />
				x3-2313</td>
			<td width="225"><br />
				Andrea Wirth<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu?subject=Question%20about%20the%20HASS%20requirement">awirth@mit.edu</a><br />
				4-240<br />
				x3-4441<br />
				 </td>
		</tr><tr><td><br />
				Handles questions about:<br />
				 
				<ul><li>The HASS Requirement</li>
					<li>Concentrations</li>
					<li>Petitions for substitutions within the HASS Requirement</li>
					<li>Overlap between the HASS and Communication Requirements</li>
				</ul><p> </p>
			</td>
			<td><br />
				Handles questions about:<br />
				 
				<ul><li>HASS Minors</li>
					<li>Interdisciplinary Majors</li>
					<li>21E/S Majors</li>
					<li>HASS@Cambridge (CME)</li>
					<li>General SHASS information</li>
					<li>Advising for special concentrations<br />
						 </li>
				</ul></td>
		</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>HASS Distribution Component  </strong></p>

<div class="text">
	<p>Beginning with the freshman class of Fall 2010, the Institute has phased in a revised HASS Distribution component of the HASS Requirement. Information on the current requirement is available through the <a href="http://mit.edu/hassreq/" target="_blank">Office of the HASS Requirement</a>. <br /><br />
		Students who entered prior to Fall 2010 must still complete the HASS-D Requirement under which they enrolled. Any students still needing a HASS-D should contact the <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">SHASS Academic Administrator</a> for HASS-D options.</p>

	<p> </p>

	<p><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_sphere.jpg" width="180" />          </p>
</div>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

        <!-- page content -->
        <div id="divcontent" role="main">

          
            <article id="node-171" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Credit by Transfer or Petition<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h3><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_transfer.jpg" width="585" /><br /><br />
	 </h3>

<h3>HASS Credit by Transfer</h3>

<p><br />
	As a general rule, MIT students are expected to take their HASS classes at MIT during the regular semesters, and exceptions to this rule are rare. In the rare cases where outside courses are assessed to be up to MIT HASS standards, credits transferred from other institutions, excluding AP credits, may be applied toward the HASS Requirement if the subject is assessed to be equivalent to an MIT HASS course of at least nine but typically twelve units. </p>

<p>It is important to note that HASS transfer credit is never guaranteed. HASS transfer credit is automatically denied if a student receives a grade below an A or B, if the subject was not taken for a letter grade, if the subject was taken at a non-degree-granting institution, or if the course was taken during high school with other high school students and/or is included in the high school transcript. All other subjects may be assessed by the relevant Transfer Credit Examiner on a case-by-case basis. </p>

<p>For questions about transferring credits, please contact the <a href="/undergraduate/hass/petition/examiners">Transfer Credit Examiner</a> (TCE) in the relevant HASS field. If you are unsure, the SHASS Academic Administrator can help you determine the correct examiner. We suggest that you obtain unofficial written approval from the TCE before starting subjects elsewhere. Please visit the Registrar's Office website for transfer credit <a href="http://web.mit.edu/registrar/reg/transfercredit.html" target="_blank">instructions and guidelines</a>. Use the following links for information about transfer credit in these specific HASS fields:</p>

<p><a href="http://econ-www.mit.edu/under/transfer" target="_blank">Economics</a><br /><a href="http://history.mit.edu/undergraduate/transfer-credit">History</a><br /><a href="http://lit.mit.edu/transfer-credit/" target="_blank">Literature</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/transfer.html" target="_blank">Science, Technology and Society</a></p>

<p><br /><strong>Please note </strong>—<strong> All transfer credit for HASS classes must be submitted through the SHASS Academic Administrator, Andrea Wirth, 4-240. </strong><br /><br />
	Bring your completed, signed, and approved transfer credit form to 4-240. This step must be completed after consulting the appropriate Transfer Credit Examiner, but before turning in any petitions for specific HASS or CI credit.<br />
	 </p>

<h3><br />
	HASS Credit by Petition<br />
	 </h3>

<p>For information about receiving HASS credit by petition, please visit the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/petitions.html" target="_blank">HASS Requirement website</a>.<br /><br />
	(For subjects taken through cross-registration at Harvard or Wellesley College, MIT graduate SHASS subjects, or combining two MIT 6-unit SHASS subjects as described on the HASS Requirement website.</p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-175" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Interdisciplinary Programs<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p> <br />
	 <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_apples.orange.jpg" width="180" />     <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_fruit-slice-ideas.jpg" width="180" />     <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_apple-sliced-rearranged-1.jpg" width="180" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>Providing opportunities for interdisciplinary study is a priority at MIT SHASS.</strong><br /><br />
	MIT's mission of meeting the world's great challenges requires not only superb technical and scientific creativity, but also a deep understanding of the human complexities — cultural, political, and economic — in which the world's challenges are embedded. MIT-SHASS offers undergraduate programs which each embrace several academic disciplines to take a multi-faceted approach to these issues. Typically, these programs are taught collaboratively by faculty from various fields in the School and, in some cases, from other schools within the Institute.<br /><br />
	For full descriptions of the programs, including the program coordinators, click on the names below. The program coordinator or the <a href="/undergraduate/office">SHASS Academic Administrator</a> can provide additional support for each.<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>Interdisciplinary Concentrations</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/african">African and African Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/american">American Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/ancient-medieval">Ancient and Medieval Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/asian">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/latin-american">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/legal">Legal Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/middle-eastern">Middle Eastern Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/conc/russian">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a><br /><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/degree-requirements">Women's and Gender Studies</a></p>

<p><br /><strong>Interdisciplinary Minors</strong></p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/african">African and African Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/ancient">Ancient and Medieval Studies</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/minor/ais.html">Applied International Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/asian">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/latin-american">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/middle-eastern">Middle Eastern Studies</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/minor/pp.html">Public Policy</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/russian">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a><br /><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/degree-requirements">Women's and Gender Studies</a><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Interdisciplinary Degrees</strong></p>

<dl><dt>
		<p><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/">Humanities</a></p>
	</dt>
	<dd>
		<p><strong>Majors</strong></p>
	</dd>
	<dd><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/american">American Studies</a></dd>
	<dd><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/ancient">Ancient and Medieval Studies</a></dd>
	<dd><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/asian">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a></dd>
	<dd><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/latin-american">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a></dd>
	<dd><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/russian">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a></dd>
	<dd><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/degree-requirements">Women’s and Gender Studies</a>
		<p> </p>
	</dd>
	<dd>
		<p><strong>How to prepare an Interdisciplinary Major proposal </strong></p>
	</dd>
	<dd>
		<p style="line-height: 15.455999374389648px;">Students interested in one of the above Interdisciplinary Majors or interested in creating a customized HASS major should fill out the following PDF form and contact the Faculty Coordinator or the HASS Academic Administrator for guidelines and procedures. </p>
	</dd>
	<dd>
		<p style="line-height: 15.455999374389648px;"><a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/FORM%20Interdisciplinary%20Proposal.pdf" target="_blank">Interdisciplinary Major Proposal Form (PDF)</a><br />
			Right-click (control-click on a Mac) the link and choose "Download Linked File As..." to save the document to your computer.</p>
	</dd>
	<dt>
		<p style="line-height: 15.455999374389648px;"><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities-engineering/">Humanities and Engineering</a></p>
	</dt>
	<dt>
		<p style="line-height: 15.455999374389648px;"><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities-science/">Humanites and Science</a></p>
	</dt>
</dl><p>      <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_fruit-sliced-together.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-247" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>African and African Diaspora Studies Concentration</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p class="MsoNormal"><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Hon-Barbara-jordan.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><br /><em>The Honorable Barbara Jordan (1936-1996), photographed during the Watergate hearings in U.S. Senate, 1973. Jordan was a stateswoman, Member of the U.S. Congress from the 18th District of Texas, keynote speaker for the 1976 National Democratic Convention, orator and defender of the U.S. Constitution.</em></p>

<p><em>"There was only one Barbara Jordan," said Eve Clayton, Representative from North Carolina, "and when she spoke—we listened. The world listened.”  </em></p>

<p><a href="http://archive.lib.msu.edu/VVL/dbnumbers/DB3810.mp3" target="_blank"><em>Recording: Barbara Jordan speaking on the extension of the Voting Rights Act</em></a> </p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>The African and African Diaspora Studies Concentration</strong> offers a variety of subjects on the history, culture and structure of societies of African descent throughout the world, with special emphasis on those of the United States and the Caribbean. The purpose of the concentration is to allow students to focus critical and analytic attention on issues of concern to black communities of the Western hemisphere, to allow students to gain a wider appreciation of the dynamic nature of those communities, and to assist students to understand the historical, humanistic, political and social dimensions of ethnicity and race.</p>

<p>Concentration requirements: <strong>Four subjects</strong>, selected in consultation with the Concentration Advisor. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p>The following subjects, offered by the various departments, programs and sections within the School of Humanities and Social Science, constitute the core of the African and African Diaspora Studies concentration:</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HISTORICAL STUDIES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21H.229 The Black Radical Tradition in America, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.319 Race, Crime, and Citizenship in American Law, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.358 Colonialism in South Asia and Africa, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.385J The Ghetto: From Venice to Harlem [11.152], HASS-S</p>

<p>24.912J Black Matters: Introduction to Black Studies [21H.106, 21L.008, 21W.741, WGS.190], HASS-A/HASS-H, CI-H<br /><em>Can count toward Historical Studies or Humanties and the Arts, but not both.</em></p>

<p>STS.048 African Americans in Science, Technology, and Medicine, HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.088 Africa for Engineers, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HUMANITIES AND THE ARTS</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21G.026/21G.326 Global Africa: Creative Cultures, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.346 (Spring 2018 Only) Contemporary Francophone Africa: Francophonie and Beyond, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.007 World Literatures, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.504J Race and Identity in American Literature [WGS.140], HASS-H</p>

<p>21M.030 Introduction to World Music, HASS-A, CI-H</p>

<p>21M.226 Jazz, HASS-A,</p>

<p>21M.293 Music of Africa, HASS-A</p>

<p>21M.460 MIT Senegalese Drum Ensemble (6 units)<br /><em>Must register for two semesters. These two 6-unit classes may be combined by petition to form one 12-unit HASS-Elective.</em></p>

<p>21W.742J Writing About Race [WGS.231], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>24.912J Black Matters: Introduction to Black Studies [21H.106, 21L.008, 21W.741, WGS.190], HASS-A/HASS-H, CI-H<br /><em>Can count toward Historical Studies or Humanties and the Arts, but not both.</em></p>

<p>WGS.142 Narrative and Identity: Writing and Film by Contemporary Women of Color, HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>SOCIAL SCIENCES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>11.164J Human Rights at Home and Abroad [17.391], HASS-S</p>

<p>11.166 Law, Social Movements, and Public Policy: Comparative and International Experience, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.523 Ethnic Conflict in World Politics, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.571 Engineering Democratic Development in Africa, HASS-S</p>

<p>21A.306 Culture, Embodiment, and the Senses, HASS-S</p>

<p>21A.308 Global Mental Health, HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>21A.442J Violence, Human Rights, and Justics [WGS.270], HASS-S</p>

<p>24.908 Creole Languages and Caribbean Identities, HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>WGS.150 Gender, Power, Leadership, and the Workplace, HASS-S</p>

<p>WGS.225J The Science of Race, Sex, and Gender [21A.103, STS.046], HASS-S</p>

<p>WGS.228 Psychology of Sex and Gender, HASS-S</p>

<p> </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Concentration Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:alexandy@mit.edu">Sandy Alexandre</a>, 14N-422, x3-4450 <br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>American Studies Concentration

 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Ellis_Island-Great_Hall.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	                                                                                 <em>Great Hall, Ellis Island, New York</em></p>

<p> </p>

<p>You may be interested in American literature, folklore or popular culture; in black history and culture; in women’s studies; in American history, politics or law; in the history of science and technology; in American art, architecture or music—whatever the special focus of your interests, American Studies may be the right concentration for you. American Studies gives you a chance to study American society and culture through its history, literature, art, politics, science, music, etc. by constructing interdisciplinary programs, made up of subjects drawn from different disciplines, centered on your particular interests. </p>

<p>One aim of American Studies is to help you understand the underlying system of beliefs that informs every aspect of American culture—its myths, institutions, politics and literature, its characteristic dreams and rituals. Another is to understand the uses and limits of different methods and intellectual disciplines as tools for exploring the complexities of a culture. And a third, no less important, is to understand the American present in relation to the American past. To these you will add your own objectives.</p>

<p>You can concentrate in American Studies by taking <strong>four subjects, at least one of which must be in Historical Studies and one in Literature</strong> (variances are possible). Concentrations may be organized around periods, problems, or themes. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p>A concentration in American Studies will well prepare you for further work not only in the various humanistic fields but also in law, urban planning, management, architecture, engineering, medicine, teaching, and any of the media. Consult the American Studies Concentration Advisor with any questions.</p>

<p>Below is a partial listing of American Studies subjects. Other courses may be included in your program at the American Studies advisor’s discretion.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HUMANITIES AND THE ARTS</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21M.215 Music of the Americas, HASS-A</p>

<p>21M.226 Jazz, HASS-A</p>

<p>21M.283 The Musical, HASS-A</p>

<p>21M.284 Film Music, HASS-A</p>

<p>21M.295 American Popular Music, HASS-A</p>

<p>21W.742J Writing about Race [WGS.231], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>24.912J Black Matters: Introduction to Black Studies [21H.106, 21L.008, 21W.741, WGS.190], HASS-A/HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>SOCIAL SCIENCES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>17.20 Introduction to the American Political Process, HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>17.251 Congress and the American Political System I, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.261 Congress and the American Political System II, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.263 Electoral Politics, Public Opinion, and Democracy, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.265 Public Opinion and American Democracy, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.317 U.S. Social Policy, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.40 American Foreign Policy: Past, Present, and Future, HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>17.483 US Military Power, HASS-S</p>

<p>21A.120 American Dream: Exploring Class in the US, HASS-S</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HISTORICAL STUDIES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>11.013J American Urban History I [21H.217], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>11.014J History of the Built Environment in the U.S. [21H.218], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>17.28J The War at Home: American Politics and Society in Wartime [21H.213], HASS-S</p>

<p>21G.043J Introduction to Asian American Studies: Historical and Contemporary Issues [21H.107], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.101 American History to 1865, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.102 American History Since 1865, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.201 The American Revolution, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.211 The United States in the Nuclear Age, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.214 War and American Society, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.220J Metropolis: A Comparative History of New York City [11.150], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.226J Riots, Strikes, and Conspiracies in American History [11.015], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.227 Constitutional Law in US History, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.228 American Classics, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.229 The Black Radical Tradition in America, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.315 American Consumer Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.319 Race, Crime, and Citizenship in American Law, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.320J Gender and the Law in US History [WGS.161], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.321J Downtown [11.026], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.322 Christianity in America, HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.026J History of Manufacturing in America, HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.027J The Civil War and the Emergence of Modern America: 1861-1890 [21H.205], HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>LITERATURE</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21L.006 American Literature, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.011 The Film Experience, HASS-A, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.432 Understanding Television, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.487 Modern Poetry, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.501 The American Novel, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.504J Race and Identity in American Literature [WGS.140], HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.512 American Authors, HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY, AND SOCIETY</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>STS.001 Technology in American History, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>STS.026 History of Manufacturing in America, HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.027J The Civil War and the Emergence of Modern America: 1861-1890 [21H.205], HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.048 African Americans in Science, Technology, and Medicine, HASS-H</p>

<p>STS.049 The Long War Against Cancer, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>STS.050 The History of MIT, HASS-H</p>

<p>WGS.150 Gender, Power, Leadership, and the Workplace, HASS-S</p>

<p>WGS.225J The Science of Race, Sex, and Gender [21A.103, STS.046], HASS-S</p>

<p> </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Concentration Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:capozzol@mit.edu">Christopher Capozzola</a>, E51-284, x2-4960<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-245" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Ancient and Medieval Studies Concentration</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Mattei_Athena_Louvre.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em;" width="585" /><br />
	 </p>

<p><em>"Mattei Athena,” located in the Louvre Museum; Roman copy of the Greek goddess of wisdom, from 1st century BC/AD, after a 4th century BC Greek original, attributed to Cephisodotos or Euphranor. Photograph by Jastrow (2006); public domain via </em><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena#mediaviewer/File:Mattei_Athena_Louvre_Ma530_n2.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Wikimedia Commons</em></a><em>.</em><br /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p>Through a wide variety of subjects drawn from a number of disciplines, this program provides a curricular framework for exploring topics in ancient and medieval studies which range from the history of ideas and institutions to that of material artifacts, literature and certain of the original languages. The chronological span of the program includes some 6,500 years between 5000 B.C. and 1500 A.D.</p>

<p>The goal of this program is to develop knowledge and understanding of the more distant past both for itself, in its uniqueness, and as an object of specifically modern questions and methods of inquiry. We are interested in the structure of institutions and social systems, and in relationships between the social order and learned traditions, values, ideologies and ideas. Ancient and medieval studies derive a special claim to our interest from the fact that the record is so full and multiform and that much of it is of exceptionally high quality at once in substance and form.</p>

<p>The concentration requirements consist of <strong>four subjects</strong>, at least one of which is to be taken in the medieval period by students whose focus is to be the Ancient World, or one in the ancient period by those whose focus is the Middle Ages. Subjects listed below as ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL may count for either. At least two of the subjects taken towards the concentration must be taken at MIT. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p>Concentrators may count up to two subjects in Greek or Latin or a medieval vernacular (taken at MIT or other institutions) towards the concentration. Students interested in the program should contact the Concentration Advisor.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>ANCIENT AND MEDIEVAL</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>4.605 A Global History of Architecture, HASS-A</p>

<p>21H.007J Empire: Introduction to Ancient and Medieval Studies [21L.014], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.333 Early Christianity, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.001 Foundations of Western Literature: Homer to Dante, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.021 Comedy, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.455 Ancient Authors, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.607 Greek I [6-unit course] **</p>

<p>21L.608 Greek II [6-unit course] **</p>

<p>21L.611 Latin I [6-unit course] **</p>

<p>21L.612 Latin II [6-unit course] **</p>

<p>CC.117J Humane Warfare: Ancient and Medieval Perspectives on Ethics in War [17.05], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>ANCIENT</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>3.981 Communities of the Living and the Dead: the Archaeology of Ancient Egypt, HASS-S</p>

<p>3.982 The Ancient Andean World, HASS-S</p>

<p>3.983 Ancient Mesoamerican Civilization, HASS-S</p>

<p>3.986 The Human Past: Introduction to Archaeology, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>3.987 Human Evolution: Data from Palaeontology, Archaeology, and Materials Science, HASS-S</p>

<p>3.993 Archaeology of the Middle East, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.130 The Ancient World: Greece, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.132 The Ancient World: Rome, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.230 Barbarians, Saints, and Emperors, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.237 The City of Athens in the Age of Pericles, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.239 The City of Rome in the Age of the Caesars, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.331 Julius Caesar and the Fall of the Roman Republic, HASS-H</p>

<p style="line-height: 15.455999374389648px;">21H.336 The Making of a Roman Emperor, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.458 The Bible, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.613 Latin Readings [6-unit course] **</p>

<p>21L.614 Advanced Latin Readings [6-unit course] **</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>MEDIEVAL</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>4.614 Building Islam, HASS-A</p>

<p>4.635 Early Modern Architecture and Art, HASS-A</p>

<p>21H.133 The Medieval World: CE 200-1500, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.134J Medieval Economic History in Comparative Perspective [14.70J], HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.160 Islam, the Middle East, and the West, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.238 The Vikings, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.240 The World of Charlemagne, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.383 Technology and the Global Economy, 1000-2000, HASS-S</p>

<p>21L.460 Arthurian Literature, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.601J Old English and Beowulf [24.916J], HASS-H</p>

<p>21M.220 Medieval and Renaissance Music, HASS-A</p>

<p>CC.116 How to Rule the World: The Promises and Pitfalls of Politics, War, and Empire, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p>** These two 6-unit classes may be combined by petition to form one 12-unit HASS-Elective</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from one of the Concentration Advisors:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:amccants@mit.edu">Anne McCants</a>, E51-263, x8-6669<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:awbahr@mit.edu">Arthur Bahr</a>, 14N-424, x3-3616<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>

<p>Please also check the <a href="http://ams.mit.edu">ams.mit.edu</a> website for the latest news.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-248" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies Concentration</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_detail_nine-dragons-scroll.jpg" width="585" /><br /><br /><em><span class="smallerx1">Detail, from the "Nine Dragons" handscroll, <span>painted by Chen Rong, during the Song Dynasty. Scroll located in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston. </span><span>In this detail, the dragon (an auspicious symbol of strength and good luck in Chinese iconography) has grasped the pearl of wisdom. (</span></span></em><em><span class="smallerx1"><span>Public domain <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Rong_(painter)#mediaviewer/File:Chen_Rong_-_Nine_Dragons.jpg" target="_blank">image</a> via Wikimedia Commons.)</span></span></em><br /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>The Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies concentration</strong> is designed for students interested in the languages, history, politics, and cultures of Asia and the Asian diasporas. The geographical region of Asia includes countries such as Bangladesh, China, India, Japan, Korea, Mongolia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. In consultation with the concentration advisor, students may focus their coursework on a sub-region of Asia or the Asian diasporas, or design their program to offer a comparative study across different regions and/or cultural groups.</p>

<p>Concentration requirements: <strong>Four</strong> subjects from the list below with no more than three subjects from a single area. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>LANGUAGE</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>Students may take up to three introductory, intermediate, or advanced subjects in an Asian language. Chinese, Japanese, and Korean are taught at MIT. Other languages may be taken at Harvard, Wellesley, or during the summer with permission from the relevant Transfer Credit Examiner.</p>

<p>21G.101 Chinese I (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.102 Chinese II (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.103 Chinese III (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.104 Chinese IV (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.105 Chinese V (Regular): Discovering Chinese Cultures and Societies, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.106 Chinese VI (Regular): Discovering Chinese Cultures and Societies, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.107 Chinese I (Streamlined), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.108 Chinese II (Streamlined), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.109 Chinese III (Streamlined), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.110 Chinese IV (Streamlined), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.113 Chinese V (Streamlined), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.120 Business Chinese, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.501 Japanese I, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.502 Japanese II, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.503 Japanese III, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.504 Japanese IV, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.505 Japanese V, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.506 Japanese VI, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.901 Korean I, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.902 Korean II, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.903 Korean III, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.904 Korean IV, HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HISTORICAL STUDIES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21G.043J Introduction to Asian American Studies: Historical and Contemporary Issues [21H.107], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.045 Global Chinese Food, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.075J The Global Chinese: Chinese Migration, 1567-Present [21H.253], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.151 Traditional China: Earliest Times to 1644, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.152 Modern China: 1644 to the Present, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.154 Inventing the Samurai, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.155 Modern Japan: 1600 to Present, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.157 The Making of Modern South Asia, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.350 Business in China Since 1800, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.351J Shanghai and China’s Modernization [11.153], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.354 World War II in Asia, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.357 South Asian Migrations, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.358 Colonialism in South Asia and Africa, HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HUMANITIES AND THE ARTS</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21G.036J Advertising and Media: Comparative Perspectives [CMS.356], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.038 China in the News: The Untold Stories, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.039J Gender and Japanese Popular Culture [21A.143, WGS154], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.040 A Passage to India: Introduction to Modern Indian Culture and Society, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.044J Classics of Chinese Literature in Translation [WGS.235], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.046 Modern Chinese Fiction and Cinema, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21G.063 Anime: Transnational Media and Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.064 Introduction to Japanese Culture, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21G.065J Japanese Literature and Cinema [21A.142], HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21G.067 Digital Media in Japan and Korea, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.094 Cinema in Japan and Korea, HASS-A</p>

<p>21W.788J South Asian America: Transnational Media, Culture, and History [CMS.334], HASS-H</p>

<p>WGS.226J Science, Gender and Social Inequality in the Developing World [STS.023], HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>SOCIAL SCIENCES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>17.407 Chinese Foreign Policy, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.433 International Relations of East Asia, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.486 Japan and East Asian Security (G)</p>

<p>17.53 The Rise of Asia, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.537 Politics and Policy in Contemporary Japan, HASS-S</p>

<p>21A.140J Cultures of East Asia [21G.047], HASS-S</p>

<p>21A.141J Images of Asian Women: Dragon Ladies and Lotus Blossoms [21G.048, WGS.274], HASS-S</p>

<p> </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p>(G) Graduate subjects which are open to qualified undergraduates, with permission of the instructor</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Concentration Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:nagahara@mit.edu">Hiromu Nagahara</a>, E51-255G, x4-4977<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->
