            <article id="node-251" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Latin American and Latino/a Studies Concentration</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Bonampak_painting.jpg" style="width: 585px; height: 260px;" /><br /><br /><em>Fresco of musicians; Bonampak, Chiapas; Photo ©2004 Jacob Rus, licensed under </em><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg#mediaviewer/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Creative Commons</em></a><em> </em></p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>The Latin American and Latino/a Studies concentration</strong> is designed for students interested in the language, history, politics and culture of Latin America and of Hispanics living in the U.S.</p>

<p>Concentration Requirements: <strong>Four subjects</strong> from the list below, including no more than two from a single discipline and no more than one focused on the Iberian Peninsula. (Please note that a student may choose not to take a subject focused on the Iberian Peninsula.) Also note that a minimum of three of the four subjects must be MIT subjects. Subjects are also available from Harvard University and Wellesley College through cross-registration. Students must receive permission from the concentration advisor before registering for a class at another institution.</p>

<p>A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>ANTHROPOLOGY / POLITICS / ARCHAEOLOGY AND MATERIAL SCIENCE / HISTORY</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>3.982 The Ancient Andean World, HASS-S</p>

<p>3.983 Ancient Mesoamerican Civilization, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.55J Introduction to Latin American Studies [21A.130, 21G.084, 21H.170], HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>17.56 The Politics of Crime and Policing, HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p>21A.506 The Anthropology of Politics, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.171 Latin America: Revolution, Dictatorship, and Democracy, 1850 to Present, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.172J Latin America Through Film [21G.078], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.273 From Coca to Cocaine: Drug Economies in Latin America, HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>LANGUAGE / LITERATURE / ARTS</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>21G.070 Latin America and the Global Sixties: Counterculture and Revolution, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21G.072 The New Latin American Novel, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21G.074 Topics in Portuguese Popular Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.700 Intensive Spansih for Advanced Beginner Students, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.701 Spanish I, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.702 Spanish II, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.703 Spanish III, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.704 Spanish IV, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.710 Advanced Communication in Spanish: Topics in Language and Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.711 Advanced Spanish Conversation and Composition: Perspectives on Technology and Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.712 Spanish Conversation and Composition, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.713 Spanish through Film: Mexico, Chile, Argentina, and Spain, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.714 Spanish for Heritage Learners, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.715 Topics in Medicine and Public Health in the Hispanic World, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.731J Creation of a Continent: Representations of Hispanic America, 1492-1898, in Literature and Film [21H.274], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.732 The Making of the Latin American City: Culture, Gender, and Citizenship, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.735 Advanced Topics in Hispanic Literature and Film, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.736 The Short Story in Spain and Hispanic America, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.782 Spanish II (Study Abroad), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.801 Portuguese I, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.802 Portuguese II, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.803 Portuguese III, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.804 Portuguese IV, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.820 Topics in Modern Portuguese Literature and Culture, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.821 The Beat of Brazil: Portuguese Language and Brazilian Society Through its Music, HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.880 Accelerated Introductory Portuguese for Spanish Speakers, HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.019 Introduction to European and Latin American Fiction, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21L.636J Introduction to Contemporary Hispanic Literature and Film [21G.716], HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.613J Introduction to Hispanic Culture [21G.717], HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.638J Literature and Social Conflict: Perspectives on the Hispanic World [21G.738], HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.639J Globalization and its Discontents: Spanish-speaking Nations [21G.739], HASS-H</p>

<p>21L.640J The New Spain: 1977 – Present [21G.740], HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information may be obtained from the Concentration Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:brs@mit.edu">Ben Schneider</a>, E53-423, x3-7207<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>

            <article id="node-1884" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Legal Studies Concentration<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585-supreme-court.jpg" style="width: 585px; height: 293px;" /><br /><em>Supreme Court of the United States, Washington D.C.</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>The Legal Studies Concentration</strong> introduces students to the academic field of legal studies. Scholars in legal studies draw on disciplines across the humanities and social sciences. The concentration likewise expects students to sample the breadth of legal studies as an interdisciplinary field by exploring the law from multiple perspectives.<br /><br />
	Students will study legal texts and practices, the role of law in processes of social change, and the relationship of law to other forms of intellectual inquiry. Concentrators will develop analytical skills commonly associated with legal reasoning, gain an understanding of the practice of law in the United States and other nations, and explore law’s relationship to social structures such as politics, economics, and identity.<br /><br />
	Concentration requirements: <strong>four subjects</strong>, selected in consultation with the Concentration Advisor, with at least two from the “Law and Social Science” subfield. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. Additional subjects cannot count as HASS Distribution subjects in your degree audit.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>Theory and Philosophy of Law<br />
	 </h3>

<p><br />
	17.01/24.04J  Justice (H)</p>

<p>17.021/24.235J  Philosophy of Law (H)</p>

<p>17.035/21H.181J  Libertarianism in History (H)</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>Law and Social Science</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>11.166  Law, Social Movements, and Public Policy: Comparative and International Experiences (S) </p>

<p>17.245  Constitutional Law: Structure of Power and Individual Rights (S)</p>

<p>17.251  Congress and the American Political System I (S)</p>

<p>17.261  Congress and the American Political System II (S)</p>

<p>21H.227  Constitutional Law in U.S. History (S)</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>Law and Policy<br />
	 </h3>

<p><br />
	1.801/11.021/17.393/IDS.060J  Environmental Law, Policy and Economics: Pollution Prevention and Control (S)</p>

<p>21A.442/WGS.270J  Violence, Human Rights, and Justice (S)</p>

<p>21H.319  Race, Crime, and Citizenship in American Law (S)</p>

<p>21H.320/WGS.161J  Gender and the Law in U.S. History (H)</p>

<p>STS.085/6.805J  Foundations of Information Policy (S)</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Students may count subjects taken at Wellesley and Harvard with permission of the Concentration Advisor. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses) may also be counted at the discretion of the Concentration Advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Concentration Advisor, <a href="mailto:capozzola@mit.edu">Christopher Capozzola</a>, E51-284, x2-4960, or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@Mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x-3-4965,<br />
	or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_scales_justice.jpg" style="width: 180px; height: 180px;" /></p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-252" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Middle Eastern Studies Concentration<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><em><img alt="" height="225" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_ceilings-mosque.jpg" style="border: 0px;" width="585" /> </em><br /><em>                                                                                       Blue Mosque, Sultanahmet</em><br /><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>The Middle Eastern Studies concentration</strong> is designed for students interested principally in the art and architecture, culture, economics, history, and politics of the Arab world, Iran, Israel, and Turkey.</p>

<p>Concentration requirements: <strong>Four subjects</strong> from the list below with no more than two subjects from a single area. A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>HUMANITIES AND THE ARTS</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>4.610 Civic Islamic Architecture, HASS-A</p>

<p>4.614 Building Islam, HASS-A</p>

<p>4.617 Topics in Islamic Urbanism (G)</p>

<p>4.619 Historiography of Islamic Architecture (G)</p>

<p>4.621 Orientalism and Representation (G)</p>

<p>4.622 Islamic Gardens and Geographies</p>

<p>WGS.220J Women and Gender in the Middle East and North Africa [21H.263], HASS-H</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>SOCIAL SCIENCES AND HISTORICAL STUDIES</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>3.993 Archaeology of the Middle East, HASS-S</p>

<p>17.565/17.567 Israel: History, Politics, Culture, and Identity, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.160 Islam, the Middle East, and the West, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.161 The Middle East in the Twentieth Century, HASS-H, CI-H</p>

<p>21H.260 Cities in the Middle East: History, Politics, and Society, HASS-S</p>

<p>21H.262 Palestine and the Arab-Israeli Conflict, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.365 Minorities and Majorities in the Middle East, HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.381J Women and War [WGS.222J], HASS-S</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>LANGUAGE</h3>

<p> </p>

<p>With the permission of the Concentration Advisor, students may take one or two introductory, intermediate, or advanced subjects in one of the following languages offered by Harvard University or Wellesley College: Arabic, Hebrew, Persian, Turkish. The advisor may also approve other Middle Eastern languages, such as Armenian, Greek, or Kurdish.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the concentration advisor.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p>(G) Graduate subjects which are open to qualified undergraduates, with the permission of the instructor</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Concentration Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:khoury@mit.edu">Philip S. Khoury</a>, 10-280, x3-0887<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-252 -->

            <article id="node-254" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Russian and Eurasian Studies Concentration</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_St-Basils-Cathedral.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><em>Detail, St. Basil's Cathedral, a former church, built between 1555-61; now a museum in Red Square, in the heart of Moscow, Russia</em></p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p><strong>The Russian and Eurasian Studies Regional Studies Concentration</strong> is intended for students seeking an interdisciplinary program of study centered on Russia and Eurasia. The program is regional in spirit, meaning that students can take courses in a wide range of countries of East/Central Europe, the Slavic states, and Central Asia.</p>

<p>A HASS Concentration may include only one subject that also counts toward the HASS Distribution Requirement. You may include more than one only if the additional subject will NOT count as a HASS Distribution subject in your degree audit.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>Concentration Requirements</h3>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Four subjects</strong>, chosen from the following MIT subjects:</p>

<p>17.569 Russia’s Foreign Policy: Toward the Post-Soviet States and Beyond, HASS-S</p>

<p>21G.077J/21G.618 Introduction to the Classics of Russian Literature [21L.490], HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.611 Russian I (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.612 Russian II (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.613 Russian III (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21G.614 Russian IV (Regular), HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.244J Imperial and Revolutionary Russia: Culture and Politics, 1700-1917 [21G.085], HASS-H</p>

<p>21H.245J Soviet and Post-Soviet Politics and Society, 1917-Present [17.57, 21G.086], HASS-S, CI-H</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Students may also cross-register for classes at Harvard or Wellesley in languages of Eastern Europe and/or Russian, as well as courses in history, literature, government and other subjects.</p>

<p>[ ] Jointly listed subjects</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional Information can be obtained from one of the Concentration Advisors:<br /><a href="mailto:khotimsk@mit.edu">Maria Khotimsky</a> 16-661, x5-5385<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:elizwood@mit.edu">Elizabeth Wood</a>, E51-282, x3-3255<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office,</a> E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

            <article id="node-966" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Major in American Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Ellis_Island-Great_Hall.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	                                                                                                    <br /><em>                                                                                                 Great Hall, Ellis Island, New York</em></p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p>You may be interested in American literature, folklore or popular culture; in black history and culture; in women’s studies; in American history, politics or law; in the history of science and technology; in American art, architecture or music—whatever the special focus of your interests, American Studies may be the right major for you. American Studies gives you a chance to study American society and culture through its history, literature, art, politics, science, music, etc. by constructing interdisciplinary programs, made up of subjects drawn from different disciplines, centered on your particular interests.</p>

<p>One aim of American Studies is to help you understand the underlying system of beliefs that informs every aspect of American culture—its myths, institutions, politics and literature, its characteristic dreams and rituals. Another is to understand the uses and limits of different methods and intellectual disciplines as tools for exploring the complexities of a culture. And a third, no less important, is to understand the American present in relation to the American past. To these you will add your own objectives.</p>

<p><strong>The Major in American Studies</strong> consists of a minimum of nine subjects (108 units) beyond the pre-thesis and thesis. Remaining subjects selected from at least two of the three disciplinary areas.</p>

<p>Area I: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area II: Social Sciences; Science, Technology, and Society</p>

<p>Area III: Historical Studies</p>

<p>Up to six subjects (72 units) may be used for both the major and the GIRs, but the units from those subjects may not count toward the 180 units required beyond the GIRs. No more than one HASS Distribution class may be counted towards the major and towards the HASS Distribution Component of the GIRs. Of the subjects required for the major, at least eight must count only toward this major (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p>A major in American Studies will well prepare you for further work not only in the various humanistic fields but also in law, urban planning, management, architecture, engineering, medicine, teaching, and any of the media. Consult the American Studies Major Advisor with any questions.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/#americanstudiestext">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects and the current <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-course-21/">degree chart</a>.</strong></p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the major advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Major Advisor<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:capozzol@mit.edu">Christopher Capozzola</a>, E51-284, x2-4960<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>

<p><br />
	 </p>

<p><img alt="" height="360" src="/files/shass/cimg/news/2012/585_rosa_parks_bus.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><br /><em><span class="smallerx1">On December 1, 1955, Rosa Parks boarded a Montgomery, Alabama city bus on her way home from work. When she was told to take a seat in the back of the bus, then the custom for African-Americans, Miss Parks quietly refused. News of this incident spread quickly and led to a city-wide bus boycott led by a young Martin Luther King, Jr. </span></em><em><span class="smallerx1">This is a photograph of the bus, now restored, that Miss Parks was riding the day her </span></em><em><span class="smallerx1">courageous action helped spark the modern American civil rights movement.  <br />
	                                                                      — from the National Trust for Historic Preservation </span></em><br /><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-967" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Major in Ancient and Medieval Studies</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Mattei_Athena_Louvre.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em; border: 0px;" width="585" /></p>

<p style="line-height: 15px; margin-bottom: 10px;"><em>"Mattei Athena,” located in the Louvre Museum; Roman copy of the Greek goddess of wisdom, from 1st century BC/AD, after a 4th century BC Greek original, attributed to Cephisodotos or Euphranor. Photograph by Jastrow (2006); public domain via </em><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena#mediaviewer/File:Mattei_Athena_Louvre_Ma530_n2.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Wikimedia Commons</em></a><em>.</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr style="width: 590px; margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px;" /><p style="line-height: 15px; margin-bottom: 10px;"> </p>

<p>Through a wide variety of subjects drawn from a number of disciplines, this program provides a curricular framework for exploring topics in ancient and medieval studies which range from the history of ideas and institutions to that of material artifacts, literature and certain of the original languages. The chronological span of the program includes some 6,500 years between 5000 B.C. and 1500 A.D.</p>

<p>The goal of this program is to develop knowledge and understanding of the more distant past both for itself, in its uniqueness, and as an object of specifically modern questions and methods of inquiry. We are interested in the structure of institutions and social systems, and in relationships between the social order and learned traditions, values, ideologies and ideas. Ancient and medieval studies derive a special claim to our interest from the fact that the record is so full and multiform and that much of it is of exceptionally high quality at once in substance and form.</p>

<p><strong>The Major in Ancient and Medieval Studies</strong> is designed for students who are seeking a fuller understanding of the forces which shaped the ancient and medieval world. The geographical and chronological scope of the program is broadly conceived and is intended to be comparative. Subjects range in content from Classical Greece and Rome, and the ancient societies of Asia and South America, to medieval Europe and Japan. Students will be required to demonstrate intermediate level language proficiency in either Greek, Latin or a medieval vernacular, but they need not concentrate their other subjects on the area associated with that language. Students are also expected to have some distribution across the ancient and medieval time periods. We expect that students will consult closely with the Major Advisor in order to devise a coherent program of study.</p>

<p>As noted in the <strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-course-21/" target="_blank">degree chart</a></strong>, the program includes a minimum of nine subjects (108 units) beyond the pre-thesis tutorial (21.THT) and thesis (21.THU).  The nine subjects must include one language subject in Area I (or equivalent proficiency); the eight remaining subjects must be selected from at least two of the three other disciplinary areas (Areas II-IV), with at least one subject in both Ancient and Medieval periods. To satisfy the communication-intensive (CI-M) component of the program, students may select two subjects from among 3.990 Seminar in Archaeological Method and Theory, 21H.331 Julius Caesar and the Fall of the Roman Republic, 21H.240 The World of Charlemagne, 21H.390 Seminar in Historical Methods, or any Literature seminar (21L.700-21L.715) with an ancient or medieval focus.</p>

<p>Area I: Languages</p>

<p>Area II: Arts and Architecture</p>

<p>Area III: Literary Studies</p>

<p>Area IV: Material and Historical Studies</p>

<p>Up to six subjects (72 units) may be used for both the major and the GIRs, but the units from those subjects may not count toward the 180 units required beyond the GIRs. No more than one HASS Distribution class may be counted towards the major and towards the HASS Distribution Component of the GIRs. Of the subjects required for the major, at least eight must count only toward this major (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/#ancientmedievalstudiestext" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the major advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Major Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:amccants@mit.edu">Anne McCants</a>, E51-263, x8-6669,<br />
	from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965,<br />
	or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-968" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Major in Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_detail_nine-dragons-scroll.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em; border: 0px;" width="585" /><br /><br /><em><span class="smallerx1" style="font-size: 10px; line-height: 13px;">Detail, from the "Nine Dragons" handscroll, painted by Chen Rong, during the Song Dynasty. Scroll located in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston. In this detail, the dragon (an auspicious symbol of strength and good luck in Chinese iconography) has grasped the pearl of wisdom. (</span></em><em><span class="smallerx1" style="font-size: 10px; line-height: 13px;">Public domain <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Rong_(painter)#mediaviewer/File:Chen_Rong_-_Nine_Dragons.jpg" target="_blank">image</a> via Wikimedia Commons.)</span></em></p>

<hr style="width: 590px; margin-top: 12px; margin-bottom: 12px;" /><p> </p>

<p><strong>The Major in Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies </strong>is designed for students interested in serious intensive research on the languages, history, politics, and cultures of Asia and/or the Asian diasporas. The geographic region of Asia includes countries such as Bangladesh, China, India, Japan, Korea, Mongolia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. In consultation with the major advisor, students may focus their coursework on a sub-region of Asia, on one of the Asian diasporas, or design their program to offer a comparative study across different regions and/or cultural groups. The goal of the Major program is to provide balanced coverage of language, humanistic and social science offerings on the region and to expose students to some comparative perspectives within the region. The MIT Departments of Global Studies and Languages, History, and Political Science offer a substantial number of subjects related to Asia and the Asian diasporas. All Interdisciplinary Major students must write a senior thesis on a topic of their choice to be determined in consultation with an MIT faculty member whose specialty falls within Asian studies. The thesis research may include knowledge of an Asian language.</p>

<p>The Major in Asian &amp; Asian Diaspora Studies consists of a minimum of nine subjects (108 units) beyond the pre-thesis and thesis, including two language subjects in Area I (or equivalent proficiency), and seven other subjects selected from at least two of the three disciplinary areas (Areas II-IV).</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>Up to six subjects (72 units) may be used for both the major and the GIRs, but the units from those subjects may not count toward the 180 units required beyond the GIRs. No more than one HASS Distribution class may be counted towards the major and towards the HASS Distribution Component of the GIRs. Of the subjects required for the major, at least eight must count only toward this major (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p>The language requirement can be satisfied by taking two intermediate (Levels III and IV) subjects in an Asian language. Students with proficiency at this level in the spoken and written language can either take two more advanced language subjects (highly recommended), or two more courses from Areas II, III and IV. Chinese and Japanese are taught at MIT. Other languages may be taken at Harvard, Wellesley, or during the summer with permission from the relevant Transfer Credit Examiner.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/#asianasiandiasporastudiestext" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects and the current <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-course-21/" target="_blank">degree chart</a>.</strong></p>

<h3> </h3>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the major advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Major Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:nagahara@mit.edu">Hiromu Nagahara</a>, E51-255G, x4-4977<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Adminstrator, <br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4443</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Major in Latin American and Latino/a Studies</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Bonampak_painting.jpg" width="585" /><br /><br /><em>Fresco of musicians; Bonampak, Chiapas; Photo ©2004 Jacob Rus, licensed under </em><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg#mediaviewer/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Creative Commons</em></a><em>  </em></p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p><strong>The Major in Latin American and Latino/a Studies</strong> is designed for students interested in the language, history, politics, and culture of Latin America and of Hispanics living in the U.S. Students are encouraged to develop a program that is both international and comparative in perspective and that takes into account the heterogeneous cultural experiences of people living in the vast territory loosely termed Latin America, as well as of those people living in the United States who identify themselves as Latino/a.</p>

<p>The Major in Latin American &amp; Latino/a Studies consists of a minimum of eight subjects (96 units) beyond the introductory course, 17.55J, “Introduction to Latin American Studies,” pre-thesis, and thesis. Remaining subjects include two language subjects in Area I (or equivalent proficiency), and six subjects selected from at least two of the three disciplinary areas (Areas II-IV).</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>Up to six subjects (72 units) may be used for both the major and the GIRs, but the units from those subjects may not count toward the 180 units required beyond the GIRs. No more than one HASS Distribution class may be counted towards the major and towards the HASS Distribution Component of the GIRs. Of the subjects required for the major, at least eight must count only toward this major (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p>Subjects in Latin American and Latino/a Studies are also available from Harvard University and Wellesley College through cross-registration.  Students must receive permission from the major advisor prior to registering for a subject at another institution.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/#latinamericanlatinostudiestext" target="_blank">Click here </a>for the latest listing of eligible subjects and the current <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-course-21/" target="_blank">degree chart</a>.</strong></p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the major advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information may be obtained from the Major Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:brs@mit.edu">Ben Schneider</a>, E53-423, x3-7207<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator, <br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-1707" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Major in Russian and Eurasian Studies</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_St-Basils-Cathedral.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"><span class="smallerx2"><em>Detail, St. Basil's Cathedral, a former church, built between 1555-61; now a museum in Red Square, in the heart of Moscow, Russia</em></span></p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>The Major Program in Russian and Eurasian Studies </strong>is intended for students seeking an interdisciplinary program of study centered on Russia and Eurasia. The program is regional in spirit, meaning that students can take courses in a wide range of countries of East/Central Europe, the Slavic states, and Central Asia.</p>

<p>The Major Program in Russian Studies consists of a minimum of nine subjects (108 units) beyond the pre-thesis and thesis. The nine subjects must include two language subjects in Area I (or equivalent proficiency); the seven remaining subjects must be selected from at least two of the three other disciplinary areas (Areas II-IV). At least six subjects must be MIT subjects or subjects taken at Harvard University or Wellesley College under cross-registration. Students must receive permission from the major advisor prior to registering for a subject at another institution. The major covers four areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/#newitemtext" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects and the current <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-course-21/" target="_blank">degree chart.</a></strong></p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the major advisor.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional Information can be obtained from the Major Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:elizwood@mit.edu">Elizabeth Wood</a>, E51-282, x3-3255<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-232" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor in African and African Diaspora Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Hon-Barbara-jordan.jpg" width="585" /><br /><br /><em>The Honorable Barbara Jordan (1936-1996), photographed during the Watergate hearings in U.S. Senate, 1973. Jordan was a stateswoman, member of the U.S. Congress from the 18th District of Texas, keynote speaker for the 1976 National Democratic Convention, orator, and defender of the U.S. Constitution. "There was only one Barbara Jordan," said Eve Clayton, Representative from North Carolina, "and when she spoke — we listened. The world listened.”  </em><em><a href="http://archive.lib.msu.edu/VVL/dbnumbers/DB3810.mp3" target="_blank"><strong>Recording</strong>: Barbara Jordan speaking on the extension of the Voting Rights Act</a></em></p>

<p> 
	</p><hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>The Minor Program in African and African Diaspora Studies</strong> is designed for students interested in the cultures and experiences of the peoples of African descent on the continent, or elsewhere. The goal of the minor program is to emphasize the importance of Africa and people of African descent in world cultural, economic, and social developments, and to provide a balance between language, humanistic, historical, and contemporary study. The minor includes study of economic and political systems as they reflect the African continent and areas of the African diaspora, and the histories, languages, and literatures of Africans and peoples of African descent elsewhere.<br /><br />
	All of Africa falls within the geographical scope of the minor. A student may concentrate on a particular region or on any of the broad groupings of African cultures, such as Arabic-speaking, Anglophone, Francophone, or Lusophone Africa. Equally, a student choosing to focus on the African Diaspora may concentrate on any group of African-descended populations in the Americas. Students focusing on either principal area (Africa or the African Diaspora) must also take at least one subject which deals with the other area or with interactions between them.<br /><br />
	The Minor Program in African and African Diaspora Studies consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects) arranged in four areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Language<br />
	Area II: Humanities and the Arts<br />
	Area III: Social Sciences<br />
	Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the eight-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement. Of the six subjects required for the minor, at least four must count only toward that minor (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/minor-african-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<h3> </h3>

<h4>Courses offered elsewhere:</h4>

<p>A substantial number of courses dealing with Africa and the African Diaspora are available to our students at Wellesley College, offered through their program in Africana Studies and other departments, and Harvard’s Department of African and African American Studies. Students may take relevant courses at these institutions provided they receive permission in advance from the HASS African and African Diaspora Studies Minor Advisor.</p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Additional information can be obtained from the Minor Advisor:</strong><br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:alexandy@mit.edu">Sandy Alexandre</a>, 14N-422, x3-4450<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth,</a> 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor Program in Ancient and Medieval Studies</h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Mattei_Athena_Louvre.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em; border: 0px;" width="585" /></p>

<p style="line-height: 15px; margin-bottom: 10px;"><em>"Mattei Athena,” located in the Louvre Museum; Roman copy of the Greek goddess of wisdom, from 1st century BC/AD, after a 4th century BC Greek original, attributed to Cephisodotos or Euphranor. Photograph by Jastrow (2006); public domain via </em><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Athena#mediaviewer/File:Mattei_Athena_Louvre_Ma530_n2.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Wikimedia Commons</em></a><em>.</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p>Through a wide variety of subjects drawn from a number of disciplines, this program provides a curricular framework for exploring topics in ancient and medieval studies which range from the history of ideas and institutions to that of material artifacts, literature and certain of the original languages. The chronological span of the program includes some 6,500 years between 5000 B.C. and 1500 A.D.</p>

<p>The goal of this program is to develop knowledge and understanding of the more distant past both for itself, in its uniqueness, and as an object of specifically modern questions and methods of inquiry. We are interested in the structure of institutions and social systems, and in relationships between the social order and learned traditions, values, ideologies and ideas. Ancient and medieval studies derive a special claim to our interest from the fact that the record is so full and multiform and that much of it is of exceptionally high quality at once in substance and form.</p>

<p><strong>The Minor Program in Ancient and Medieval Studies</strong> is designed for students who, in addition to the focus of their major program of study, are seeking a fuller understanding of the forces which shaped the ancient and medieval world. The geographical and chronological scope of the Minor program is broadly conceived and is intended to be comparative. Subjects range in content from Classical Greece and Rome, and the ancient societies of Asia and South America, to medieval Europe and Japan. Students will be required to demonstrate intermediate level language proficiency in either Greek, Latin or a medieval vernacular, but they need not concentrate their other subjects on the area associated with that language. Students are also expected to have some distribution across the ancient and medieval time periods. We expect that students will consult closely with the Minor Advisor in order to devise a coherent program of study.</p>

<p>The Minor program in Ancient and Medieval Studies consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be taken at MIT) arranged in four primary areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Languages</p>

<p>Area II: Arts and Architecture</p>

<p>Area III: Literary Studies</p>

<p>Area IV: Material and Historical Studies</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the eight-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement. Of the six subjects required for the minor, at least four must count only toward that minor (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/ancient-medieval-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from one of the Minor Advisors:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:amccants@mit.edu">Anne McCants</a>, E51-263, x8-6669 <br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:awbahr@mit.edu">Arthur Bahr</a>, 14N-424, x3-3616<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator, <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-237" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor in Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_detail_nine-dragons-scroll.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em; border: 0px;" width="585" /><br /><br /><em>Detail, from the "Nine Dragons" handscroll, painted by Chen Rong, during the Song Dynasty. Scroll located in the Museum of Fine Arts Boston. In this detail, the dragon — an auspicious symbol of strength and good luck in Chinese iconography — has grasped the pearl of wisdom. (</em><em>Public domain <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chen_Rong_(painter)#mediaviewer/File:Chen_Rong_-_Nine_Dragons.jpg" target="_blank">image</a> via Wikimedia Commons.)</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><br /><strong>The Minor Program in Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</strong> is designed for students interested in the language, history, politics, and culture of Asia. The geographic region of Asia includes countries such as Bangladesh, China, India, Japan, Korea, Mongolia, Pakistan, the Philippines, Taiwan, and Vietnam. In consultation with the minor advisor, students may focus their coursework on a sub-region of Asia, on one of the Asian diasporas, or design their program to offer a comparative study across different regions and/or cultural groups.</p>

<p>The goal of the Minor Program is to provide balanced coverage of language, humanistic, and social science offerings and to expose students to comparative perspectives.</p>

<p>The Minor Program in Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects) arranged in four areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>The language requirement can be satisfied by taking two intermediate (Levels III and IV) subjects in an Asian language. Students with proficiency at this level in the spoken and written language can either take two more advanced language subjects (highly recommended), or two more courses from Areas II, III and IV. Chinese and Japanese are taught at MIT. Other languages may be taken at Harvard, Wellesley, or during the summer with permission from relevant transfer credit examiner.</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the eight-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement. Of the six subjects required for the minor, at least four must count only toward that minor (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/asian-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<h3> </h3>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Minor Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:nagahara@mit.edu">Hiromu Nagahara</a>, E51-255, x4-4977<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-239" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor in Latin American and Latino/a Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Bonampak_painting.jpg" width="585" /><br /><em>Fresco of musicians; Bonampak, Chiapas; Photo ©2004 Jacob Rus, licensed under </em><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg#mediaviewer/File:Bonampak_painting.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Creative Commons</em></a><em> </em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>The Minor Program in Latin American and Latino/a Studies </strong>is designed for students interested in the language, history, politics, and culture of Latin America and in its presence in the United States. Students are encouraged to develop a program that is both international and comparative in perspective and that takes into account the heterogeneous cultural experiences of people living in the vast territory ecompassed by the term Latin America, as well as of those people living in the United States who identify themselves as Latino/a.</p>

<p>The Minor Program in Latin American &amp; Latino/a Studies consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects, including required subject 17.55J/21A.430J/21G.084J Introduction to Latin American Studies) arranged into four areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the eight-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement. Of the six subjects required for the minor, at least four must count only toward that minor (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/latin-american-latino-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<p>Subjects in Latin American and Latino/a Studies are also available from Harvard University and Wellesley College through cross-registration. Students must receive permission from the minor advisor prior to registering for a class at another institution.  </p>

<p>This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</p>

<p>Additional information may be obtained from the Minor Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:brs@mit.edu">Ben Schneider</a>, E53-423, x3-7207<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-240" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor in Middle Eastern Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><em><img alt="" height="225" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_ceilings-mosque.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	Blue Mosque, Sultanahmet</em></p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>Middle Eastern Studies at MIT</strong> offers students the opportunity to explore the connections among culture, society, politics, economics, technology, and environment in the Middle East, including North Africa. MIT offers a number of subjects open to undergraduates which provide a variety of perspectives on the ancient, Islamic, and modern Middle East. The goal of the HASS Minor Program in Middle Eastern Studies is to lead the student from the basic language into survey subjects and then into more focused studies of individual countries or specific historical periods and to encourage analysis of the main methodological and conceptual issues in Middle Eastern Studies.</p>

<p><strong>The Minor Program in Middle Eastern Studies</strong> consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects) arranged into four areas of study.</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the eight-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement. Of the six subjects required for the minor, at least four must count only toward that minor (and not toward any other degrees, major or minor).</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/middle-eastern-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligilble subjects.</strong></p>

<p><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-size: 11px;">This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</span></p>

<p>A substantial number of courses dealing with Middle Eastern Studies are available to our students at Wellesley College and Harvard University. Students may take relevant courses at these institutions provided they receive permission in advance from the HASS Middle Eastern Studies Minor Advisor.</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Additional information can be obtained from the Minor Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:khoury@mit.edu">Philip S. Khoury</a>, 10-280, x3-0887<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965,<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-240 -->

            <article id="node-241" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Minor Program in Russian and Eurasian Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_St-Basils-Cathedral.jpg" width="585" /><br /><em>Detail, St. Basil's Cathedral, a former church, built between 1555-61; now a museum in Red Square, in the heart of Moscow, Russia</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>The Russian and Eurasian Studies Regional Studies Minor</strong> is intended for students seeking an interdisciplinary program of study centered on Russia and Eurasia. The program is regional in spirit, meaning that students can take courses in a wide range of countries of East/Central Europe, the Slavic states, and Central Asia.</p>

<p>The Minor Program in Russian Studies consists of six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects or subjects taken at Harvard or Wellesley under cross-registration) arranged into four areas of study:</p>

<p>Area I: Language</p>

<p>Area II: Humanities and the Arts</p>

<p>Area III: Social Sciences</p>

<p>Area IV: Historical Studies</p>

<p>As with all HASS Minors, only five of the six minor subjects may be counted toward the 8-subject Institute HASS Requirement. Of these five, at most one shall count toward satisfaction of the HASS Distribution Requirement.</p>

<p><strong><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/minors/russian-eurasian-studies/" target="_blank">Click here</a> for the latest listing of eligible subjects.</strong></p>

<p><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-size: 11px;">This list is not exhaustive. Relevant subjects that are no longer offered and subjects with variable topics (such as “special subjects” or “selected topics” courses, for example) may also be counted at the discretion of the minor advisor.</span></p>

<p><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-size: 11px;">Subjects in Russian and Eurasian Studies are also available from Harvard University and Wellesley College through cross-registration. Students must receive permission from the minor advisor prior to registering for a class at another institution.  </span></p>

<p>Additional Information can be obtained from the Minor Advisor:<br />
	Professor <a href="mailto:elizwood@mit.edu">Elizabeth Wood</a>, E51-282, x3-3255<br />
	Or from the <a href="mailto:mjpepin@mit.edu">History Office</a>, E51-255, x3-4965<br />
	Or from the SHASS Academic Administrator,<br /><a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">Andrea Wirth</a>, 4-240, x3-4441.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-241 -->

            <article id="node-158" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Joint Degrees<br /><strong>Combined study in the Humanities with Science or Engineering</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_shakespeare-circuit-board-crisp.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>S.B. in Humanities and Engineering  </strong>|<strong>  </strong><strong>S.B. in Humanities and Science </strong><br /><br />
	Students who wish to combine study in one of 19 fields in the humanities with work in an engineering or science field may pursue a joint degree, earning a Bachelor of Science in Humanities and Engineering (Course 21E), or a Bachelor of Science in Humanities and Science (Course 21S).  </p>

<p>If you are interested in this educational option, contact the <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu?subject=21E%20%2F%2021S%20Degree%20Inquiry">SHASS Academic Administrator</a> in the SHASS Dean's Office.<br /><br /><strong>Possible fields of study and degree requirements</strong><br /><br />
	The requirements for a joint degree, along with a list of the humanities fields that can be incorporated into this joint S.B. degree, can be found in the degree charts for <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-engineering-course-21e/">21E</a> and <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/degree-charts/humanities-science-course-21s/">21S</a>.  The degree requires 60% of the work in a humanities field and 40% of the work in an engineering or science field.  While the required portion of the engineering and science field is smaller than that of a full engineering or science degree, it does offer flexibility to use the unrestricted electives for other areas of engineering, science, or humanities, creating a more flexible platform on which to build your course of study. </p>

<p>Some popular combinations include, but are by no means limited to:</p>

<ul><li>Comparative Media Studies and Electrical Engineering &amp; Computer Science</li>
	<li>Literature and Mathematics</li>
	<li>Music and Electrical Engineering &amp; Computer Science</li>
	<li>Comparative Media Studies and Mechanical Engineering</li>
	<li>Science Writing and Mechanical Engineering</li>
	<li>Theater Arts and Electrical Engineering &amp; Computer Science</li>
	<li><span style="color: rgb(88, 88, 88); font-size: 11px;">Spanish and Mathematics</span></li>
</ul>      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-158 -->

          
        </div><!-- divcontent -->

      </div><!-- divbodymaincolumn -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>HASS Majors<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585_mit-henge-1.jpg" style="width: 585px; height: 260px;" /><br /><em>View of <a href="http://bit.ly/1tP1fzn" target="_blank">MIT Henge</a>, Infinite Corridor, photograph by </em><em><a href="http://bit.ly/1AFbeLM" target="_blank">Matt Yourst</a></em><br /><br /><br /><strong>MIT SHASS offers 19 undergraduate majors. </strong> </p>

<p style="text-align: right;"><a href="https://shass.mit.edu/resources/advisors/major" target="_blank"><strong>ROADMAPS and Sample Schedules</strong></a></p>

<p>As with most majors at MIT, these consist of a core of required subjects and a set of electives, and combine the study of basic principles with practical applications. The major course of study is designed to prepare students for careers in that field or for graduate study.<br /><br />
	Most students who major within the School do so through one of the following departments, sections, and programs:</p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Major Fields</strong></p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="3" height="235" width="500"><tbody><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/undergraduate/requirements.html" target="_blank">Anthropology</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/comparative-media-studies/undergraduate/" target="_blank">Comparative Media Studies</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://economics.mit.edu/under/majors" target="_blank">Economics</a> (Economics, Mathematical Economics)</td>
		</tr><tr><td>Global Studies and Languages (<a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/54" target="_blank">French</a>, <a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/58" target="_blank">German</a>, <a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/68" target="_blank">Spanish</a>)</td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://history.mit.edu/undergraduate" target="_blank">History</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities/" target="_blank">Humanities</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities-engineering/" target="_blank">Humanities and Engineering</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/interdisciplinary/undergraduate-programs/degrees/humanities-science/" target="_blank">Humanities and Science</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/linguistics/undergraduate/" target="_blank">Linguistics</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://lit.mit.edu/major-in-literature/" target="_blank">Literature</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/music-major" target="_blank">Music</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philosophy/majors.html" target="_blank">Philosophy</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/major/index.html" target="_blank">Political Science</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/major.html" target="_blank">Science, Technology, and Society</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/theater-arts/degree-requirements" target="_blank">Theater Arts</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/writing/undergraduate/" target="_blank">Writing</a> (Creative Writing, Digital Media, Science Writing)</td>
		</tr></tbody></table><p> </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Interdisciplinary Majors</strong></p>

<p>SHASS also offers six Interdisciplinary Majors. These programs are made up of coursework from multiple SHASS departments. Students who complete these programs receive an S.B. in Humanities, Course 21.<br />
	  </p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="3" width="500"><tbody><tr><td><strong>Interdisciplinary Major Fields</strong></td>
			<td><strong>Faculty Coordinator</strong></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/american">American Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:capozzol@mit.edu">Christopher Capozzola</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/ancient">Ancient and Medieval Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:amccants@mit.edu">Anne McCants</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="/undergraduate//interdisciplinary/majors/asian">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:nagahara@mit.edu">Hiromu Nagahara</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/latin-american">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:brs@mit.edu">Ben Schneider</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/majors/russian">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:elizwood@mit.edu">Elizabeth Wood</a></td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/degree-requirements/major" target="_blank">Women’s and Gender Studies</a></td>
			<td><a href="mailto:helee@MIT.EDU">Helen Elaine Lee</a></td>
		</tr></tbody></table><p><br /><br /><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/Screen_Shot_2017-06-06_at_2.18.24_PM.png" style="width: 590px; height: 184px;" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><a name="proposal" id="proposal"></a></p>

<p><br /><strong>How to prepare an Interdisciplinary Major proposal </strong></p>

<p>Students interested in one of the above Interdisciplinary Majors or interested in creating a customized HASS major should fill out the following PDF form and contact the Faculty Coordinator or the HASS Academic Administrator for guidelines and procedures. </p>

<p><a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/FORM%20Interdisciplinary%20Proposal.pdf" target="_blank">Interdisciplinary Major Proposal Form (PDF)</a><br />
	Right-click (control-click on a Mac) the link and choose "Download Linked File As..." to save the document to your computer.<br /><br /><strong>Learn more about</strong> <a href="http://bit.ly/1O0dPI9" target="_blank">The Power of STEM + SHASS at MIT</a><br />
	 </p>

<p class="imageonly"><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/about/590x320_MIT-Lightwands.jpg" style="" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p>At MIT, we view the humanities, arts, and social sciences as essential, both for educating great engineers, scientists, scholars, and citizens, and for sustaining the Institute’s capacity for innovation.   <br /><br />
	Why? Because the Institute’s mission is to advance knowledge and educate students who are prepared to help solve the world’s most challenging problems – in energy, health care, transportation, and dozens of other fields. To do this, our graduates naturally need advanced technical knowledge and skills — the deep, original thinking about the physical universe that is the genius of the science and engineering fields.<br /><br />
	But the world’s problems are never tidily confined to the laboratory, workbench, or spreadsheet. From climate change to poverty to disease, the challenges of our age are unwaveringly human in nature and scale; and engineering and science issues are always embedded in broader human realities, from deeply-felt cultural traditions to building codes to political tensions. So our students also need an in-depth understanding of human complexities — the political, cultural, and economic realities that shape our existence — as well as fluency in the powerful forms of thinking and creativity cultivated by the humanities, arts, and social sciences. More at <a href="http://bit.ly/1O0dPI9" target="_blank">The Power of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT</a>.</p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->
