    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>HASS Minors<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_MITHenge-photo-Richard-Koolish-MIT68.jpg" width="585" /><br /><view of=""></view><view of=""></view><view of=""></view><view of=""><em>MIT Henge, photograph courtesy of <a href="http://www.dickkoolish.com/rmk_page/mithenge.html" target="_blank">Richard Koolish</a> '68     </em></view></p>

<hr /><p><span class="smallerx1"><em>                                                                                                         </em></span></p>

<p><br /><strong>What is a Minor? </strong></p>

<p>Minors are coherent programs of study providing significant experience in their disciplines. Minor fields are specified as part of the S.B. degree, thus giving recognition of focused work in a discipline outside the major course of study. Each year hundreds of MIT undergraduates decide to minor in the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences, choosing from 30 fields.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Why Minor? </strong><br /><br />
	You may find that your 3- to 4-subject required <a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank">HASS Concentration</a> has not satisfied your curiosity about your field of choice. By adding 2 or 3 subjects to your concentration, you can build a 6-subject minor that allows you to explore the field in greater depth. A minor is <strong>not</strong> required for graduation, but you may earn up to 2 minors, whether in HASS fields or other disciplines.<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>You can choose from these 30 MIT HASS disciplines: </strong><br />
	  </p>

<table border="0" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" width="100%"><tbody><tr><td align="left" valign="top">
				<p><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/african" target="_blank">African and African Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/ancient" target="_blank">Ancient and Medieval Studies</a><br /><a href="http://anthropology.mit.edu/undergraduate/requirements" target="_blank">Anthropology</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/minor/ais.html" target="_blank">Applied International Studies</a><br /><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/minor-art-culture-and-technology-hass-minor" target="_blank">Art, Culture, and Technology</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/asian" target="_blank">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/39" target="_blank">Chinese</a><br /><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/comparative-media-studies/undergraduate/#minor" target="_blank">Comparative Media Studies</a><br /><a href="http://econ-www.mit.edu/under/minors" target="_blank">Economics</a><br /><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/55" target="_blank">French</a><br /><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/59" target="_blank">German</a><br /><a href="http://history.mit.edu/undergraduate" target="_blank">History</a><br /><a href="http://architecture.mit.edu/history-theory-and-criticism/degree/undergraduate" target="_blank">History of Architecture, Art, and Design</a><br /><a href="http://dusp.mit.edu/degrees/undergraduate" target="_blank">International Development</a><br /><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/61" target="_blank">Japanese</a></p>
			</td>
			<td align="left" valign="top">  </td>
			<td align="left" valign="top">
				<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/latin-american" target="_blank">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/linguistics/undergraduate/LingMinor.html" target="_blank">Linguistics</a><br /><a href="http://lit.mit.edu/minor-in-literature/" target="_blank">Literature</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/middle-eastern">Middle Eastern Studies</a><br /><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/music/degree-requirements/music-minor" target="_blank">Music</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/philosophy/minor.html" target="_blank">Philosophy</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergrad/minor.html" target="_blank">Political Science</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/minor/pp.html" target="_blank">Public Policy</a><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/russian" target="_blank">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a><br /><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/minor.html" target="_blank">Science, Technology, and Society</a><br /><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/node/69" target="_blank">Spanish</a><br /><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/theater-arts/degree-requirements" target="_blank">Theater Arts</a><br /><a href="http://dusp.mit.edu/degrees/undergraduate" target="_blank">Urban Studies and Planning</a><br /><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/minor" target="_blank">Women's and Gender Studies</a><br /><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/education/writing/undergraduate/" target="_blank">Writing</a></p>
			</td>
		</tr></tbody></table><hr /><p> </p>

<h4>HASS Minor Advisors</h4>

<p>For a list of current minor advisors, click <a href="/undergraduate/minors/advisors">here</a>.<br />
	 </p>

<h4>Course Requirements and Guidelines<br />
	 </h4>

<ul><li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">A HASS minor consists of at least 6 subjects. These are typically arranged into 3 levels, reflecting different degrees of sophistication. </span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">You may concentrate and minor in the same field, and use the same subjects for both. You must still submit concentration forms, even if you minor in the same field.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">No more than 5 of your HASS minor subjects may be applied toward the 8-subject HASS Requirement. Of these 5, only one may be applied toward the HASS-Distribution requirement.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">Minors are awarded when the S.B. degree is awarded, and must be associated with a specific degree.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">Subjects taken under the junior-senior P/D/F grading option cannot be used for a minor program.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">You may use transfer credits toward a HASS minor, at the discretion of the minor advisor. However, MIT subjects must comprise at least half of any minor program.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">You may not minor and major in the same field.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">A HASS minor may not be in the same field as the humanities component of a Course 21E or 21S major.</span></p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">You may not overlap more than 2 subjects between a HASS minor and any other degree (major or minor). In some cases, you may minor and major in different, but related fields. Regardless of any overlap in requirements between the two programs, SHASS does not allow students to overlap more than 2 subjects between any two degrees (minor and minor or minor and major).</span><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
</ul><p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/590_trio-of-images-minors-page.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 186px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Procedures, Forms, and Timing</strong> <br />
	 </p>

<ol class="paragraphic"><li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">Pick up a HASS minor application from the field office, the advisor for your chosen minor, the SHASS Dean's Office (4-240), or the Students Services Center (11-120). You should apply for your HASS minor by the end of your junior year.</span><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">Consult with the minor advisor about your program of study, and have the advisor sign your application.</span><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">Submit the yellow (“canary”) copy to Andrea Wirth in the SHASS Dean's Office, 4-240; distribute the other copies as indicated on the bottom of the form.</span><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1">To change any part of your program once it has been approved, consult the minor advisor. Mark the changes on the field office’s copy of your application (the original, white copy), have the minor advisor initial them, and give a photocopy to the Registrar's Office.</span><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1"><strong>You must file a HASS minor completion form by the end of the third week of your final term at MIT</strong>, whether or not you are taking some of your minor subjects during that term. If the deadline falls on a holiday, forms are due on Thursday instead. Here are the procedures to follow in each instance:</span></p>

		<ul><li>
				<p><span class="largerx1">If you have completed all of the subjects in your minor program, bring a HASS minor completion form (available from the same sources as the minor application) to the minor advisor for signature, along with an unofficial transcript and the white copy of your minor application (available from the minor field office). Have the head of the department, program, or section, sign the form as well and submit it to the Registrar's Office. You may file the completion form at any point after you have completed the subjects in your minor—there is no need to wait until your final semester--but you <strong>must</strong> do so by the deadline above in order to avoid a <strong>$50 late fee</strong>.</span></p>
			</li>
			<li>
				<p><span class="largerx1">If you are taking some of your minor subjects during your final term, list these subjects on the bottom of the minor completion form, have the minor advisor and the head of the department, program, or section sign the form, and submit it to the Registrar's Office. The last term subject(s) must be correctly listed. <strong>List the exact subject number under which you are registered.</strong> Failure to take these steps by the deadline above will result in a <strong>$50 late fee</strong>. If you need to change a last term subject after submitting the form, you must notify the Registrar's Office immediately. Once a passing grade for these classes has been reported, the Registrar will record that your minor is complete.</span></p>
			</li>
			<li>
				<p><span class="largerx1"><strong>Please note: As of Academic Year 2010-2011, the late fee has been raised from $40 to $50.</strong> Some forms list the old fee, but any late forms will be charged the $50 late fee.</span></p>
			</li>
		</ul></li>
	<li>
		<p><span class="largerx1"><strong>If you decide not to minor after you have submitted a minor application, you must notify the SHASS Academic Administrator and your minor advisor. </strong>Send an <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu?subject=HASS%20Minor%20Drop&amp;body=Full%20Name%3A%20%0AMIT%20ID%3A%20%0AClass%20Year%3A%20%0AMinor%20to%20be%20Dropped%3A%20">email</a> to both, with your full name, ID number, class year, and the minor you are dropping.</span><br /><br />
			 </p>
	</li>
</ol><p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/590_Ritvo-Class-Animals.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 342px;" /></p>

<p><em>Class on field trip for 21H.380 /21A.411/21H.980, People and Other Animals, a seminar on history and anthropology </em></p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>Learn more about</strong> <a href="/news/news-2014-power-of-humanities-arts-social-sciences-at-mit" target="_blank">The Power of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT</a></p>

<p>At MIT we view the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences as essential<span class="largerx1">, both for educating great engineers, scientists, scholars, and citizens, and for sustaining the Institute’s capacity for innovation.   <br /><br />
	Why? Because the Institute’s mission is to advance knowledge and educate students who are prepared to help solve the world’s most challenging problems – in energy, health care, transportation, and dozens of other fields. To do this, our graduates naturally need advanced technical knowledge and skills — the deep, original thinking about the physical universe that is the genius of the science and engineering fields.<br /><br />
	But the world’s problems are never tidily confined to the laboratory, workbench, or spreadsheet. From climate change to poverty to disease, the challenges of our age are unwaveringly human in nature and scale; and engineering and science issues are always embedded in broader human realities, from deeply-felt cultural traditions to building codes to political tensions.<br /><br />
	So our students also need an in-depth understanding of human complexities — the political, cultural, and economic realities that shape our existence — as well as fluency in the powerful forms of thinking and creativity cultivated by the humanities, arts, and social sciences.<strong> </strong></span><br /><br /><strong><a href="/news/news-2014-power-of-humanities-arts-social-sciences-at-mit" target="_blank">More</a></strong></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<ol class="paragraphic"></ol><p> </p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>HASS Minors  <strong>|</strong> <strong>Advisors for Fall 2017</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_MITHenge-photo-Richard-Koolish-MIT68.jpg" style="width: 585px; height: 260px;" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Questions?</strong><br /><br />
	For general questions about HASS Minors contact the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/acadinfo/deptcontacts/undergrad_administrators.html">staff of the headquarters of the discipline</a>, or the<a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu"> SHASS Academic Administrator</a>, Andrea Wirth (4-240B, X3-4441).<br />
	 </p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-230" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>HASS Minors in Regional Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_tahrir_square-2012.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em;" width="585" /><br /><em>Tahrir Square, Egypt, the Arab Spring, 2012</em><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>The following Minors in Regional Studies are approved</strong><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/african">African and African Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/asian">Asian and Asian Diaspora Studies</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/latin-american">Latin American and Latino/a Studies</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/middle-eastern">Middle Eastern Studies</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary/minors/russian">Russian and Eurasian Studies</a><br /><br />
	These interdisciplinary programs provide MIT undergraduates with a valuable opportunity to acquire knowledge of a particular country or region in conjunction with proficiency in that region's language. This better prepares them for academic, business, and government careers in a world where regions and countries are increasingly interdependent.</p>

<p><strong>Four Areas of Study </strong><br />
	Because the nature of these minors is cross-disciplinary, combining language study with humanities, arts, and social sciences, they are arranged into the following four areas of study:</p>

<p><strong>Area 1 </strong> Language (Intermediate level)<br /><strong>Area 2  </strong>Humanities and the Arts<br /><strong>Area 3  </strong>Social Sciences<br /><strong>Area 4  </strong>Historical Studies</p>

<p><strong>Assembling the Six Subjects for a Minor</strong><br />
	Students are required to take six subjects (at least three of which must be MIT subjects) in the following configuration: two intermediate-level language subjects (Area I) and four other subjects, chosen from at least two of the other three areas. If a student already has achieved the equivalent of intermediate-level proficiency, he or she can take either two more advanced-level language subjects or two more subjects from Areas II, III, or IV in place of the intermediate language subjects. Languages not presently taught at MIT may be taken at <a href="http://web.mit.edu/registrar/reg/xreg/ugradMITtoHarvard.html" target="_blank">Harvard</a> or <a href="http://web.mit.edu/registrar/reg/xreg/MITtoWellesley.html" target="_blank">Wellesley</a>, or elsewhere during the summer with the permission of the Minor Advisor.</p>

<p><strong>About Each Minor </strong><br />
	Details on each of the minors are available on their relevant pages (see links above). Lists of subjects that are appropriate for a HASS minor in each of the regional studies, as well as additional information about minors, advisors, etc., can be obtained from the relevant <a href="/undergraduate/minors/advisors">Minor Advisor</a> or from the <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">SHASS Academic Administrator</a>.<br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

            <article id="node-172" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Contacts<br /><strong>Finding answers to your HASS questions </strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p> </p>

<p><span class="largerx2"><strong><span class="smallerx1">We are here to help. </span></strong><br /><br /><span class="smallerx1">We’re happy to answer all your questions about undergraduate HASS studies, including how to navigate the SHASS offerings, how to minor in HASS, how to do a 21E or 21S joint degree, or a Course 21 (Humanities) interdisciplinary major, and anything else you need to know about HASS fields. </span>Please note that the SHASS Academic Administrator does not handle Admissions or Graduate Studies. </span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Contact the SHASS Academic Administrator</strong>  <br /><br />
	Andrea Wirth<br />
	Phone: 617-253-4441<br />
	Email: <a href="mailto:awirth@mit.edu">awirth@mit.edu</a><br /><br />
	Visit: 4-240. Regular office hours are M-F, 10AM-12PM and 2-5PM.<br />
	Feel free to set up an appointment, or just come by the office.<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><h2><br /><br /><strong>Additional Sources of Information</strong></h2>

<p><br /><strong>Contacts for the </strong><a href="/undergraduate/hass-fields" target="_blank">HASS Field Offices</a><br /><br /><strong>For questions regarding the HASS Requirement</strong>,<br />
	contact Patty Fernandes, Advisor <br />
	Communication and HASS Requirements<br />
	Email: <a href="mailto:hassreq@mit.edu">hassreq@mit.edu</a><br />
	Phone: 617-523--2313<br />
	Location: 5-133</p>

<p><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

              <h1>MIT SHASS classes related to current social, political, and economic issues in the U.S.<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/590x280_flag-circuit-board.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 280px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br />
	See below for a list of MIT classes related to current social, political, and economic issues in the U.S.. The classes are organized by department or program<em>. </em>Please refer to the <a href="http://catalog.mit.edu/" target="_blank">official subject listings</a> for updated schedules and locations.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Related links</strong></p>

<p><a href="/research/impact/citizenship" target="_blank">21st Century Citizenship | Research + Events</a></p>

<p><a href="/news/mens-et-manus-america-initiative-site" target="_blank"><em>Mens et Manus </em>America</a><br /><br /><a href="http://cis.mit.edu/events-seminars/about-starr-forum" target="_blank">Starr Forum Events | Center for International Studies</a></p>

<p><a href="https://commforum.mit.edu/" target="_blank">Communications Forum</a></p>

<p> </p>

            <article id="node-177" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Student Awards and Opportunities<br /><strong>Scholarships, Fellowships, Societies, Prizes</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><strong><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_fireworks-gold-red.jpg" width="585" /></strong><br /><br /><em>                                                                             </em><br /><br /><strong>Exceptional Opportunities for Excellent Students</strong><br /><br />
	The following opportunities are available to MIT undergraduates — regardless of major — who have demonstrated excellence in some aspect of the humanities, arts, and social sciences.  <br /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><h3><br /><br /><a href="/burchard" target="_blank">Burchard Scholars Program</a></h3>

<p>The Burchard Scholars Program brings together students and faculty members in a series of monthly dinner seminars.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong><a href="/resources/internal/deflorez" target="_blank">De Florez Fund for Humor</a></strong><br />
	Funding for MIT students, faculty, and staff<br />
	 </p>

<h3><span class="largerx1"><span class="smallerx1"><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas" target="_blank">Kelly-Douglas Fund</a></span></span></h3>

<p><span class="largerx1"><span class="smallerx1">The Kelly-Douglas Fund includes two awards for undergraduates: the I. Austin Kelly III Essay Prize and the Kelly-Douglas Traveling Fellowship. </span></span><br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/phi-beta-kappa" target="_blank">Phi Beta Kappa Society</a></h3>

<p><span class="largerx1"><span class="smallerx1">The faculty committee that elects students to MIT’s chapter of the Phi Beta Kappa Society takes into account several criteria relating to a student’s HASS coursework</span></span><br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/palitz" target="_blank">Palitz Fellowship for the Study of Dutch Art</a> </h3>

<p><span class="largerx1"><span class="smallerx1">A fellowship for an exceptional MIT undergraduate to spend the summer in The Hague, Netherlands, studying the Golden Age of Dutch and Flemish art and culture—with special access to the Royal Picture Gallery, Mauritshuis</span></span><br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="http://web.mit.edu/scholarships/scholarships.htm" target="_blank">MIT Scholarships and Fellowships</a></h3>

<p>Main MIT listing of scholarships and fellowships<br />
	 </p>

<h3><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/awards" target="_blank">SHASS Departmental Awards</a></h3>

<p>Awards and prizes available to MIT undergraduates from the SHASS academic disciplines<br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

            <article id="node-1624" class="node node-lev3page">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>SHASS Departmental Awards<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_fireworks-yellow-red-with-tracers.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><br /><br /><br /><strong>The following is a list of awards and prizes available to MIT undergraduates from the MIT SHASS academic disciplines:  </strong></p>

<p class="rteleft"><a href="#_anthroaward">Anthropology</a> | <a href="#_cmsaward">Comparative Media Studies / Writing</a> | <a href="#_economics">Economics</a> | <a href="#_gslaward">Global Studies and Languages</a> | <a href="#_historyaward">History</a> | <a href="#_literatureaward">Literature</a> | <a href="#_musicaward">Music</a> | <a href="#_polisciaward">Political Science</a> | <a href="#_sts">Science, Technology, and Society</a> | <a href="#_wgsaward">Women's and Gender Studies</a> | <a href="#_shassawards">School Awards and Opportunities</a></p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_anthroaward" id="_anthroaward"></a>Anthropology</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://web.mit.edu/anthropology/undergraduate/howeprize.html" target="_blank">MIT Anthropology James Howe Prize</a></p>

<p>The annual James Howe Prize honors the contributions of Professor of Anthropology James Howe, who retired in 2012. Professor Howe's scholarship has focused on the history and political struggles of the indigenous Kuna population in Panama. A renowned photographer and political activist, not only has Howe's ethnographic work supported the rights of the Kuna people, as a longstanding board member of Cultural Survival — an organization that provides support to and advocates on behalf of the linguistic, cultural, and property rights of indigenous populations around the world — Howe has promoted human rights throughout his distinguished career. The James Howe Prize is awarded each spring.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_cmsaward" id="_cmsaward"></a>Comparative Media Studies / Writing</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://cmsw.mit.edu/publications/ilona-karmel-writing-prizes/" target="_blank">Ilona Karmel Writing Prizes</a></p>

<p>The Ilona Karmel Writing Prizes are awarded every May by MIT’s Comparative Media Studies/Writing program. This competition was named in honor of the late Ilona Karmel, novelist, poet and Senior Lecturer in the writing program. Throughout her teaching career, Karmel’s outstanding contributions to creative writing at MIT were her inspirational teachings and relationships with students.</p>

<p><u>Ellen King Prize for Freshman Writing</u></p>

<p>Writing by freshmen at MIT in any category is eligible; e.g., short story, poetry (must contain at least three poems), essay, and drama.</p>

<p><u>Enterprise Poets Prize for Imagining a Future</u></p>

<p>Essays, short stories or poems, that convincingly imagine a future human enterprise are eligible. The word enterprise is used in the broadest possible sense to cover products, processes, companies, industries, forms of government, social movements, artistic forms – any human endeavor. This prize is open to undergraduate and graduate MIT students.</p>

<p><u>Robert A. Boit Writing Prize</u></p>

<p>Writing by MIT undergraduate students in the categories of essay, poetry and short story is eligible.</p>

<p><u>S. Klein Prizes: Scientific Writing</u></p>

<p>Manuscripts should be intended for non-specialized but educated audiences and show evidence of publishable quality. Open to MIT undergraduate and graduate students.</p>

<p><u>S. Klein Prizes: Technical Writing</u></p>

<p>Manuscripts should be intended for an audience of peers and professionals. Open to MIT undergraduate and graduate students.</p>

<p><u>DeWitt Wallace Prize for Science Writing for the Public</u></p>

<p>Writing of any length addressed to lay audiences on issues and developments in science, medicine, and engineering. Open to MIT undergraduate students only.</p>

<p><u>Boit Manuscript Prize</u></p>

<p>Awarded for longer works and collections, in any category mentioned above, which give evidence of publishable quality. Both completed manuscripts and those in progress are eligible. Works of substantial length by MIT undergraduate students are eligible in the categories of fiction, poetry (minimum length of 200 lines or 10-15 poems), essay, and drama (a play in one act or equivalent).</p>

<p><u>Writing and Humanistic Studies Prize for Engineering Writing</u></p>

<p>Manuscripts should be intended for an audience of engineers and other professionals who are knowledgeable about the subject matter. Writing from any engineering discipline is welcome. Types of papers may include design documents, engineering lab reports, literature reviews focused on a particular technology or engineering problem, design reports or proposals, and analyses of testing or other experiments. Group- written reports are acceptable if all authors are MIT undergraduates at the time of submission.</p>

<p><u>Prize for Writing Science Fiction</u></p>

<p>Writing by MIT undergraduate students in the category of science fiction short story.</p>

<p><u>Vera List Prize for Writing on the Visual Arts</u></p>

<p>Open to MIT undergraduate and graduate students. Writing should demonstrate unusual and thoughtful expression on some aspect of contemporary visual art. Works can be prose, poetry, or graphic format. Sponsored by the List Visual Arts Center.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a id="_economics" name="_economics"></a>Economics</h4>

<hr /><p><u>Undergraduate Economics Association Journal Prizes</u></p>

<p>To acknowledge excellence in writing in the field of Economics, the Undergraduate Economics Association prints the MIT Undergraduate Journal of Economics at the end of each academic year.  Three cash prizes are given for the best three papers submitted.  The best five or six papers are printed in the journal. For more information, please email <a href="mailto:gking@mit.edu?subject=UEA%20Journal%20Prizes">Gary King</a>.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_gslaward" id="_gslaward"></a>Global Studies and Languages</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/academics-courses/award-excellence" target="_blank">Award for Excellence in G</a><a href="http://mitgsl.mit.edu/academics-courses/award-excellence">lobal Studies and Languages</a></p>

<p>Awarded annually, the MIT Award For Excellence in Global Studies and Languages is presented to an outstanding student of languages. The award includes a monetary prize to be used for international travel and lodging for the undergraduate student who best reflects the Section’s goals for achievement of proficiency in language, cultural understanding and enthusiasm in language learning. The stipend must be used in a country whose language the grantee has studied at MIT and must be used by February 1st of the following year.</p>

<p><a href="http://cbbs.mit.edu/isabelle-de-courtivron-prize" target="_blank">Isabelle de Courtivron Writing Prize</a></p>

<p>The Isabelle de Courtivron Prize seeks student writing submissions on immigrant, diaspora, bicultural, bilingual, and/or mixed-race experiences. It is open to all MIT undergraduate students. Entries will be judged by a panel of faculty and professional writers. The Isabelle de Courtivron Prize was established by MIT’s Center for Bilingual / Bicultural Studies to reward high-quality undergraduate writing (creative or expository) and to honor distinguished Professor Emerita Isabelle de Courtivron. De Courtivron, a professor in MIT Foreign Languages and Literatures, was one of the founders of the CB/BS. The Prize was established on the occasion of her retirement in 2010 and is awarded on an annual basis.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong><a name="_historyaward" id="_historyaward"></a>History</strong></p>

<hr /><p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/palitz">Palitz Fellowship for the Study of Dutch Art and Culture </a></p>

<p>The Palitz Fellowship is an exciting new research and international education opportunity for MIT undergradutes. The 6-month term as a Palitz Fellow includes the Spring semester in preparation with a faculty supervisor, followed by summer study in the Hague, with access to the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis. Areas of study can include any aspect of culture, art, or history in the Dutch and Flemish Golden Age, for example: history of science, horticulture, or cartography; the art market; economic history; or the technologies of print making and book production.</p>

<p><a href="http://history.mit.edu/news/history-undergraduate-writing-prizes" target="_blank">Undergraduate Writing Prizes in History</a></p>

<p>The Undergraduate Writing Prizes in History award excellence in historical research and writing in honor of MIT Historians John Dower, Pauline Maier, and Bruce Mazlish.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_literatureaward" id="_literatureaward"></a>Literature</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="mailto:dalesej@mit.edu">Peter S. Donaldson Prize for Excellence in Literary Studies</a></p>

<p>Awarded to a literature major each spring who excels academically and is an engaging participant in the literary community at MIT.</p>

<p><a href="mailto:dalesej@mit.edu">John Hildebidle Poetry Prize</a></p>

<p>The Poetry Prize is awarded to students who excel academically in 21L.004 “Reading Poetry” and enrich the poetry community at MIT more broadly.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_musicaward" id="_musicaward"></a>Music</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/music/performance/emerson-program" target="_blank">MIT Emerson Scholarship/Fellowship Program for Private Study</a></p>

<p>Funded by Mr. Cherry L. Emerson, Jr. (SM, 1941) the Emerson Program offers merit-based financial assistance for private lessons to MIT students who demonstrate outstanding achievement on their instrument or voice in classical, jazz or world music. Each academic year private study scholarships and fellowships are offered to approximately 50 qualified students out of about 100 who apply and audition. Private teacher selections, made in consultation with the music faculty, may include instructors from MIT or from the greater Boston musical community.</p>

<p><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/music/performance" target="_blank">Concerto Competition</a></p>

<p>An MIT student soloist will be selected each spring to perform with the MIT Symphony.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_polisciaward" id="_polisciaward"></a>Political Science</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://www.web.mit.edu/polisci/undergraduate/pressman/index.html" target="_blank">Pressman Awards</a></p>

<p>Talented MIT undergraduates are recognized annually with the Jeffrey L. Pressman Award for research or internship in U.S. government, politics, policy, law, or education. Pressman Awards include stipends in support of special summer projects or internships in issues related to American politics. The project should focus on a legal, political, institutional, or policy issue. All MIT undergraduates returning to campus as undergraduates in the fall semester are eligible to apply.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a id="_sts" name="_sts"></a>Science, Technology, and Society</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/news/ongoing.html">The Benjamin Siegel Prize</a></p>

<p>The Benjamin Siegel prize was established in 1990 by family and friends of the late Benjamin Siegel (S.B. 1938, Ph.D.). The Prize of $2500 is awarded to the MIT student submitting the best written work on issues in science, technology, and society. It is open to undergraduate and graduate students from any school or department of the Institute.  Submissions must be a single-authored work of no more than 50 pages written within the last two academic years.</p>

<p> </p>

<h4><a name="_wgsaward" id="_wgsaward"></a>Women’s and Gender Studies</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/kampf-prize" target="_blank">The Louis Kampf Writing Prize in Women's and Gender Studies</a></p>

<p>The writing prize, sponsored by The Program in Women's and Gender Studies (WGS), was started in 1995-96 to honor Louis Kampf, distinguished professor emeritus of Literature and Women's Studies, and to reward high quality undergraduate writing in women's and gender studies. The Prize is judged by faculty from WGS. MIT students can submit entries in different genres of academic writing as well as fiction and poetry. Submissions should provide thoughtful reflection using gender as a central category of analysis.</p>

<h4><br /><a id="_shassawards" name="_shassawards"></a>School Awards and Opportunities</h4>

<hr /><p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/burchard">Burchard Scholars Program</a></p>

<p>The Burchard Scholars Program brings together distinguished members of the faculty and promising MIT sophomores and juniors who have demonstrated excellence in some aspect of the humanities, arts, or social sciences. The format is a series of dinner seminars that reflect the vast range of inquiry and research in the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Science.</p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas">The Kelly Douglas Fund </a></p>

<p>The Kelly-Douglas fund supports projects that enrich our understanding of one or more of the fields comprising the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT.</p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay">Kelly-Douglas Essay Prize for Excellence in Humanistic Scholarship</a></p>

<p>To acknowledge outstanding achievement by undergraduate students intellectually committed to fields of study that fall under the purview of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT, the Kelly-Douglas Fund awards two cash prizes to the best essays in any field of study within SHASS.</p>

<p><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/traveling">Kelly-Douglas Fund IAP and Summer Travel Fellowships</a></p>

<p>An important dimension of the Kelly-Douglas Fund is the support for and encouragement of undergraduate education in the humanities, arts and social sciences. A portion of the Fund is reserved for Traveling Fellowships for MIT pursuing an endeavor of their own devising either during IAP or the Summer. All MIT sophomores, juniors, and seniors wishing to travel during IAP or Summer to deepen their understanding of a field in the humanities, arts, and social sciences, or to contribute to a humanitarian project are eligible to apply. Students need not belong to the School of HASS, though majors and minors in the School will be given preference.<br /><br /><br /><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_fireworks-three-blooms.jpg" width="180" /></p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-1624 -->

          
        </div><!-- divcontent -->

            <article id="node-216" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>The Burchard Scholars Program <br /><strong>Expand your horizons at dinner seminars with distinguished MIT faculty </strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Burchard-pencils.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/burchard/application" target="_blank"><strong>Students, you can apply here.</strong></a><br />
	Program open to MIT sophomores and juniors.<br /><strong>Application deadline October 31, 2017</strong><br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx1"><strong>Expand Your Horizons at </strong><strong>Dinner Seminars with Distinguished Faculty </strong></span></p>

<p>The Burchard Scholars Program brings together distinguished members of the faculty and promising MIT sophomores and juniors who have demonstrated excellence in some aspect of the humanities, arts, or social sciences. About 35 MIT undergraduates are selected each year for the competitive program. Each cohort of "Burchards" participates for one calendar year, from February through December.<br /><br />
	The format is a series of dinner seminars that reflect the vast range of inquiry and research in the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Science. The Burchard Program consists of nine events throughout a calendar year — a large reception at the beginning of spring term, seven dinner-seminars, and one cultural event in the fall. Seminars are held monthly, on Wednesday evenings from 5-7pm, during the school year.</p>

<p><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>Application Information</strong></span></p>

<p>The Burchard Scholars application must include the following materials:</p>

<ul><li>Curriculum Vitae or résumé</li>
	<li>List of HASS classes you have taken at MIT</li>
	<li>A letter of recommendation from a faculty member who has taught you in a HASS course</li>
	<li>An essay on one of three essay topics in less than 500 words:
		<ul><li>If you could require every incoming MIT student to read one book, what would it be and why?</li>
			<li>"Great ideas change the world.” In your essay, personalize the SHASS motto by addressing the following question: How have one or two “great ideas” changed you and your views of “the world”?</li>
			<li>Write about an experience in which you encountered a tension between personal freedom and community standards. Discuss the experience and the underlying issues, how you dealt with the tension, and whether or not there was a satisfactory resolution.</li>
		</ul></li>
</ul><p>Students submit applications online <a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/burchard/application">here</a>. You are expected to contact your HASS faculty/lecturer referee directly no later than the application deadline to make arrangements for them to supply a recommendation directly to <a href="mailto:burchard-scholars@mit.edu">burchard-scholars@mit.edu</a> no later than one full week after the application deadline. You should supply them copies of your résumé and your list of HASS subjects. Please allow your referees time to do their job!</p>

<p><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>Applications are due on October 31, 2017 </strong></span><span class="largerx1"><strong>for the 2018 Burchard Program. </strong></span></p>

<p>Please note:</p>

<p>A Burchard Scholar can be a major in any department of the Institute; no preference is given to HASS majors. All sophomores and juniors in good standing are eligible to apply. If you have a question about the Program or how to apply, please email <a href="mailto:burchard-scholars@mit.edu ?subject=Inquiry%20to%20Burchard%20Scholars%20Program">burchard-scholars@mit.edu</a>.<br />
	 </p>

<p><span class="largerx1"><strong>Information on the Burchard Program</strong></span></p>

<p><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/burchard/events">Burchard Events</a><br /><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/past-burchards">Past Burchard Scholars</a></p>

<div> </div>

<p> </p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly Douglas Fund <br /><strong>Mission | Contents | Announcements</strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_johann-wolfgang-von-goethe.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p><br /><strong>Application Announcements </strong></p>

<p><br /><strong style="font-size: 0.92em;"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/traveling" target="_blank">Kelly-Douglas Traveling Fellowships</a></strong><br />
	Fellowship applications deadline for 2017-2018 will be announced soon.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/grants" target="_blank">Teaching and Research Support</a></strong><br />
	Applications for teaching and research support accepted on a rolling basis.</p>

<p><br /><strong><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay" target="_blank">Kelly Essay Prize</a></strong><br />
	Application deadline for 2017-2018 will be announced soon.</p>

<p> </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Mission</strong><br /><br />
	The Kelly-Douglas fund supports projects that enrich our understanding of one or more of the fields comprising the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT.</p>

<p>Initially created to support faculty research and teaching in the humanities alone, the Fund has gradually shifted its emphasis, broadening its mission to include lecturers and students (both graduate and undergraduate).<br /><br /><br /><br /><strong>Contents</strong><br /><br />
	The following pages describe the fund, answer frequently asked questions, and give information about the three areas of funding.  <br />
	 </p>

<p>          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/about" target="_blank">About | History, Areas of Funding, Administration, Contact</a></p>

<p>          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/faqs" target="_blank">FAQs | Frequently-Asked Questions</a></p>

<p>          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay" target="_blank">Kelly Essay Prize</a> | <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay-prize/application" target="_blank">Application</a></p>

<p>          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/grants" target="_blank">Research and Teaching Grants</a> | <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/grants/application" target="_blank">Application</a> </p>

<p>          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/traveling" target="_blank">Traveling IAP and Summer Fellowships</a> | <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/traveling/application" target="_blank">Application</a>   <br /><br />
	          <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/awards" target="_blank">Award Recipients</a> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly Douglas Fund <strong>| About <br />
	History, Areas of Funding, Administration, Contacts</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_building_sky.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<h2> </h2>

<h2><strong>On this Page</strong></h2>

<h2>History of the Fund <br />
	Director and Acting Director<br />
	Areas of Funding <br />
	Fund Administration <br />
	Contact Us <br />
	 </h2>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><b>History of the Fund</b><br /><br />
	The Kelly-Douglas Fund was established in 1975 through generous donations of I. Austin Kelly III (1903-2003, SB'26). Its founder and first director was the historian Richard M. Douglas (1922-2005), who came to MIT in 1962 to head the Humanities Department. Upon his retirement in 1991, Austin Kelly requested that the Kelly Fund be re-named the Kelly-Douglas Fund in honor of its first director. <br />
	 </p>

<p><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/180_austin-kelly.bw_.jpg" width="180" />      <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/180_richard-douglas.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p><a href="http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2003/kelly-1008.html" target="_blank">Ironton Austin Kelly</a>                        <a href="http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2005/obit-douglas.html" target="_blank">Richard M. Douglas</a><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>1996 - 2006</strong><br />
	The Fund was subsequently piloted for five years by the historian Arthur Kaledin, and then for ten years (1996-2006) by the music historian, Lowell Lindgren, under whose tenure the basic policies of the Fund as it operates today were put into place. Professor Lindgren was the motivating force behind the undergraduate traveling fellowships; these were first awarded in 2000, following the silver anniversary of the Kelly-Douglas Fund.<br /><br /><br /><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_Kaledin-bw.jpg" width="180" />      <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_lindgren-color.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p><a href="http://web.mit.edu/adkaledi/www/kaledin.htm" target="_blank">Arthur Kaledin</a>                                <a href="http://web.mit.edu/music/facstaff/lindgren.html" target="_blank">Lowell Lindgren</a><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Current Director</strong><br /><br />
	The Current Director of the Kelly-Douglas Fund is Professor Shankar Raman of the Literature Section.</p>

<p> </p>

<p> <img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/square_Shankar-Raman_portrait_.jpeg" width="180" />     </p>

<p><a href="http://lit.mit.edu/people/sraman/" target="_blank">Shankar Raman</a>, <em>Director </em>            <br />
	 </p>

<p><img alt="" height="0" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/180_ram.jpg" width="0" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><br /><strong>Areas of Funding </strong><br /><br />
	The Fund divides its resources over three main areas:</p>

<p><strong>1—</strong>Teaching and Research Support for teaching staff (primarily faculty and lecturers) and graduate students in HASS. The Fund helps teachers bring in guest lecturers, take students to see a performance, and so on. It assists graduate student research and development through partial support for travel to conferences, libraries, or other repositories of information centrally related to the student's research.</p>

<p><strong>2—</strong>The I. Austin Kelly III Essay Prizes recognize excellence in humanistic scholarship by MIT undergraduates.<br /><br /><strong>3—</strong>Traveling Fellowships are awarded to MIT undergraduates who intend to pursue HASS-related or humanitarian projects during either IAP or the Summer.<br />
	 <br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Fund Administration </strong><br /><br />
	The Fund is housed in the Dean's Office in the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences. Its activities are overseen by a Director appointed by the Dean and a Board consisting of HASS Faculty selected by the Fund's Director. The current Director of the Kelly-Douglas Fund is Professor Shankar Raman of the Literature Section.</p>

<p>Enquiries concerning applying to the Fund should be directed in the first instance to the Director; for queries about the disbursement of funds, please contact the Administrator. Board Members serving for the 2014-2015 academic year are: Professors Sandy Alexandre (Literature), Patricia Tang (Music), William Broadhead (History), and Stefan Helmreich (Anthropology).<br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_k-d-about.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>Contact Us </strong><br /><br />
	Please read the relevant portions of the <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas" target="_blank">Kelly Douglas web pages</a> (including the <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/faqs" target="_blank">FAQs</a>) carefully before contacting the Fund Administrators. All queries regarding application procedures or of a general nature should be addressed to:<br /><br /><strong>Professor Shankar Raman </strong>| <strong>Director </strong><br />
	Attn: Kelly-Douglas Fund<br />
	Room 14N-433<br />
	77 Massachusetts Avenue<br />
	Cambridge MA 02139<br />
	Email: sram@MIT.EDU<br />
	Tel: 617-253-8873</p>

<p>Questions about the status of application or the disbursement of funds should be directed to the Administrator:</p>

<p><b>Thomas Arabia</b><strong> </strong>| <strong>Kelly-Douglas Fund Administrator</strong><br />
	14N-407 Literature Headquarters MIT<br />
	77 Massachusetts Ave<br />
	Cambridge MA 02139<br />
	Email: arabia@mit.edu<br />
	Tel: 617-253-3581<br /><br /><br />
	Should the Director or the Administrator not be available, please email one of the Board Members listed below:</p>

<p><a href="mailto:alexandy@mit.edu">Professor Sandy Alexandre</a>, Literature<br /><a href="mailto:sgh2@mit.edu">Professor Stefan Helmreich</a>, Anthropology<br /><a href="mailto:pjtang@mit.edu">Professor Patricia Tang</a>, Music<br /><a href="mailto:williamb@mit.edu">Professor William Broadhead</a>, History<br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

              <h1>Kelly Douglas Award Recipients<br /><strong>Essay Prize, Undergraduate Traveling Fellowships, IAP Travel Awards </strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_San_Diego_Fireworks.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p><em>San Diego fireworks; photocredit Quadell, 2004; </em><a href="http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:San_Diego_Fireworks.jpg#mediaviewer/File:San_Diego_Fireworks.jpg" target="_blank"><em>Public domain</em></a><em> via Wikimedia Commons</em></p>

<hr /><h2><br /><br /><strong>Kelly-Douglas Essay Prize</strong> </h2>

<div>
	<h4 class="dotted" style="line-height: 13.8000001907349px;">2015</h4>

	<p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"> </p>

	<p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"><strong>Winners</strong></p>

	<ul><li style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;">
			<p style="line-height: 14.2195205688477px;">Daniel Parker, ’16, “The Unity and Disunity in Beethoven’s Great Fugue”</p>
		</li>
	</ul><p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"><strong>Runner-ups</strong></p>

	<ul><li style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;">
			<p style="line-height: 14.2195205688477px;">Daniel Stone, ’17, “Reverse Culture Shock”</p>
		</li>
	</ul><p style="line-height: 15.4559993743896px;"> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">2014</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<p><strong>Winners</strong></p>

	<ul><li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Leonid Grinberg (Electric Engineering and Computer Science, 2014) awarded $800 for "Fumbling the 'Torch of Civilization': MIT and the Tragedy of Aaron Swartz"</span></p>
		</li>
	</ul><p><strong>Runner-ups</strong></p>

	<ul><li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Natasha Balwit (Urban Studies and Planning, 2016) awarded $400 for "Sufi Road: Voices of Torreon"</span></p>
		</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">2013</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<p><strong>Winners</strong></p>

	<ul><li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Alicia Singham Goodwin (Mathematics / Women's and Gender Studies, 2014) awarded $800 for "The Stifled History of the Feminist Porn Debates"</span><br />
				 </p>
		</li>
		<li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Michelle Dion (Chemical Engineering, 2013) awarded $800 for "Breaching the Limits of Human Knowledge: The Intertextual Connections between Melville's <em>Moby-Dick</em> and Emerson's <em>Nature</em>"</span><br />
				 </p>
		</li>
	</ul><p><strong>Runner-ups</strong></p>

	<ul><li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Caitlin Mackey (Mechanical Engineering, 2015) awarded $400 for "MIT on Strike: The March 4th Demonstration"</span></p>
		</li>
	</ul>
	 

	<h4 class="dotted"><br />
		2012</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>
			<p><span class="largerx1">Xenia Antipova (Mechanical Engineering, 2013) awarded $800 for "Bonfield's Disregard for Justice: The Haymarket Riot"</span><br />
				 </p>
		</li>
	</ul><h4 class="dotted"><br />
		2011</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Emma Rosen (Economics, 2011): awarded $800 for "The Revolution Stops Here: Shay's' Rebellion"</li>
	</ul><p> <br />
		 </p>

	<h4 class="dotted"><strong>2010 </strong></h4>

	<p> </p>

	<p><strong>Winners</strong></p>

	<ul><li>Sam Kronick (Architecture, 2010): awarded $800 for "Air conditioning: A Conflict of Environmental Control"</li>
		<li>Matt Lord (Literature / Mathematics, 2010): awarded $800 for "Between Delight and Sacrifice: the Problem of Language in the Poetry of George Herbert"</li>
	</ul><p><strong>Runner-ups</strong></p>

	<ul><li>Praveen Rathinavelu (Literature / Mathematics, 2010): awarded $400 for "Aesthetic Self-Fashoning: Sugary Nymphets, Lechers, and Lovers in Lolita"</li>
		<li>Anna Waldman-Brown (Writing / Physics, 2011): awarded $400 for "Unpredictability of Determinism: Scientific Contradictions in Arcadia and Hapgood"</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted"><strong>2008-2009</strong></h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Cristen Blair Chinea (Course 4, 2010) for “From the First Maps to Today's Maps.”</li>
	</ul><p>The Committee for this year consisted of Professors Chris Capozzola (History), Michael Cuthbert (Music) and Sandy Alexandre (Literature).</p>

	<p> <br />
		 </p>

	<h2><strong>Kelly Douglas Undergraduate Traveling Fellowship</strong></h2>

	<p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted" style="line-height: 13.8px;">Summer 2015 </h4>

	<p style="line-height: 15.456px;"> </p>

	<ul><li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Neerja Aggarwal (Course 6, 2016): Study theatre and performance at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival from August 15—22.</li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Nisha Dalvie (Biological Engineering, 2016): Work with the Indian NGO AVANI by travelling to Uttarakhand India to hold co-creation workshops with the women working for a menstrual hygiene and empowerment project. </li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Joie Chang (Architecture, 2017): Travel to Venice to participate in the Veneto Experience, run by MIT professor Shun Kanda.</li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Alyssa Napier (Course 5, 2017): Travel to Berlin to attend two artistic and cultural events to enrich current as well as future projects. </li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Fernando Ruiz (Course 2, 2016): Humanitarian work in Tanzania.</li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Abra Shen 2016 Theatre Arts Study theatre and performance at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival, August 15—22.</li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Tamanna Urmi (Course 2, 2016): Travel to D'kar to engage with the Sans people in order to come up with solutions for their desert livelihood issues through technology. A group of engineers, artists, business students and others will work together. </li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Marissa  Wang (Course 18, 2018): Travel to Prague University to do a two week program with Bozzy Karasu, director of the PULSEE program (Prague University of Light and Sound Experimental Engineering).</li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Marsha Wibowo (Course 7, 2016): Empower underprivileged children in Indonesia by teaching and raising awareness of the importance of education. </li>
		<li style="line-height: 15.456px;">Mei Zuo (CMS, 2016): Travel to Silicon Valley, Shenzhen Technology Park, to interview women in STEM and research “Imposter Syndrome”, July 1—August 31.<br /></li>
	</ul><p style="line-height: 15.456px;"> </p>

	<p style="line-height: 15.456px;"> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">IAP 2013-2014 </h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Sherry Fu (Course 6, 2014): Improve data management systems within the leading HIV healthcare organization in Togo</li>
		<li>Han Beal Jang (Course 6, 2014): Attend MIT's 2014 IAP-in-Ancient &amp; Medieval Italy program</li>
		<li>Yuxin Jing(Course 6, 2015): Travel to Italy to learn about Roman, Greek and medieval archaelogy and history</li>
		<li>Ambika Krishnamachar (Course 6, 2015): Assist with conducting and evaluating an educational program on the risk of HIV/AIDS in Botswana</li>
		<li>Guillaume Kugener (Course 6, 2015): Travel to Togo to work on a project to implement a mobile health interface in an HIV clinic</li>
		<li>Jiahao Liang (Course 9, 2014): Attend MIT's 2014 IAP-in-Ancient &amp; Medieval Italy program</li>
		<li>Tiandra Ray (Course 4, 2015): To design and build library/community center in Makuleke, South Africa and Gwelutshena, Zimbabwe</li>
		<li>Sresht Rengesh (Course 6 and 3, 2015): Travel to Madrid to partipicate in the IAP Madrid Program (Spanish II)</li>
		<li>Amy Riley (Course 6, 2014): Attend MIT's 2014 IAP-in-Ancient &amp; Medieval Italy program</li>
		<li>Tasha Schoenstein (Course 18, 2016): Travel to Florence to take an intensive 3 week art history course called Art in Context</li>
		<li>Shruti Sharma (Course 3, 2015): Travel to Madrid to partipicate in the IAP Madrid Program (Spanish II)</li>
		<li>Alicia Singham Goodwin (Course 18 and WGS, 2014): Travel to Kara, Togo to implement sustainable computer literacy training for an HIV clinic</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">IAP 2012-2013 </h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Adwoa Boakye (Course 6.2, 2013): To work with Professor Aleta Hayes and dancer Katharine Hawthorne at Stanford University on performance and a collaborative paper</li>
		<li>Amita Gupta (Course 10B, 2015): Will study Spanish II over IAP in Madrid</li>
		<li>Christian Londoño (Course 6, 2014): To take an arts, history, and cultures course with Wellesley in Barcelona</li>
		<li>Victoria McCrave (Course 16, 2014): To travel to Italy as part of IAP History program</li>
		<li>Emily Perritt (Course 7, 2014): Travel with MIT History's ancient and medieval studies to Italy to experience Greek, Roman, and Medieval archeology</li>
		<li>Elizabeth Shanahan (Course 7, 2015): Humanitarian trip to Kara, Togo to implement computer literacy training in clinics in an HIV positive community</li>
		<li>Alexandra Wassenberg (Course 16, 2014): To study Greek, Roman, and Medieval architecture, urban development, society, and politics in Italy</li>
		<li>Yiliu Zhang (Course 17, 2013): To study cities in ancient and medieval Italy in terms of their political development </li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">IAP 2011-2012</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Hamsika Chandrasekar (Course 9, Course 6-7, 2013): Provide infant mortality prevention to nurses and doctors at the Shamiaji Tribal Hospital in Gujurat, India</li>
		<li>Deborah Hanus (Course 6, 2012): To travel to Cambodia to implement a series of workshops teaching women iterative design and critical thinking via engineering</li>
		<li>Danny Katz (Course 5, Course 15, 2012): To study Spanish as part of the IAP-Madrid Program</li>
		<li>Laura Stilwell (Course 20, 2014): To study Spanish II in Madrid as part of the IAP-Madrid program</li>
		<li>Meng Heng Touch (Course 8, Course 16, 2012): To travel to Cambodia with the D-lab Cambodia team to develop and bring new technologies to small communities on the floating village.   </li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">Spring 2011</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Linda Chen (Physics and Philosophy, 2012): For ancient Greek philosophy study abroad program in Turkey</li>
		<li>Kayla Meduna (Electrical Engineering &amp; Computer Science / Materials Science &amp; Engineering, 2013): Intermediate Czech language study and culture course in Prague</li>
		<li>Meng Heng Touch (Physics / Aeronautics and Astronautics, 2012): To execute a photography project of European architecture</li>
		<li>Aditi Verma (Nuclear Engineering, 2012): Self Study of French 3 through Traveling and Cultural Immersion</li>
		<li>Evelyn Wang (Biology, 2012): Internship at Shanghai Children's Medical Center</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">Fall 2010</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Stacey Allen (Economics, 2011): IAP Madrid program to study Spanish</li>
		<li>Xenia Antipova (Architecture, 2013): To assist the resource and advertising of Habitat para la Humanidad Columbia and attend Spanish language classes</li>
		<li>Kimee Boonbanjerdsri (Architecture, 2012): The "Veneto Experience" Architectural Study in Venice Italy</li>
		<li>Corinne Carland (Chemical Engineering, 2013): Travel to Madrid to participate in an intensive lauguage course</li>
		<li>Dorota Chapko (Brain &amp; Cognitive Science / Anthropology, 2012): To work in Anchorage Neighborhood Health Center</li>
		<li>Lila Fridley (Chemical Engineering, 2013): To attend intensive Spanish language classes and immersion in Madrid</li>
		<li>Dora Gao (Physics, 2011): Spend eight days in Rome studying Augustan Propaganda for senior thesis research</li>
		<li>Carolyne Gathinji (Economics, 2011): IAP Madrid to study Spanish II</li>
		<li>Bethany Patten (Architecture, 2011): Working with children in rural Guatemala through arts education</li>
		<li>Nathan Robert (Mechanical Engineering, 2013): IAP Madrid to study Spanish II</li>
		<li>Melissa Showers (Mechanical Engineering, 2013): Travel to Rome to experience ancient and modern Italian culture</li>
		<li>Christopher Su (History / Biology, 2011): To investigate the role of educational programs in WWII Japanese-American internment centers</li>
		<li>Anna Waldman-Brown (Physics/W&amp;HS, 2011): To explore Icelandic culture for thesis</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">Fall 2009</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Biafra Ahanonu (Brain &amp; Cognitive Science, 2012): To study Spanish II in Madrid through the IAP-Madrid Program</li>
		<li>Jeremiah Edwards (Mathematics, 2010): To study Spanish II in Madrid through the IAP-Madrid Program</li>
		<li>Styliani Gaitani (Mathematics, 2010): Attend production week of "Puntilla and His Man Matti" at the Theatre Augsburg in Germany</li>
		<li>Alina Griner (Economics, 2010): Attend production week of "Puntilla and His Man Matti" at the Theatre Augsburg in Germany</li>
		<li>Rebecca Heywood (Civil and Environmental Engineering, 2012): To participate in a joint course on Energy, Water, and the Environment in Brazil</li>
		<li>Seohyung Kim (Literature / Mathematics, 2010): Travel to South Korea for study of Korean poetry and translation</li>
		<li>Irene Lee (Management, 2010): Travel to Taiwan in order to document the experiences of Chinese civil war veterans who fled from China to Taiwan for political asylum</li>
		<li>Leah Nation (Materials Science and Engineering, 2011): Travel to Ghana to test ceramic water filters and perform training sessions</li>
		<li>Alice Nawfal (Economics / Mathematics, 2011): To study Spanish II in Madrid through the IAP-Madrid Program</li>
		<li>Robert Slater (Aeronautics and Astronautics, 2011): To study Spanish II in Madrid through the IAP-Madrid Program</li>
		<li>Praveen Subramani (Urban Studies and Planning, 2010): To research the potentiality of new mobility systems to improve the quality of life of migrant workers in Dubai</li>
		<li>Mahesh K. Vidula (Biological Engineering, 2011): To develop culturally-sensative cardiovascular health education in Shamirpet, India</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

	<h4 class="dotted">Fall 2008</h4>

	<p> </p>

	<ul><li>Jose Barcena (Course 3, 2010): To participate in a German Language course at the Freie Universität, Berlin</li>
		<li>Jodie-Marie Fernandes (Course 6, 2009): To attend a programme for classical musicians at Peppardine University</li>
		<li>Brooke Jarrett (Course 1A, 2010): To work with Adam Talsma on a collaborative project</li>
		<li>Diana Jue (Course 11, 2009): For travel to China to work with the Nest of Hope Foundation's orphanage &amp; vocational school</li>
		<li>Seohyung Kim (Courses 21L and 18, 2010): For travel to London to work with the literary arts community outreach program "Spread the Word"</li>
		<li>Amy Leung (Course 10, 2010): To travel to China for the Synergy Programme's Silk Road Tour and reunion conference</li>
		<li>Yusing Li (Course4, 2010) and James Ira Winder (Course 4, 2010): For travel to northern Italy with the Veneto experience program, and explore the architecture of Carlo Scarpa</li>
		<li>Christie Lin (Course 22, 2011): To understand the culture of Texas through culinary investigation</li>
		<li>Richard Prevost (Course 10, 2011): To travel with the Dana Tai Soon Burgess &amp; Company dance company in Peru</li>
		<li>Sukrit Ranjan (Course 8, 2010): To participate in an archaeological dig in Mozia, Italy</li>
		<li>Adam Talsma (Course 1, 2010): To make a documentary on the experiences of a disaster stricken region of Peru</li>
		<li>Jingwen Tao (Course 15, 2009): To participate in the Hong Kong University Summer Program "Asia as the Global Future"</li>
		<li>Elizabeth Theurer (Course 2 and 18): To research optimizing factories for recycling electronic waste in the United States and Chile</li>
	</ul><p> </p>

            <article id="node-705" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly-Douglas Fund<br /><strong>The Kelly Essay Prize for Excellence in Humanistic Scholarship</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h2><br /><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_eightlegged_essay.jpg" width="585" /></h2>

<h3><br /><br />
	Deadlines for 2017-2018 will be announced soon</h3>

<p><br /><br /><b><span>Honoring outstanding achievement in non-fiction writing</span></b><br /><br />
	To acknowledge outstanding achievement by undergraduate students intellectually committed to fields of study that fall under the purview of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT, the Kelly-Douglas Fund awards two prizes of up to $800 each to the best essays in any field of study within SHASS.<br /><br />
	Beginning this year the Kelly-Douglas Fund has restructured the terms of the annual Kelly Essay Prize to admit a wider range of student essay submissions than in years past. For this year’s competition, all forms of non-fiction prose are eligible for consideration. In addition to submitting research essays written for SHASS subjects in any of the fields above, students may submit works of 12-20 pages in these genres: personal essays, memoir, cultural commentary, creative non-fiction, travel writing, field reports, and science journalism.<br /><br /><br /><b>Faculty Role</b><br /><br />
	The Kelly Essay Prize is distinctive in being the only SHASS writing award open to all students engaged in HASS-related studies, with no further restriction on topic and content. Faculty are encouraged to identify high-quality undergraduate essays written for courses they offer, and help students develop them for submission to the essay competition.  <br /><br /><span><b>Deadline </b></span><br /><br /><span style="color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-size: 11px; line-height: 15.455999374389648px;">Deadlines for 2017-2018 will be announced soon</span><span> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"> <br /><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay-prize/application" target="_blank"><strong>Application Process</strong></a><br />
	 </p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><em><span>Top Image: Detail, The Eight-legged Essay (Ba Gu Wen)<br />
	The eight-legged essay was a style of essay writing that had to be mastered to pass the imperial examinations during the Ming and Qing Dynasties. It is named so because it was divided into eight sections.</span></em></p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

            <article id="node-738" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly-Douglas Fund<br /><strong>Kelly Essay Prize | Application</strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="150" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/150_eightlegged_essay.jpg" width="585" /></p>

<p> </p>

<p><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay" target="_blank">Also see the main Kelly Essay Prize page</a>  <br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Eligibility</strong><br /><br />
	Any full time MIT undergraduate — with the exception of previous winners of a Kelly Essay Prize — may submit an essay written during his or her years at MIT.  The work may have been conceived for an MIT subject. Contestants are encouraged to consult with appropriate members of the faculty while preparing his or her submission (naturally, any assistance received should be acknowledged in the essay).<br /><br /><br /><b><strong>Format</strong></b><br /><br />
	Essays may range from 12-20 double-spaced pages, with standard one inch margins. A group of shorter papers, a translation, a work of creative fiction, or a study exceeding 20 pages (exclusive of notes and bibliography) will not be considered.</p>

<p>Beginning this year the Kelly-Douglas Fund has restructured the terms of the annual Kelly Essay Prize to admit a wider range of student essay submissions than in years past.<span> </span>For this year’s competition, all forms of non-fiction prose in the 12-20 page range are eligible for consideration.<span> </span>In addition to submitting research essays written for HASS subjects, students may submit personal essays, memoir, cultural commentary, creative non-fiction, travel writing, field reports, science journalism, etc.<span>  </span></p>

<p><br /><strong>Submitting an Essay for Consideration</strong><br /><br />
	Applicants must submit two unstapled copies of the essay. These must be accompanied by an <span class="MsoHyperlink"><a href="/files/shass/cfile/inside/3.KELLY_DOUGLAS_FUND_ESSAY_FORM.pdf" target="_blank">Entry Form which you can download here</a></span>.</p>

<p>The author's name should appear <em>only</em> on the entry form, since submissions are read without the Committee knowing the author's name. The title of the essay should be entered on both the entry form and on the first page of the essay.</p>

<p>Submissions should be delivered or mailed to the following address:</p>

<p>The Director | Kelly-Douglas Fund, Essay Prize <br />
	c/o Benjamin Kemp, Fund Administrator       <br />
	Literature Section<br /><a href="http://whereis.mit.edu/map-jpg?selection=14">14N</a>-407 MIT<br />
	77 Massachusetts Ave<br />
	Cambridge MA 02139<br /><br /><br /><strong>Judging</strong><br /><br />
	Entries are judged by a panel drawn from the different faculties within SHASS, who read each essay without knowing the author's name, On occasion, the total prize money — usually split between two winners — may be divided among three deserving essays, in a proportion to be decided by the Committee for that year. Prize winners are notified in late April.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>For additional information </strong><strong>visit the </strong><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/essay" target="_blank"><strong>main prize page.</strong></a><strong> </strong></p>

<p><strong><span class="MsoHyperlink"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/KELLY-DOUGLAS-FUND-ESSAY-COVER-SHEET.pdf" target="_blank">Download </a></span></strong><span class="MsoHyperlink"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/KELLY-DOUGLAS-FUND-ESSAY-COVER-SHEET.pdf" target="_blank">| </a></span><strong><span class="MsoHyperlink"><a href="/files/shass/cfile/inside/KELLY-DOUGLAS-FUND-ESSAY-COVER-SHEET.pdf" target="_blank">Entry Form Cover Sheet</a></span></strong></p>

<p><strong><!--EndFragment--> </strong></p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-704" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly-Douglas Fund <strong>| </strong><strong>FAQs</strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><br /><br /><br /><strong>Can I get a travel advance if I have been granted financial support by the Kelly-Douglas Fund?</strong></p>

<p>No. All disbursements of travel take place after completion of travel. Receipts detailing expenditures must be submitted for reimbursement. Please keep copies of all receipts.</p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>If I am not sure whether I am eligible to apply for a travelling fellowship, how do I find out?</strong></p>

<p>Email or phone the Fund Director (see the <a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/about" target="_blank">Contact Us </a>page).</p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>My recommender is not in town or will not be able to get the evaluation in by the deadline. What should I do?</strong></p>

<p>Submit your portion of the application by the deadline, but email the Fund Director to explain the reason for the delay and attach a note to the application indicating when the recommendation will arrive. Note that recommendations must be received before the Board meets to deliberate on your proposal, and an application is not considered complete until the recommendation has arrived.</p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>I am graduating Senior. Can I apply for a Travelling Fellowship?</strong></p>

<p>Only for the IAP of your senior year. You may not apply for support for travel to be undertaken in the Summer immediately after graduation.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>I am a first-year student. Can I apply for a Travelling Fellowship?</strong></p>

<p>Only if you have already been granted sophomore standing at the time of application.<br />
	 </p>

<p><br /><strong>Can I get to read essays that have won the Kelly Essay Prize in the past?</strong></p>

<p>Yes. Winning essays from past years are available in the Institute Archives (14N-118).</p>

<p><br /><br /><strong>Can I receive funds to attend a conference where I am not presenting a paper?</strong></p>

<p>No. Travel funds require that you be a full participant in the conference and that the activity contribute to your career and educational trajectory.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>May I apply for the Kelly Douglas Fund after the conference/event has happened? </strong></p>

<p>No, all applications must be submitted prior to the event. The Kelly-Douglas Fund is unable to retroactively reimburse any candidate. </p>

<p> </p>

<p><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_k-d-faq.jpg" width="180" /> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

  </div><!-- divnodecontent -->

</article><!-- node-704 -->
