        <div id="divcontent" role="main">

          
            <article id="node-702" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly Douglas Fund<br /><strong>Research and Teaching Grants </strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="250" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/585_woman_library.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	 </p>

<h3><br /><strong>How the Fund works </strong></h3>

<p><br />
	The Kelly-Douglas Fund allocates a part of its annual budget to support teaching and research by members of MIT's School of Humanities, Arts and Social Sciences. These funds are distributed on a rolling basis each semester. Since the Fund is a small one and seeks to assist as many deserving projects as possible, grants are typically modest: no individual may receive more than $500 in a given academic year, and a majority of grants awarded are for smaller amounts.<br /><br />
	In general, faculty and students who are part of the School of Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences are given first preference. Nonetheless, applications from outside the domain of HASS receive full consideration, as long as they engage intellectual concerns central to the disciplines comprising the School.  <br />
	 <br />
	 </p>

<h3><strong>Grants to support teaching</strong></h3>

<h3><br />
	 </h3>

<p><strong>Who may apply?</strong><br /><br />
	In general, the Fund accepts applications from graduate students and visiting faculty in SHASS, along with current lecturers who have not received funds from an alternative source.<br /><br /><br /><strong>What sorts of proposals are funded?</strong><br /><br />
	Teaching grants take a number of forms. In the past, the Fund has offered partial support for course-related field trips, museum fees, and, on occasion, the purchase of instructional material (on the condition that these do not revert to personal use at the end of the teaching period). The Fund has also regularly helped offset the costs of honoraria for guest lecturers, and subsidized tickets to take members of a class to see a performance. These examples are meant to be indicative of the kinds of activities the Fund supports; they do not exhaust the list of possibilities. Proposals are judged upon the merit of proposed activity and an assessment of their impact upon undergraduate learning.<br /><br /><strong>Are there any strings attached to these awards?</strong><br /><br />
	We expect the applicant's home department or section to demonstrate its commitment to the proposed endeavour: applicants are expected to seek and to receive some financial assistance from their home departments before applying the Kelly-Douglas Fund. The Board is aware that departmental resources vary across the School, and therefore does not set a quantitative minimum. It does, however, expect that a department or section will back the application to the best of its ability.</p>

<p>In general, the maximum an individual may apply for is $500 — though most grants are for lower amounts. Support to offset honoraria is capped at $200.</p>

<h3><br /><br /><strong>Grants to support research</strong><br /><br />
	 </h3>

<p><strong>Who may apply?</strong><br /><br />
	Research grants are limited to applicants whose access to other sources of funding is limited. Consequently, regular tenured and tenure-track faculty are not eligible for research grants. In general, the Fund accepts applications from current lecturers, visiting faculty and graduate students in SHASS.</p>

<p><br /><strong>What sorts of proposals are funded?</strong></p>

<p>Typically, the Fund subsidizes travel expenses (usually airfare) to conferences, as well to carry out research (for fieldwork or to consult libraries, archives and other repositories of information). The Fund does not contribute to expenses incurred for food or entertainment, or to equipment related to the research project. It has, on occasion, helped offset such costs as indexing services provided by a vendor — though it cannot pay individuals hired by the grantee.<br /><br /><strong>Any strings</strong><br /><br />
	The Kelly-Douglas Fund expects the applicant to apply to other sources as well. For conference-related travel in particular, the applicant is expected to receive some departmental support. This requirement is especially important in the case of graduate students: we assume that the primary responsibility for nurturing a graduate student's development rests with the home department, the Fund having consequently a supplementary function. Conference travel is only funded if the applicant is actually presenting a paper — the Fund does not pay simply to attend a conference.</p>

<p>The maximum an individual may receive each year is $500.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_k-d-research.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p> </p>

        <!-- page content -->
        <div id="divcontent" role="main">

          
            <article id="node-703" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly Douglas Fund<br /><strong>Research and Teaching Grants | Application Process</strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h3><br /><img alt="" height="130" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x130_woman_library.jpg" style="font-size: 0.92em;" width="585" /></h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3><br /><strong>Deadlines</strong><br /><br />
	 </h3>

<p>The Kelly-Douglas Fund offers research and travel support awards twice a year on a rolling basis. Each semester it distributes funds until the limit for that semester has been reached. Any unused funds from one term are transferred over to the succeeding term. Once the limit for a particular semester has been reached, the Fund will cease to accept applications for that semester and an announcement will be posted on the Fund's home page.</p>

<p>For all travel and research to be completed by <strong>January 31st</strong>, applicants may turn in requests starting on <strong>August 1</strong> of that calendar year.</p>

<p>For all travel and research to be completed by <strong>July 31st</strong>, applicants may turn in requests starting January 1st of that calendar year.<br />
	 <br />
	 </p>

<h3><strong>Summary of Application Process</strong><br />
	 </h3>

<ol><li>Download and Complete Cover Sheet</li>
	<li>Mail a hard copy of signed Cover Sheet and Letter of Request to the Administrator of the Fund</li>
	<li>If appropriate, arrange for a letter of recommendation to be mailed or emailed to the Director and the Fund Administrator.</li>
	<li>A response will be sent to you via email or interdepartmental mail.</li>
	<li>Contact Fund Administrator at the appropriate time, and turn in the Reimbursements form along with necessary receipts.<br /><br />
		 </li>
</ol><h3><strong>The Application in Detail</strong><br />
	 </h3>

<p>The Cover Sheet – <a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/kelly-support%20updated10.21.15.pdf" target="_blank">Download </a></p>

<p>Whether applying for a teaching or a research grant, the request must be accompanied by a signed cover sheet. Applications must be mailed as hard copy Fund Administrator (see address below). Please do <strong>not</strong> send your own application and cover sheet by email. (Recommenders may email their evaluations, however. See instructions below.)</p>

<p>Apart from the usual information (name, contact information etc.), the cover sheet asks for the following:</p>

<ul><li>A <strong>brief description</strong> of the project (no more than a couple of sentences indicating the purpose of the application).</li>
	<li>A <strong>concise budget</strong> for the whole project. This should outline specific expenses (travel, lodging, and so on), and specify what part of the sum would be paid by the Kelly-Douglas Fund, assuming the application is successful.</li>
	<li>A <strong>concise summary of other sources</strong> to which you are also applying for support (such as the Department or Section, the Dean's Office, NEH etc). If you have already been awarded support, indicate the amount you have received (or will receive). Remember that the Fund is a modest one, and do not pad your application. Failure to disclose other sources of funding may result in the Fund's grant being revoked.</li>
	<li>Finally, all graduate students applying for research or conference-related support must indicate the name and email address of a <strong>recommender</strong>.<br />
		 </li>
</ul><h3><br /><strong>Letter of Request</strong><br />
	 </h3>

<p>Requests for funding should be outlined in a brief letter that clearly describes the proposed project. <strong>The letter should not exceed one single-spaced typed page.</strong></p>

<p>What the letter says will depend, of course, on the project itself. For instance, a letter applying for an honorarium for a guest lecturer should provide the tentative title or topic of the lecture and briefly summarize the speaker's expertise and accomplishments in so far as they are relevant to the invitation. It should also tell us about the proposed audience — MIT subject number(s), size of class(es), whether open to the public or limited to students in a class, and so on — and convey the applicant's sense of how the planned event will contribute to the education of the listeners.</p>

<p>An application for a research grant would, by contrast, cogently describe the applicant's field of study and specify the particular purpose served by this grant (should the application be successful). For conference travel, please provide details about the conference, including the title and subject of your paper.<br />
	 </p>

<h3><strong>Recommendations</strong><br />
	 </h3>

<p>In general, recommendations are not required for teaching-related grants.</p>

<p>For research-related travel, students are required to arrange for one letter of recommendation from a person who is able to speak knowledgeably about the student's research and merit. Normally, the endorsement would come from a thesis advisor, a member of the dissertation committee, or departmental or sectional head. Lecturers are not required to submit a letter of endorsement. However, a brief statement of support from the departmental or sectional head will strengthen the application.</p>

<p>The recommendation need not physically accompany the application — if it does, it should be in a separate sealed envelope — and can be mailed or emailed independently to the address below. Note that an application will not be considered until the recommendation has been received by the Fund Administrator.<br />
	 </p>

<h3><br /><strong>To whom should applications be sent?</strong><br />
	 </h3>

<p>All applications, consisting of a signed cover sheet and a letter of request, should be sent to the following address (if using interdepartmental mail, the street and city information can obviously be omitted).</p>

<p>The Director, Kelly-Douglas Fund,<br />
	c/o Benjamin Kemp, Fund Administrator<br />
	Literature Section<br />
	14N-407 MIT<br />
	77 Massachusetts Ave<br />
	Cambridge MA 02139</p>

<p>Recommendations can also be mailed to the same address, or emailed to both the current Director, Shankar Raman (<a href="mailto:sram@mit.edu?subject=Kelly%20Douglas%20Fund">sram@mit.edu</a>) and to the Fund Administrator, Benjamin Kemp (<a href="mailto:benkemp@mit.edu">benkemp@mit.edu</a>).<br />
	 <br />
	 </p>

<h3><strong>When do I hear back and how do I receive the funds?</strong></h3>

<p><br />
	Once your application is complete, your request will reviewed and you will receive a response as swiftly as possible. If you are the recipient of an award, please contact the Fund Administrator after your travel, to turn in the <a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/kelly-reimbursement.pdf" target="_blank">Reimbursements</a> form and your receipts.</p>

<p>Please note that all travel and research grants are only paid out upon completion of the proposed project, and recipients need to provide receipts and evidence of completion before funds can be released. Always keep copies of any receipts you submit.</p>

<p>Certain types of activities may be paid for in advance. For instance, honoraria and support to take students to a performance can be received before the event. In such cases, the recipient should arrange with the Fund Administrator to have the money transferred internally to the departmental or sectional account responsible for the actual disbursement of funds. A brief confirmation that the funds have been expended for the purpose for which they were awarded should subsequently be sent to the Director or the Fund Administrator.</p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

                  <!-- default block template -->
<nav id="block-shasstools-shassmenusection" class="block block-shasstools block-menu-secondary" role="navigation" aria-label="section-wide navigation">

  
  <ul class="menu"><li class="first last expanded active-trail"><a href="/academics" class="active-trail active-trail">Academics</a><ul class="menu"><li class="first expanded active-trail"><a href="/academics/undergraduate" class="active-trail active-trail">Undergraduate Studies</a><ul class="menu"><li class="first leaf"><a href="/undergraduate/tour">Take the TOUR de SHASS</a></li>

            <article id="node-707" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly-Douglas Fund<br /><strong>Travel Fellowships for IAP and Summer </strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h2><img alt="" height="260" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x260_Sarek_Flower_path.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	 <br /><br /><br /><strong>Travel Fellowship applications </strong><br />
	Deadlines for 2017-2018 will be announced soon</h2>

<p><br /><b>The power of travel </b><br /><br />
	An important dimension of the Kelly-Douglas Fund is the support for and encouragement of undergraduate education in the humanities, arts and social sciences. We believe that travel outside MIT to pursue an independent project in a HASS field, or to collaborate in a humanitarian project, can have a powerful and lasting effect on students. To this end, a portion of the Fund is reserved for Traveling Fellowships for MIT pursuing an endeavor of their own devising either during IAP or the Summer.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Who can apply?</strong><br /><br />
	All MIT sophomores, juniors, and seniors wishing to travel during IAP or Summer to deepen their understanding of a field in the humanities, arts, and social sciences, or to contribute to a humanitarian project are eligible to apply. Students need not belong to the School of HASS, though majors and minors in the School will be given preference.</p>

<p>Please note that first-year students are NOT eligible to apply unless they have already been granted sophomore status at the time of application. Seniors may only apply to travel in the IAP of their final year, and are NOT eligible for grants for the summer following graduation.<br /><br /><br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/kelly-douglas/traveling/application"><strong>About the Undergraduate Travel Application Process</strong></a><br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>How much support does the Fund provide?</strong><br /><br />
	The maximum level of support offered by the Fund is $1500. However, since the Board seeks to assist as many students as possible, grants are often for smaller amounts. The grants are competitively awarded: decisions on funding are reached based upon an assessment both of the proposal's intrinsic merit, and the demonstrated financial need. It is expected that students will also seek supplementary funds - either personal or from some other source. All other potential sources need to be disclosed on the application. In the event that a student receives substantial funding from an outside source (such as the Eloranta), he or she will not be considered for a financial award from the Kelly-Douglas Fund.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>What sorts of activities does the Fund support?</strong><br /><br />
	The Kelly-Douglas Fund has assisted a range of efforts. Students have been awarded grants to carry out archival and library research, or to conduct interview and gather data for independent projects. Others have applied for and received some support to travel abroad to study intensively a language that will be of use in their future careers. The Fund has further supported travel to take courses not available at MIT or to develop skills in the performing arts and music. It has also helped realise humanitarian projects in small communities in Africa and Asia. This list is by no means exhaustive. A list of current winners and a brief description of their projects may be found on the Award Recipients page of this website.</p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

            <article id="node-708" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Kelly-Douglas Fund<br /><strong>Traveling Fellowships | Application Process</strong></h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <h3><img alt="" height="130" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/585x130_Sarek_Flower_path.jpg" width="585" /></h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3> </h3>

<h3>Deadlines<br />
	 </h3>

<p>There are two competitions each year, one for travel during IAP and the other for travel during the Summer.</p>

<p> </p>

<h3>Application Overview<br />
	 </h3>

<ol><li>Download and complete Cover Sheet.</li>
	<li>Send hard copy of signed Cover Sheet and Application to the Fund Administrator.</li>
	<li>Arrange for one letter of recommendation, addressed to the Director, to be sent to the Fund Administrator.</li>
	<li>Decisions will be made and communicated (by email) in early December for IAP applications and by the end of April for Summer applications.</li>
	<li>Applicants will contact the Fund Administrator thereafter to confirm acceptance. After completion of travel, please turn in the <a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/kelly-reimbursement.pdf" target="_blank">Reimbursements</a> form along with receipts.</li>
</ol><p> </p>

<h3>The Cover Sheet<br />
	 </h3>

<p>Download the <a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/kelly-support%20travelling%20fellowship.pdf" target="_blank">cover sheet</a>.</p>

<p>In addition to contact and student status information, the Cover Sheet requires the following:</p>

<ul><li><strong>A brief description</strong> of the proposed project (no more than a sentence or two).</li>
	<li><strong>A detailed budget</strong> that estimates the cost of the proposed travel in terms of transportation, lodging, and other expenses. The budget should also indicate what portions of the travel costs are to be funded by the Kelly-Douglas Fund, should the application be successful.</li>
	<li><strong>Alternative and supplementary sources of funding being sought</strong>, and amounts already received, if any. A full disclosure is necessary. Failure to do so may result in the revocation of a grants awarded.</li>
	<li><strong>Name and email</strong> contact information of a <strong>recommender</strong>.</li>
</ul><p> </p>

<h3>The Application</h3>

<p>The Application should describe cogently the nature of the travel proposed, its reasons and goals, as well as provide a summary of the planned itinerary. It should also make clear either its relation to a field in the humanities, arts and social sciences, or — in the case of travel for humanitarian reasons — the desired impact upon the community the student intends to aid. The Application should not exceed two single-spaced typed pages in length, though applicants are permitted to attach brief appendices to the application (should that seem necessary).<br />
	 </p>

<h3>Recommendations</h3>

<p>Students should arrange for a letter of evaluation, addressed to the Fund Director, to be sent to the Fund Administrator. The recommender should be an instructor at MIT who is familiar with the applicant’s work, and can speak to the merits of the proposed project. Please note that applications will not be considered until the supporting letter has been received.<br />
	 </p>

<h3>Submitting the Application</h3>

<p>Please send a hard copy of your application to the following address (if using interdepartmental mail, the street and city information can obviously be omitted)<br /><br />
	   Attn: The Director, Kelly-Douglas Fund,<br />
	   c/o Benjamin Kemp, Fund Administrator<br />
	   Literature Section<br />
	   14N-407 MIT<br />
	   77 Massachusetts Ave<br />
	   Cambridge MA 02139</p>

<p>Applications may <strong>not</strong> be submitted by email.<br />
	 </p>

<h3><br /><strong>When do I hear back and how do I get the money?</strong></h3>

<p>Once your application is complete, your request will reviewed by the Board and you will receive a response as swiftly as possible – by early December for IAP requests and by end April for Summer requests. If you are the recipient of an award, please contact the Fund Administrator after your travel, to turn in the <a href="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/kelly-reimbursement.pdf" target="_blank">Reimbursements</a> form and your receipts.</p>

<p>Please note that all travel and research grants are usually paid out upon completion of the proposed project, and recipients are be required to provide receipts and evidence of completion before funds are released. Always keep copies of any receipts you submit. </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    </div><!-- divcontentcolumn -->

            <article id="node-681" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>The Palitz Fellowship<br /><strong>Summer Study in The Hague, Netherlands</strong><br /><br /><em><strong>for MIT students who are freshmen, sophomores, or juniors<br />
	at the time of application</strong></em><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/inside/Palitz_email_horiz_2017.jpg" style="width:590px;height:321px;" /></p>

<p><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>The Palitz Fellowship in The Hague</strong> is an exciting new research and international education opportunity for MIT undergraduate students.</span></p>

<p><span class="largerx2">The 6-month term as a Palitz Fellow includes the Spring semester in preparation with a faculty supervisor, followed by summer study in The Hague, with access to the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis.</span></p>

<p><span class="largerx2">Areas of study can include any aspect of history, art, or culture in the Dutch and Flemish Golden Age, for example: history of science, horticulture, or cartography; the art market; economic history; or the technologies of print making and book production.</span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Scope</strong><br /><br />
	Six-month term as an MIT Palitz Fellow: Spring semester in preparation with a faculty supervisor, followed by a program of summer research and study in The Hague, Netherlands, with access to the Royal Picture Gallery Mauritshuis. </p>

<p><br /><strong>Who may apply?</strong></p>

<p>• Students must be freshmen, sophomores, or juniors at the time of application.</p>

<p>• Students must be American citizens. </p>

<p>• Preference will be given to students who have some background in the subject areas of the Fellowship; note that areas of study can include any aspect of history, art, or culture in the Dutch and Flemish Golden Age, for example: history of science, horticulture, or cartography; the art market; economic history; or the technologies of print making and book production.</p>

<p>• Students will work with the Director of the Fellowship in the spring term to learn more about the history and culture of the Netherlands, and to prepare for a cultural exchange.</p>

<p>• On completion of the Fellowship, the student will present two oral reports on the experience and the research findings — one to the Friends of the Mauritshuis in the Netherlands, and another in the fall to the American Friends of the Mauritshuis in New York.  </p>

<p> <br /><strong>Research Areas</strong><br /><br />
	Areas of study can include any aspect of painting, history, or culture in the Dutch and Flemish Golden Age, for example: the art market; economic history; history of science, horticulture or cartography; or the technologies of print making and book production. The student is expected to relate the research in some way to the Mauritshuis collection.</p>

<p><br /><strong>Application process</strong></p>

<h3>Applications will be due in February 2018</h3>

<p><br />
	By [Date to Come] submit a packet containing the following application materials:</p>

<p>• MIT transcript</p>

<p>• One page resume</p>

<p>• Proposal (1000 word maximum) that explains the area of research you wish to pursue in The Hague, with an emphasis on some aspect of Dutch art, culture, or history in the Golden Age. This should include any previous relevant experience in this area that you may have had.  <br /><br />
	• Two letters of recommendation, at least one of which must come from an MIT faculty member, speaking to your academic record</p>

<p><br /><strong>Application Process </strong>| <strong> Submit packet by email </strong></p>

<p>• Make sure all application pieces are complete and included in your email. </p>

<p>• Identify your packet in the email subject line as: Palitz Fellowship Application.</p>

<p>• Email your completed packet to Margo Collett: <a href="mailto:mcollett@mit.edu?subject=Palitz%20Fellowship%20Application">mcollett@mit.edu</a></p>

<p><br /><strong>If you have questions, please contact:  </strong><br />
	Margo Collett<br />
	Administrative Assistant | History <br />
	617-253-4965<br /><a href="mailto:mcollett@mit.edu?subject=Palitz%20Fellowship%20Application">mcollett@mit.edu</a><br />
	 </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

        <!-- page content -->
        <div id="divcontent" role="main">

          
            <article id="node-217" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>MIT Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa<br /><strong>Xi of Massachusetts</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" height="220" src="/files/shass/cimg/magazine/2014/02/585_PBK-insignia.jpg" width="585" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><strong>Founded in 1776</strong><br /><br />
	“Five students at the College of William &amp; Mary founded Phi Beta Kappa in 1776, during the American Revolution. For over two and a quarter centuries, the Society has embraced the principles of freedom of inquiry and liberty of thought and expression.” It continues to honor the nation’s most outstanding undergraduate students for excellence in the liberal arts and sciences.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Best of the Best </strong><br /><br />
	Only about ten percent of the nation’s institutions of higher education have been selected to have Phi Beta Kappa chapters, and only ten percent or fewer of the students in these schools are selected for Phi Beta Kappa membership.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Xi of Massachusetts</strong><br /><br />
	MIT’s own chapter, Xi of Massachusetts, annually elects approximately 75 students in their senior year of undergraduate study. Students do not apply for membership. Election is conducted by a faculty committee, which reviews the academic records of seniors to find students with superlative records and clear evidence of breadth in the liberal arts.<br /><br />
	Several mechanical criteria may be of interest to you in choosing HASS and related subjects. Phi Beta Kappa members must have two years of a foreign language in college, three years in high school, a combination thereof, or be a native speaker of a language other than English. Majors in engineering must show clear evidence of depth and breadth in their selection of HASS and related courses. Generally, members will have more than the required eight HASS courses.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>The Phi Beta Kappa Induction Ceremony at MIT</strong></p>

<p>In early June each year, on the afternoon before MIT’s annual Commencement exercises, our Phi Beta Kappa chapter holds an induction ceremony to honor our newest members in front of their family and friends. The President, Historian, and Guide of our chapter, all MIT Faculty members, preside over this event, which begins with a scholarly lecture by an MIT professor on a topic of broad intellectual interest. Recent speakers have discussed reform of the voting system in the United States, and the size and nature of the physical universe.<br /><br />
	After the lecture, the Historian and Guide provide a brief introduction to the rights and responsibilities of Phi Beta Kappa members. The newest inductees are then individually recognized and asked to sign the official register of the Xi of Massachusetts chapter. They are also taught the Phi Beta Kappa secret handshake, but strict Society regulations prohibit us from revealing its characteristics here!<o p=""></o><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><o p=""></o><br /><strong>Gallery of Speakers </strong><br />
	Speakers at the annual MIT PBK ceremony, with links to their websites <br /><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/scholarships/phi-beta-kappa/speakers" target="_blank">Gallery</a></p>

<p> </p>

<p><o p=""><strong>Photo Galleries from PBK Induction Ceremonies  </strong></o><o p=""></o></p>

<p><a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/great-ideas/sets/72157685696360745/" target="_blank">2017 ceremony </a><br /><br /><a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/great-ideas/albums/72157667091217103" target="_blank">2016 ceremony</a><o p=""><br /><br /><a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/great-ideas/sets/72157656571590235" target="_blank">2015 ceremony</a></o><br /><br /><a href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/great-ideas/sets/72157645110439835/page1" target="_blank">2014 ceremony</a><br />
	 </p>

<p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/pbk_2015_3.gif" style="width: 180px; height: 180px;" /><span>     </span><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/pbk_2015_2.gif" style="width: 180px; height: 180px;" /><span>     </span><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/pbk_2015_1.gif" style="width: 180px; height: 180px;" /><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><o p=""></o><br /><strong>Contact</strong><br />
	MIT Professor of History Jeffrey Ravel is President of the MIT Chapter of Phi Beta Kappa. For further information contact <a href="mailto:benard@mit.edu">Kimberly Benard</a>, Secretary of the Chapter, Room 12-189, (617) 253-4378.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><img alt="" height="180" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/180_pbk-key.jpg" width="180" /></p>

<p><strong>Suggested Links</strong></p>

<p><a href="https://www.pbk.org  " target="_blank">Phi Beta Kappa Society</a><br /><em>The Nation's Oldest Academic Honor Society</em><br /><br /><a href="http://theamericanscholar.org/" target="_blank">The American Scholar</a><br />
	Magazine of the Phi Beta Kappa Society</p>

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Take the TOUR de SHASS online<br /><strong>Explore </strong><strong>MIT's Humanities, Arts, and Social Science Fields</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/SHASS-SF-postcard-2017.gif" style="width: 590px; height: 422px;" /> <br /><br /><span class="largerx1">Join us each September for the TOUR de SHASS campus fair event. For a virtual tour online anytime, click on the photographs below for information about each of the MIT HASS fields.</span></p>

<p><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>2017 TOUR de SHASS event</strong></span><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>Thursday, September 7, 2017</strong><br />
	11:30am–1:30pm<br />
	Bush Room, 10-105</span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>Greetings Students </strong>— <br /><br />
	At MIT, we view the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (HASS) as essential, both for educating great engineers, scientists, thinkers, and citizens, and for sustaining the Institute’s capacity for innovation. From this page, you can take a virtual tour through the entire range of MIT's HASS fields of study and discover which options are the most meaningful for your goals.<em> </em>Get started by clicking on the photographs below.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Empowering</strong></p>

<p>All MIT HASS classes are designed to empower our students to succeed — to serve the world well, with innovations and lives that are rich in meaning and wisdom. In HASS studies and explorations, MIT students gain critical thinking and communication skills, cultural and historical perspectives, fluent language abilities, and knowledge about economic and political forces.<br /><br />
	In addition to the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/" target="_blank">MIT HASS requirement</a>, students can pursue a <a href="/undergraduate/majors" target="_blank">major</a> and/or a <a href="/undergraduate/minors" target="_blank">minor</a> in HASS fields, exploring interests that support, balance, or expand studies in MIT's STEM fields. All MIT HASS classes empower professional success, whatever one's major field, and open windows onto a lifetime of creativity and growth.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Annual TOUR de SHASS campus fair in September </strong><br /><br />
	Join us each September for the TOUR de SHASS campus fair. For a virtual tour online anytime, click on the photographs below for information about each of the MIT HASS fields.<br />
	 </p>

<table cellspacing="0" class="itemtable-200"><tbody><tr><td> </td>

Culture is a system of signs and practices through which humans interact and communicate."  <br /><em>— Susan Silbey, </em><em>Goldberg Professor of Humanities, and Professor of Sociology and Anthropology</em></span></p>

            <article id="node-2163" class="node node-lev3page">

  <div id="divnodecontent" class="nosidebar">

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Undergraduate Studies<br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/inside/590_MISTI-Students.jpg" style="width: 590px; height: 318px;" /></p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><strong>100% of MIT undergraduates study the humanities, arts, and social sciences.</strong>   </span></p>

<h4> </h4>

<p><span class="largerx2">The MIT SHASS disciplines — the humanities, arts, and social sciences — are central to the Institute's mission to provide all graduates with the knowledge, skills, and perspectives to make lasting contributions to the nation and the world.<br /><br />
	All MIT undergraduates spend substantial time on subjects like literature, languages, economics, music, political science, and history. In fact, every MIT undergraduate takes a minimum of eight such classes — about 25% of the total class time.<br /><br />
	For an online overview of the HASS options and fields of study at MIT: </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/tour" target="_blank"><strong>Take the TOUR de SHASS</strong></a></span><br /><br /><br /><span class="largerx2">Explore the following pages for more information and ideas:  </span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="/news/news-2014-power-of-humanities-arts-social-sciences-at-mit" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Power of the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences at MIT</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/hass" target="_blank">The HASS Requirement</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/comm-requirement" style="font-size: 0.92em;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Communication Requirement</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/majors" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Majors</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/minors" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Minors</span></a><br /><br /><a class="external" href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/concentrations.html" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Concentrations</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/joint" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Joint Degrees</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/interdisciplinary" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Interdisciplinary Programs</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/harvard" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">The Harvard/MIT Cross-Registration Program</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><br /><span class="largerx2"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/classes" target="_blank">Introductory Classes</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/news" style="font-size: 11px;" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">HASS Exploration Subjects</span></a><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/courses-on-diversity-related-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS Diversity Subjects</span></a></span><br /><br /><span class="largerx2"><a href="http://shass.mit.edu/undergraduate/programs/courses-current-issues" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">SHASS classes related to current U.S. social, political, and economic issues</span></a></span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p><span class="largerx2"><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">FAQs</span></a><br /><br /><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;"><a href="/undergraduate/scholarships" target="_blank">Student Awards and Opportunities</a></span><br /><br /><a href="/undergraduate/office" target="_blank"><span class="largerx1" style="font-size: 12px;">Contacts for Information + Assistance</span></a></span></p>

<p> </p>

<p><br /><br />
	 </p>
      </div><!-- maintext -->

    <div id="divcontenttitle">

              <h1>Take the TOUR de SHASS online<br /><strong>Explore </strong><strong>MIT's Humanities, Arts, and Social Science Fields</strong><br />
	 </h1>
      
    </div><!-- divcontenttitle -->

    <div id="divcontentcolumn">

      <div class="maintext">
        <p><img alt="" src="/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/SHASS-SF-postcard-2017.gif" style="width: 590px; height: 422px;" /> <br /><br /><span class="largerx1">Join us each September for the TOUR de SHASS campus fair event. For a virtual tour online anytime, click on the photographs below for information about each of the MIT HASS fields.</span></p>

<p><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>2017 TOUR de SHASS event</strong></span><br /><span class="largerx1"><strong>Thursday, September 7, 2017</strong><br />
	11:30am–1:30pm<br />
	Bush Room, 10-105</span><br />
	 </p>

<hr /><p> </p>

<p><strong>Greetings Students </strong>— <br /><br />
	At MIT, we view the Humanities, Arts, and Social Sciences (HASS) as essential, both for educating great engineers, scientists, thinkers, and citizens, and for sustaining the Institute’s capacity for innovation. From this page, you can take a virtual tour through the entire range of MIT's HASS fields of study and discover which options are the most meaningful for your goals.<em> </em>Get started by clicking on the photographs below.<br />
	 </p>

<p><strong>Empowering</strong></p>

<p>All MIT HASS classes are designed to empower our students to succeed — to serve the world well, with innovations and lives that are rich in meaning and wisdom. In HASS studies and explorations, MIT students gain critical thinking and communication skills, cultural and historical perspectives, fluent language abilities, and knowledge about economic and political forces.<br /><br />
	In addition to the <a href="http://web.mit.edu/hassreq/" target="_blank">MIT HASS requirement</a>, students can pursue a <a href="/undergraduate/majors" target="_blank">major</a> and/or a <a href="/undergraduate/minors" target="_blank">minor</a> in HASS fields, exploring interests that support, balance, or expand studies in MIT's STEM fields. All MIT HASS classes empower professional success, whatever one's major field, and open windows onto a lifetime of creativity and growth.<br /><br /><br /><strong>Annual TOUR de SHASS campus fair in September </strong><br /><br />
	Join us each September for the TOUR de SHASS campus fair. For a virtual tour online anytime, click on the photographs below for information about each of the MIT HASS fields.<br />
	 </p>

		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://web.mit.edu/sts/academic/undergraduate.html" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/200_sts-emblem.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></a></td>
			<td>
				<h2><strong>Science, Technology, and Society</strong> | Course STS</h2>

				<p> </p>

				<p><span class="largerx1">Field Office: E51-163<br />
					Main Number: 617-253-9759<br /><br />
					STS scholars ask such questions as: "How do changes in science and technology affect what it means to be human?,” and "How do science and technology express human values?"</span></p>
			</td>
		</tr><tr><td> </td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://mta.mit.edu/theater-arts" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/undergraduate/200_theater-emblem.jpg" style="width: 200px; height: 200px;" /></a></td>
			<td>
				<h2><strong>Theater Arts</strong> | Course 21M</h2>

				<p> </p>

				<p><span class="largerx1">Field Office: 4-246<br />
					Main Number: 617-253-3210<br />
					 <br />
					"Studying physics has enabled me to step back and analyze the mechanics of problems. Theater shows me how to examine them in terms of their human relevance."  </span><br /><em>— Kenneth L. Roraback SB '06 in Physics and Theater</em></p>
			</td>
		</tr><tr><td> </td>
		</tr><tr><td><a href="http://wgs.mit.edu/degree-requirements" target="_blank"><img alt="" src="http://shass.mit.edu/files/shass/cimg/inside/200x200_WGS-collage-emblem.jpg" /></a></td>
			<td>
				<h2><strong>Women’s and Gender Studies</strong> | Course WGS</h2>

				<p> </p>

				<p><span class="largerx1">Field Office: 14E-316<br />
					Main Number: 617-253-2642</span><br /><br /><span class="largerx1">“Re-vision—the act of looking back, of seeing with fresh eyes, of entering an old text from a new critical direction—is for women more than a chapter in cultural history: it is an act of survival."</span></p>
				<span class="smallerx1"><em>— Adrienne Cecile Rich (1929–2012), American poet and essayist</em></span></td>
		</tr></tbody></table><p> <strong>                                      </strong></p>
